This topic is used for travel/day trips in and around Switzerland.   Switzerland means it's OK to discuss continuing events in the neighboring countries or "How to drive from Switzerland to England/Czech Republic" etc.    
For travel to other countries, "Who's going to Ibiza this summer?" or "Who has tips about Japan?", then you can post them in  . An even better idea would be to search online for a travel forum that deals with the region. (Eg: the   or at  ).   
Sometimes we have "visitor" members who are coming to visit Switzerland. It's OK for them to post here, as the feedback they receive may be interesting to others here.    
Commercial posts are not allowed, however cunningly they may be hidden.

I'd totally pull that trick with some dodgy ticket website. But I would not do so with any airline I plan to use in the future...

Go 2nd class, it's far quieter and not many people, you get far better view than in the 1st class panoramic waggons which are usualy full of tourists.

IIRC Stoos has an airboard run - just not sure whether you can take your own tube.   
Even then I'd avoid "proper" sledge runs - a tube is going to be twice the width of a normal sledge and you're likely to cause a whole load of accidents blocking so much of a run.   
Stick to hillsides you can walk up and exist on common land.

Best to fill the car with potatoes and hagelslag.

post: One important thing is that the train you take has to stop in the station that is the last one in your area. For example, if you take a "fast"/direct train that does not stop there your local pass is not valid and you need an SBB ticket for the whole journey (or at least from the last real stop of that train in the area covered by your pass).

Every year around the second Sunday in December the SBB introduce the new timetable which is carved in stone for the next 12 months.    
The major changes this year concern the Gotthard route under the Alps to & from Tessin. The Base tunnel will now be operational and should cut 30 minutes off the journey. The old mountain route with the looping tunnels will still be used.    
There will also be an increase in prices, mainly on the season tickets / annual abonnements.

post:
Hi,   
If you're looking for an educational day out in Zurich:   
There will be a   at the Rote Fabrik cultural center in Zurich. At least 50% English spoken, so no language issues there...   
Some highlights: 
- all your 1980s home computers ready to play 
- minicomputers from the 1970s, like the PDP-11 with proper Blinkenlights 
- lots of creative DIY electronics around computers 
- video games from the very first one (from 1961) to the 1990s 
- Even some Big Iron mainframe computers: an IBM System 360   
Want to show your children what computers used to look like before the iPad? Or satisfy the Inner Geek?   
--> 19 & 20 November, Rote Fabrik, Seestrasse 395, Zurich             
Regards,   
Oscar.

post:
In a word: not very good (ok, in three words).   
First, forget about the top of Uetliberg. I did not quite realize how much light is up there. The whole path from the station to the hotel is lit, the whole terrace up there is lit, they even had fireworks   No good.   
Walk away a little and it gets better. I went down towards the city, I suppose one could also walk south along the ridge and find darker spots. I found a place relatively isolated and with a clear view. But by then clouds had rolled in. Just a few of them, but they catch and reflect city lights so well, it makes the whole sky way too bright.    
See   for example.    
And that's just for a relatively short exposure time, any longer and the picture is covered with clouds. There's no meteor in there, but there are planes. Those are also annoying. It's probably better to go later when air traffic has slowed down.    
Bottom line, Uetliberg may work but (1) walk away from the top, and (2) hope for perfectly clear conditions. Even so, I did manage to see a few meteors. A handful of bright shooting stars, and once my eyes were really accustomed to the dark (and this takes a while, not just a minute, but a good 15 minutes or so), fainter ones as well. I wished upon them for the clouds to go away, but it never worked    
Good luck to those who go hunting tonight.

Spent the past weekend in Bologna to see the   exhibit.   
It is indeed, despite some lapses & pitfalls, an incredible smorgasbord of sights and sounds. We were amazed by the sheer number of teenage fans (some w/ Bowie makeup as well!) that on sunday queued almost 3 hours (yep - do buy your tickets in advance, see link below) to visit the exhibit. Saw & heard many older fans singing along to the videos... a touching sight. 
[Note: this is the LAST date of the european tour, the exhibit will move on to Japan in 2017...you're warned...]   
The MAMBo museum is situated right by the city's historic centre, with its piazzas and score of shops, eateries and sundry foodie hangouts which makes for a great weekend getaway IMHO. 
If you plan to drive there are also other noteworthy visits: Bologna's "Food Valley", Maranello (hello Ferrari fans), Sasso Marconi, Palazzo Albergati, etc, etc...   
The train station is within 15minutes walking distance from the historic San Petronio church and square, and about 10 from the exhibit venue. There are high speed train connections from Milano Centrale (60 minute trip w/ @ 300km/h stretch if you're into that kind of stuff).   
Links to the Bologna exhibit:     [tour]   
Cheers & beers & rock'n'roll!   
Paul

Last September we spent a long weekend at the campsite in Aquacalda, just below the Lukmanier Pass.  It had good and bad points... 
Good: 
Nice restaurant attached to site 
Allowed campfires on pitches (and some had fire places built in) 
Next to a lovely stream 
Fantastic location for walking the mountains round the Lukanier pass, which are gorgeous   
Not so good: 
Pitches were very small (only just room for our 4 man tent and car) 
Site was very small and felt very cramped 
It's high altitude (1750m) and in September it got down to freezing by 8pm every night...  This would probably turn into a plus in the summer though!   
It's the only campsite in the area, so if you wanted to stay near the Lukmanier pass, it's your only option.  If you're going in the off season, it'd be lovely and quiet, but may be a bit cramped in the high season.  It'd definitely be worth calling ahead to book.

I've stayed at some of those.  Small doesn't always mean secluded and quiet with lots of open space. It can mean small and squashed together caravans that are old and decrepit and full of weird creepy people who live there permanently and make you feel like you're camping on their private lawn and whom you wouldn't want to leave your children with.   
You can get lovely campsites in the U.K, notably in Wales, the Lake District and Scotland where your dreams would be fulfilled.   
The concept doesn't exist here as far as I can see.

post: Cheers swissinfo, just checked and for the week in January I'm thinking the cheapest tickets are CHF 950. The BA flights (Basel > DXB) were a more wallet pleasing CHF 535. There are reasonable flights from London to Dubai via Bahrain and Doha with Gulf Air and Qatar Airways respectively. So I may also look into those as an alternative.

We traveled with Lufthansa Airlines from Frankfurt internationally, to the U.S. west coast (10+ hours) with a 1 year old and had a very positive experience. All our flight attendants were extremely kind and accommodating to our needs. We didn't have any problems on our flight and in fact Lufthansa service stood out to us as exceptional. We flew to the same destination on a different airline this summer, and in contrast the service was inferior compared to what we experienced with Lufthansa.

You might find places for this year if someone has cancelled a reservation, or the price was so high that no sane person would book, but I doubt you'll all be in the same chalet, you might not even all end up in the same village.

Took elderly visitors to the Titlis - the bridge over the cliff is easily accssible.   
With a UBS card you can also take the train to Schynigge platte for 10 CHF. the views are great, very easy stroll near the restaurant.

Walk is quite straightforward. Depending on your logistics check the times of the bus or train for your return trip as they are very patchy especially around lunchtime and/or out of season.     
If you want to do yourself a favor take lunch at La Remise which is excellent, in season you need to book to be safe.       
Just remember that Chamonix is subject to mountain weather, that is to say the forecast is broadly useless and weather can change suddenly so take a good waterproof coat and decent shoes.

Life of Pi. Just finished it, and loved it. It's described as fantasy, but perhaps not quite the genre you're after.   
Try Steven Donaldson, the Thomas Covenant trilogies (there's two of them). I particularly liked Stephen Lawhead Pendragon Cycle (arthurian legend) and The Paradise War trilogy.   
Another good take on Arthurian stuff is by Bernhard Cornwell - I think it's the "A Novel of Arthur"  series, starting possibly with the Winter King.   
I'm sure some are available on Kindle.

I wouldn't at this time of year, unless you enjoy sitting in traffic.

The government said UK officials helped at French border posts overnight and remain on standby after motorists suffered "extraordinary disruption", with some queuing for up to 14 hours. 
Delays began on Friday night and could last until Monday, police have warned. 
Kent Police said it would "proactively" manage traffic to ease congestion. 
On Sunday morning, the Port of Dover said passengers travelling on the A20 were still experiencing road delays of almost four hours and up to thirty minutes on the A2, followed by two-hour delays inside the port. 
A spokesperson told the BBC that current delays were due to more traffic heading to the port, as it continues to deal with Saturday's backlog.

Yes, it IS a big deal.  
How are they supposed to know you weren't just going to be a little late collecting the ticket? If they'd simply handed it on to someone else because you were five or ten minutes late at the reception desk you'd have been cross, and understandably so. These things are done on trust, you've now proved you don't deserve that trust.   
Each commune/gemeinde has access to a very limited number of these day passes, which they subsidise so that locals can have a day traveling around the country.... maybe making a trip to visit friends or family that they couldn't otherwise afford. Others buy them just for a cheaper day out, but that's fine too. By reserving and not collecting your ticket not once but four blooming times you've deprived others of that chance. 
Hopefully you'll get a bill not only for the four tickets but also a nice fat administration charge on top.  
How you were allowed to reserve tickets after the first or second non-show is a mystery, but fingers crossed you're now on your local commune/gemeinde blacklist and will never be allowed to be as selfish again.

post:
When I first moved here, I had a half-fare card. I kept a track of how much I spent on train tickets every month. Initially this was quite low.   
After I'd been here some time I realised that (due to changes in my circumstances) I was spending so much on train travel that it was worth my while to get the monthly general abonnement. (Incidentally, it is possible to buy an annual general abonnement which, at CHF 3656, works out cheaper than a monthly one, but you have to pay the total amount up front).    
I kept the general abonnement for several years, and really enjoyed having it as I could travel further afield in Switzerland at no additional expense, as well as making all my regular trips.    
Then my circumstances changed again and I cancelled my general abonnement (mainly because I couldn't afford to keep it).   
At some point (can't remember when) I also had a monthly travel pass which covered my canton, plus the half fare card. This enabled me to travel freely in Vaud (useful for my daily activities), but I could also benefit from reduced travel costs when I went outside Vaud.    
Most recently, I have had a monthly pass which just covers one specific journey, plus my half fare card.   
In summary, I would suggest that you get a half fare card to start with. They aren't expensive and will quickly pay for themselves if you travel any distance. Then keep a track of your expenses and after a few months work out what option (general abonnement, monthly pass for your canton, or point.to-point pass) is best for you.

They all look really nice and I wish I could go there myself. Unfortunately they also cost as much for one week as a return ticket for 3 weeks to Canada PLUS 1 week of camp there, so the Troll will cross the Atlantic on his own again this year.    
Maybe next year, once/if I find a job.

Le Chalet did not disappoint, but mind you nothing would with beautiful Gruyères under the snow, no tourist in sight, and the slopes of Moléson almost to ourselves, as CA Fribourg were not on holiday. I went for indeed 100% Vacherin fondue, although it no longer appears on the menu because apparently too many people trying it for the first time don't like it. I loved it but still think I prefer my moitié-moitié.     
Bindella Italian restaurant was where we ended up in Fribourg and the food was top range Italian, gorgeous, but service a bit slow.      
B&B on a farm, 5 minutes walk from the centre of Gruyères, was a little gem and outstanding value for money:

You are quite right, depending on how warm the spring is, there could well be snow on the walk between Männlichen and Kleine Scheidegg, we have certainly encountered it at the end of June, and of course the White Giants (the Jungfrau and its neighbours) are snowy all year round and with glaciers visible.  Only the end wall of the Jungfrau and the Silberhorn are visible from the floor of the Lauterbrunnen valley, but a higher elevation will reveal the three peaks, and there are mountains such as the Breithorn at the Stechelberg end of the valley should you head that way, and Schynige Platte and the Beatenberg visible if you walk down towards Interlaken.   
I would also recommend Lauterbrunnen as a base to rent an apartment for a week...... but then I would say that, wouldn't I, seeing as I spend nearly every holiday god sends here  ?

One of my very favourite train journeys is the trip from Montreux to Château d'Oex.    
Sadly you are just a few weeks too late for the Hot Air Balloon Festival, but it's a beautiful trip and Château d'Oex is a lovely village - especially at this time of year with all the snow.    
If you like travelling just for the fun of it, and if you enjoy hot chocolate, then I recommend going to Villars-sur-Ollon and having a hot chocolate at the café La Gourmandine. There's not a lot else to do there, but the hot chocolate is really wonderful. Here's a   I wrote about one of my trips there.    
A little later in the year, you could travel up to Les Avants to find the wild narcissi, which are a beautiful sight.    
Finally, (for a suggestion outside of Vaud) I really enjoyed visiting the   caves, near Interlaken. IT's a great trip - you travel by train, boat and bus from Vaud... and the caves are beautiful. They offer guided tours in English too.   
Have fun exploring!

post: Dachau is well worth the visit, the museum is good, well balanced and not overpowering, although Dachau was not a Vernichtungslager but a workcamp I would not say you can leave without tears in your eyes.   It was the main base to the concentration camp system that spread all over Bavaria, for a While I lived in Bobingen in a old hardended factory building on what was once the production facilities of IG-Farben, it was a center for explosives production, now it is in the middle of the forest and undisturbed since 1945, the ground in parts of the areal were still classed as explosive as late as 1980. Now it is pristine forest with the remains of blown bunkers and ammo dumps, including a complete railwaystation.   The wildlife love it, the hall I lived and worked in was huge with a set of massive folding doors, one night I was working late my skin started to crawl and I knew that even though I was alone in the building I was being watched   I turned and there were two deer in the doorway having a gander at what the monkey at the computer was up to.

post:
Also, if you do not get a reply today, send them a picture of your suitcase (or similar) and any identifier to help the search. Baggage tags?     
In principle what happens is that they have a suitcase somewhere with a luggage tag and the flight information that belongs to you. The luggage tag will be scanned and that then will show up in the tracking system. From there as soon as your luggage has been identified it will be flown to your final destination. There again it will be scanned and then finally you will be contacted for the delivery.     
IF your luggage has lost the luggage tag (identifier), it helps giving them as much information on your luggage as you can.     
And for the future: always staple/tag a business card on the inside of your suitcase. If it gets to the point that they open it to search for the owner, they will find your business card and can contact you accordingly.

Yep both beautiful - my neck of the woods- but in the Neuchâtel Jura, not the Jura Canton.   
The word 'Jura' confuses many. It is a Swiss Canton, A French  department, a French region (that includes Jura, Doubs, Franche-Comté)  and a Swiss region (which included part of Vaud, part of Neuchâtel, part  of Bern and part of Basel Kantons too- with the massive long hike from  Geneva to Basel, doable over a week or more, on foot, by mountain bike  or ski de fond/Langlauf.   
BTW 10.30, calling Le Doubs a small river is a bit unfair. It is 453 km long and the 10th longest in France- so a 'small river' it is not

I also used rentalcars.com (Now based in Athens !) and booked a Ford Escort with EuropCar at Bristol airport. I did the pre rental checks and found 5 items not listed. The office which was responsible closed at 5pm, so I went back to the issuing desk and got them to note down the extra damages, all now OK.    
Later, driving on the M6 a warning light came on, and there was no driver's handbook. I stopped at a service station & looked closely and decided it was the tyre under inflation warning. So I adjusted all the tyres to 2.5 ATU and reset the tyre check system. No other problems, but not having the handbook could have been a big problem. I have the tyre check system on my Skoda, so luckily I was aware of it, and knew what to do.

Dear all, 
I have recently visited Geneva during the week-end with some friends. I had quite low expectations as Geneva did not sound like a very fun and interesting place to me, but I changed my mind during the visit.   
We found out about these "Greeters", who are basically locals offering free walking visits to tourists and bring them off-the-beaten tracks. Our greeter was a young man studying architecture, he had a great passion for his city and showed us things we would not have seen by ourselves. We really enjoyed it because it is a great way to see the city from the inside and discover things besides the touristy spots (the water fountain, the old town, etc). We also had nice discussions about the everyday life, our personal lives, and compared living in Zürich with Geneva. At the end of the stroll, we even went out for a drink together. The best thing is that it is very genuine: these Greeters don't event ask for tips or any money.   
I recommend it if you want to visit the Romandie with a local :-) I am not sure if it exists in other cities of Switzerland but it would be great to have it here. 
Cheers, 
Alain

That is the Pas de Chèvres, which is a more difficult variant on the standard route. It can be easily avoided by going over the Col de Riedmatten, which is right next to it. The Col de Riedmatten is steep on the Cabane des Dix side (i.e. the uphill side if doing the walk in the "normal" direction), but not in any way difficult or dangerous.   
I don't remember there being any other ladders...  a few cabled sections, especially if you go all the way to Zermatt via the Europaweg, but I wouldn't rate it as any more than a solid T3 on the Swiss Alpine Club scale.

1. The Rent-A-Bike website has a Reservation tab at the Tour level. 
2. You could check the weather forecast the day before and then make the reservation based on the weather forecast. 
3. I looked at the number of bicycles available for a number of the tours to judge which ones were popular. The tour with possibly the greatest number of bicycles, about 200, is Airolo to Biasca (#12).  
- You could buy an all-in ticket through RailAway, taking the train from Basel to Airolo. Then ride 40km on your rented bicycle downhill direction Biasca, stopping at a Grotto for lunch, e.g., Grotto dei Due Ponti. Then continue to Biasca and drop bicycle there. Return to Basel on train. This would be a full day.   
Also, these tours are self-guided with signs.
Just don't go in October:

Airbnb is people renting part of their home or their apartment to travellers/visitors. Hence, all properties are furnished because no one travels with furniture    
2k for 2.5 bedroom apt sounds normal if it is in Zurich city and big enough. Give us more details of the apt and we could tell you.   
You look like you are looking for sublets, which might be found on other websites.

Somehow really love this post! People that give great advice and people that are actually listening.   
Hope the OP enjoyed the time in Italy and can make it to CH not too far down the road

Not for Swissward, who knows what the problem with the parents is, but  'I cannot walk very far' can mean anything. Heart trouble, lung trouble, hip pain, knee problems, or just lack of training. 
The Spouse mentions a problem with the altitide which may have to limit Alpine trips, even in a cable-car or a post bus.  A friend of mine had a stroke while still young and can walk up gentle hills with a stick quite well, IF the surface is smooth. Downhill however is a problem whether it is smooth or not.    
And don't forget, even if heart and lungs are fine,  from the age of about sixty upwards it takes longer  to 'get going'. Pulse rate is down and the blood circulation in the leg  muscles is still in 'watching TV mode' and hasn't increased yet. The  first ten minutes or so can give the impression one is totally incapable  of managing a longer walk or a bike-ride. Take it really easy to start with. Give yourself time to enjoy the wonderful countryside.

Yes, it can be purchased from the French ticket machine at the SBB, as Adrian said, and I have used a credit card there successfully as well.   
Its a great deal on the weekend when an entire family can travel for little more than price of one.   
On weekdays, its worth it more when doing multiple-leg trips, such as Basel-Colmar-Route du Vin by bus 106. A direct day trip to Colmar you wont benefit much over single ticket.   
You can also economize by buying only for the zone you need, Haut-Rhin, Bas-Rhin, which are cheaper than the entire Alsace ticket.

Hi, Obvious answer but we have been going to Portugal for the past 20 years, second week of January and you can't go wrong. We stay at the Marina Hotel in Vilamoura and it's perfect. Our main reason for returning is we can count on one hand the amount of days lost to weather.   
Vilamoura has 5 courses, then on your doorstep you've got Vila Sol, 3 courses at Quinta do logo, 2 at Vale do Lobo and San Lorenzo which has just been redeveloped, but to play usually means staying at the Dona Filipa Hotel. This is just the best local ones, there are many more!   
The Algarve although great can be expensive, so a lot of golfers are now heading to the Antalya/Belek region of Turkey. Courses and hotels are normally All inclusive and really good quality and value. Main problem we found was we like to get out and about a little in the evenings, and the Turkey option was not great on this front. But hotels and courses could not be faulted.

post: I think you are underestimating yourself with 15 km/day.  Last Sunday my family of 4 with an 8 and a 10 year old averaged 16 km/hr and went from Neuchatel to Yverdon (40 total km) in 2.5 hours.

It shouldn't be too hard to find a place which rents gear. For example, Bächli has a shop in Zurich and rents out  , but there may be better deals out in the small mountain towns.   
Also, don't underestimate the dam. I know people who were quite active climbers leading up to their trip and turned back after a few pitches. It is long, and overhanging, and there really isn't a place to rest. One planned to bring some sort of hanging seat next time, to be able to recover better while belaying.   
And finally, WTF is a "certified lead climber"? The Swiss gyms that I know will let anybody sign a form saying that they know how to lead, and you don't normally get to practice actually installing quick draws in the gym. Personally, I'd only go out with somebody who I trust both technically and attitude wise, and excepting IFMGA level credentials (which of course, are a whole nother level), I don't think any certification would be part of that judgement.

was at Holiday Inn Express Arena towers 2 weeks ago, close to the Biljmer Arena which is a main train station with 15 min direct line to the airport and to the main city. Rates are at par with the smaller ones near the city center. The neighborhood is a quiet business district.  Kids will appreciate the cleaner air at night  . I'd skip the Glacier Express. It takes too much time, plus I prefer being outside, on the mountains, and have the time to enjoy the view.   
1 day: Instead of Jungfrau I'd do Schilthorn. Way cheaper, less people, and in some sense better view because you see the Jungfrau as well.   
2 day: Then the glacier you can check by visiting the Aletsch as suggested below plus Zermatt area   
1 day: You could combine Titlis and Luzern. On Titlis try the scooter and devil bikes.   
1 day Ticino: Bellinzona, Locarno, up to Cardada   
1 day: You could combine Zürich with a great hike to the Grosser Mythen. Or, I you'd prefer a lazy day, then Zürich, Rhine Falls, Schaffhausen, Rapperswil, then take the ship all the way back to Zürich, and finally up to Uetliberg.    
and/or:   
1 day Klettersteing in Braunwald, there are routes with different difficulties, and you can rent everything in the hut up there.   
1 day: Lausanne, Montreux, Les Diablerets, Glacier 3000    
 ..and don't forget to check SBB's offers of the month:

We have used this one before to find b and b's in the area that we wanted:

There are no points on a Swiss license.     
Some countries (like Italy) might choose to create you a point account for Italy using your swiss details, from which they will deduct point from infractions whilst driving there and eventually ban you.  But this is unlikely to happen unless you really get stopped for a big one.

Timed connections usually wait, and if they don't the train conductor should inform you of the next available connection. I'm very relaxed about German trains. Even when things go wrong they tend to not to go catastrophically wrong.   
I don't know if its a cool design in the software or that I've just been lucky, but I've often noticed that when changing trains to another train on the same platform or across the platform that the car with my reserved seat stops in exactly or close to the place where I got off. So I hardly ever need to drag bags the full length of the platform.

That's the route we always take. 
The slowest part for us is driving through Biel but you won't have that problem.

Hi there Baltser   
Have you looked at the Swiss Alpine huts ?? 
These vary from quite comfortable houses, to very small basic shelters. Most are on the top of the mountains here, and all are in the middle of walking paths of mountain trails.   
You need to bring your own sleeping bags of covers, as just duvets or blankets are supplied. There might be showers ( if you're lucky ) or just washing facilities.   
They are relativly cheap, and can serve evening meal and breakfast.   
It's possible to plan multi day walks, walking from hut to hut.   
Hope the weather is good for you ...

Glad to find this post...   
We've been in ZH since Jan and have tried to start as we mean to go on; and have managed the following so far: 
- St Moritz for White Turf (train - 3hrs) 
- Bern for YB vs Everton game (train - 1hr) 
- Milan for sightseeing, shopping and risotto alla milanese (train - 4hrs) 
- Konstanz for sightseeing and shopping (train - 1.5hrs)   
We've also the following booked: 
- Graz to visit frends (flight - 1hr) 
- Istanbul + Dubai for sightseeing and to visit family (flights - 2.5hrs, 4hrs)   
..and these are on our agenda: 
- Geneva as a comparable to ZH in CH (train - 3hrs) 
- Monaco via Nice to see how the other half live! (flight - 1hr) 
- Vienna + Budapest for sightseeing (overnight train - 9hrs + 1hr) 
- Berlin to see what's left of the wall (flight - 1.5hrs)   
The kicker here is that weekend tickets to all of these destinations are available at under CHF 200 return, if you're a little flexible with times.   
If anyone has tips for getting tickets under CHF 100 return to other "must see" destinations, I'd love to hear them!

A bit late now as we are getting towards the end of the season. I took a couple of Neuch expats to try their ski legs a couple ot times at the very small resort of Les Fourgs, on the other side of the border- perfect for learning and very cheap ski hire and lifts. Snow is disappearing fast- but if we go again, I'll tell you about it. Best would be to have a few private lessons, with a few friends (they might be interested)- your best bet is to go to Les Fourgs or Métabiefs (both on French side, near St Croix and above Vallorbe)- Swiss ski school in the Jura tend to do group lessons on a weekly basis - rather than odd hour here and there.

If you like some celtic/french atmosphere you could rent a house à la mer in bretagne, the cornouaille is very nice (better climate than the northern coast), lots of things to see, beautiful villages, very good plâteaus de fruits de mer, sidre, regional beer, ideal for biking and BBQ. 
The negatives are: the bathrooms may smell of piss, the climate is very variable and water temperature is prohibitive. further south in the atlantic coast is more expensive i think.

Ouch.   
I've been pretty bruised from running up there.   
TBH, I won't run up there this time of year unless I'm carrying some running spikes.

The Greenwich based Ski Company often has 'filler' places at very low prices- just check with them if you, a couple, a small group or family fancy some last minute deals. They do have groups coming over from UK that do not actually fill their accom to full capacity- and will sell the last few places at really low rates. Just check with them:      or call 020 8858 9535.   
They are based in Torgon, Portes du Soleil, but also do weeks in Crans, Les Crozets, Arosa, and more.   
This is NOT an advert- I've been a very happy customer for about 20 years- bringing so many school, family and friends groups with the Ski Co. Just tell them (Gerry the boss, Ollie or Becky his right hands) that you are in CH and do not need transport. They do their own excellent in house ski and snowboard rental, are right next to the slopes linking to the whole to the Portes du Soleil- work very closely with the Ski/snowboard school that is in the same building, and the Gold Test ski shop, in the same building too- their own brand. Tell them (or not- I get nothing from recommendations- that Odile sent you). Look the up on FB too. Staff are all Brits, Kiwis and Ossies.

post:
Well, snow cover has been poor in the Jura, otherwise there are many easy accessible resorts not far from Neuchâtel for the future, with special train tickets combined with lift pass and even lunch. La Robella is 2 mins walk from the train station in Buttes, and perhaps you could try Les Bugnenets too- but check snow first.   
Champery-Les Crozets is really nice- cable-car up to the restaurant and shops- then a huge bowl with slopes for every level of skier- difficult to advise more than that. Lots of beginner slopes as well as reds and blacks of every shade. Restaurants dotted around the mountain are nicer than the one at top. Young guys I know there are all crazy snowboarders  though    
I like Champéry because it is a small town before it is a resort- but you won't have time to visit this time. The best if the view of my favourite mountains, les Dents du Midi. Another time, why not go to Verbier- train to Martigny, change for Le Châble, and then bubble up to Verbier and on to slopes (without changing bubble = avoiding Verbier queues).

post: In December we stayed in a cabin in Schwyz. We booked it through airbnb and it was titled Kleinod - little gem in Rickenbach. If you Google that you should find it. It was well priced and clean, spacious with views to die for. It's a mountain cabin though so not much help for visiting Lucern since you'll have to pay for the cable car each time. Very nice for a few days to get the Swiss mountain experience. Highly recommended.

Well, some offers can be purchased online (like cheap tickets to milan from zurich) and other offers (like Interrail global or Interrail one country Pass) can be purchased online (interrail.eu) or at the ticket office (zurich HB for example).   
1.Make plans well ahead, where to go.   
2.Buy tickets well ahead( it is possible to purchase rail tickets 3 months in advance, so be ready at midnight in europe to buy your ticket online to save a lot of money). Reservations should be made with the ticket purchasing. 
3. Compare prices in the internet  of every country where you want to go, for example when you want to visit a city in germany , it could be cheaper to buy a ticket in germany (from the border station to your destination) and a ticket in switzerland(with a half tax card)

Honestly, I can't follow your rant, neither.   
Well, if you use a tool the wrong way, no surprise it seems to be highly unruly. But thats not the tools (websites) problem, but the users one, of course. If you try to use a potato peeler to open a coconut, you will eventually fail.    
SBBs site sells tickets,  (you say: domestic)   (trains/buses/trams etc.), and   (or terminate here).     you   purchase train tickets on SBB's site for Italian national (domestic)  trains, or lets say French, or German, or . whatever foreign domestic connections, which are not under SBBs fare control/sovereignty.     I know of, though you   (almost)   on both, on  , as well as on   for example. But you   compare or even purchase foreign domestic train tickets on bahn.de, nor on trenitalia.it,  !  I think you got this first part of the message, dont you?!?    
Let's say, if you want to buy a flight from Zurich to New York with Swiss, and then from NYC to Boston by a US-american airway which provide this connection (but not by Swiss) thats exactly the same and you have to purchase two tickets on two different sites, why then should it be different for railways, though  I totally agree  it would be extremely convenient for the traveler, but it just simply contradicts the free market idiology! (except that Swiss probably fly to Boston from NYC as well!?)  However, your compatriots would probably call it a socialistic approach then, I suppose?    
Second thought you have to know: You will have to change the train in Milano. From there you can take the high speed train from Milano to Rome, which takes only 3 hours for about 600km, because its max speed is over 320km/h (an experience for itself)! But this is a national (oh pardon-me: domestic) connection!!!   
Third thought:  . Thats the simple reason   (like TGVs, trenitalias, or DBs do), since the fares are anyhow the same for whatever connection you are interested in. Well, except for some international trains, which, however, are not Swiss railways cash cow!   
I hope this clears your initial novice confusion.      It was neither a question of time, nor of inability to track back, but of not being available at all. SBBs site   suppresses any information as soon as they are available (quite contrary to other sellers).       As it says, ZVV is thought for ZVVs fare network (canton of Zurich plus some adjoining ones), though you find the same (schedule) information as on SBBs site, just differently presented (since it accesses the same data base), and cannot sell Switzerland-wide tickets!      ,  !       OP, if you do not really have  to take care about 100 bucks, or even less (see below), I thoroughly would not advice you to travel by bus; it is just a horrible experience I would not even wish for my enemies, especially not for 12+ hours duration.    
And finally: A one way ticket Zurich-Milano can be as cheap as CHF 28. A one-way ticket Milano-Rome can be as cheap as  29.  
That means you can comfortably travel for only about   both ways, if you are smart enough. Hardly beatable, I think.    
PS: I just simply groan at you, since you groaned at rob1s post, which was simply unjustified.

Thank y'all, again, for taking the time to respond.   
I thought I should let you know what we ended up doing.   
One day, we just took a tram ride through Zurich and then a boat ride on Lake Zurich - the four hour tour. Very convenient, of course, as it did not entail any walking whatsoever.   
The second day, we took the train to Lucerne - walk 100m to the boat to Vitznau - walk 50m to the train up the Rigi, take in the view over the mountains (no walking) and the same way back. We were so lucky, because it was all foggy on the way there, until we made our way through the clouds on the way up to the Rigi, right into the sunshine. And on the way back, it was all sunny.   
My dad was happy, could take little naps here and there - and with a boat, it seems you cannot go wrong for a man.

7 to 8 years old is difficult, maybe the Zoo (  Tierpark)  
there are two parts, top and bottom. Top is conventional, bottom is children's zoo (Free).   
Outside the Gotthard cinema, take the Bus nr. 19 towards  , & get off at   stop.  
Walk eastwards, & then walk through the woods & down the hill.  
Halfway down is the zoo entrance, at the bottom is the restaurant, kid's park, & river.                    
School holidays in Bern too, so there might be pony rides (about Fr 5 extra) 
Feeding times,   10.30 Uhr: Seals,       14.30 Uhr: Puffins,         15.30 Uhr: Seals     (again)   
Small animal zoo, & Restaurant and playground are down by the river.

post: The card will get you as far as Wengen or Grindelwald.  From there onwards it is half-price

If you're in Vallorbe, there are 3 major things to visit: 
 -The caves (Grottes) 
 -The Iron and railroad museum 
 -The 2nd WW fort (Pré-Giroud Fort 1939-1945)   
You can also fish some trout nearby the cave parking lot (for a fee of course).
I like the excuvations under the cathedral.
We could organize an EF event to re-arrange the deck chairs?

Take the train to Gruyere and back.  It is essential that you become familiar with Gruyere and the cheese factory tour and the Cailler chocolate factory tour in nearby Broc because when you start having visitors, this will be the number one thing on your itinerary.     
Trust me, I have been there now about 12 times.  Ditto for the day trip to Montreux and Chateau de Chillon.  Take the train to Montreux.  Walk along the waterfront.  Hop on the bus that runs along the lake and stops at the chateau.  Tour the chateau.  Take the bus back to the Montreux waterfront.  TAKE THE ESCALATOR right next to the lighting shop up to the gare, (unless you want to carry a stroller up 5 flights of stairs).   
On a clear day, take the car to Leysin.  Park at the gondola.  Take the gondola up to the restaurant Kuklos.  Eat fondue in the revolving restaurant, (not the self-serve cafeteria on the lower level) and watch the crazy parapenters jump off the mountain.  (You need to check the dates on this--the gondola might be closed for the season.)

If you are still looking for a beautiful but relatively close scenic spot, try Thun. It's around an hour away and easily accessible by train. I went with my partner a few months ago and it was wonderful. Very traditional and Swiss, especially if you stay near the old castle at the top of the hill.   
Also try to make it to the lakeside, as the view towards the Eiger and Jungfrau is simply breathtaking! You can stop there in Schloss Schadau, a large (surprisingly pink) castle-turned-hotel for a great brunch.

post:
Hi All,   
I recently went to this Outlet. I'll have to back up what someone posted earlier in these threads about the prices being very normal or even higher, with no real discounts to be found. For what would be considered a fair price in USD for the item, will be the price you will see in Euros. 30-40% higher than what I would consider a good price coming from Canada.   
If you are from the US or Canada, this place is definitely not cheap for an 'outlet'. Nike / Adidas running shoes are around 80-100 euros for the nicer models (the out of style clearance ones that aren't selling can be as low as 50 euros). I wouldn't say this is extremely expensive or anything, but for an outlet, and a place where you are normally looking for deals, it definitely is not cheap.     
I think if you are used to normal brand prices in Europe, you might be happy with these prices, a North American would definitely not be.    
Also, when I was there, the place was completely overrun, can barely walk through some of the stores without bumping shoulders.    
Pros: It is a very nice outlet by American standards, you can do all your shopping in one place, and you can make a trip to Swabian Alps / Black Forest out of it.

If you're in the good shape you say you are in, then you can do the whole tour de dents du midi imo. Take the train into Champery very early Friday morning and hike to auberge de salanfe. Saturday hike to Auberge de Chindonne, Sunday back to Champery.  Here's more info:  
Btw, there might be snow on the dents du midi but the trail goes at a lower altitude around it.   
What you can do will depend mostly on the weather. I'd prepare 1 good and 1 bad weather option and decide on Tuesday/Wednesday what to do.   
If the forecast looks iffy I would rather go to a "popular" mountain place (Chamonix, Zermatt, Riederalp, Grindelwald, Leukerbad). There are often many hiking trails in these areas, there are more bad weather options for when it rains and cable cars bring you quickly up to a nice altitude. 
Also, even the popular places aren't very busy in-between the summer and the winter season (minus perhaps Jungfraujoch).
I know Ian, he's not Scottish.

Yesterday, myself and the trouble-and-strife went on a beautiful hike in the Fribourg pre-Alps. We drove up to Crau Rappo from Le Mouret, on the road from Marly to Bulle/Broc. From there we walked to La Berra, passing just below the peak of Le Cousimbert and back again. It took us 4 hrs all in, including a couple of refreshments breaks. The reason I mention it is not just the fantastic vistas; the Alps to one side, the plains down to Lac Neuchâtel in the other, but it is not too taxing and we saw many familes with prams and the elderly along the route (as well as a handful of MTBers). Was a perfect day for it too  . 
Next I plan to bike it.
Not perfect visibility.  It was good early and clouded up a bit later

post:
On my way back from a work trip to Geneva we decided to stop over in Ivrea, which is on the way down from the Mt. Blanc tunnel in direction of Torino.   
We slept in a modern / cool B&B called Spazio Bianco, which is located in the old town (Eur 95/night, incl. very nice breakfast).   
Apéro right below the B&B at a bar called MoMa - I can't remember just how many different permutations of the classic cocktails were on the list...! (heh was nicely buzzed by the time we went to dinner)   
Had dinner at a restaurant called La Mugnaia, in the old town. De-li-cious 4 course menu for 42 euros p.p. (wine not included).   
At a short walking distance from the B&B you will also find a very nice patisserie called Balla and right besides a trattoria, "Blupum", run by one of Italy's most talented chefs, Davide Scabin... Would have been our first choice, but unfortunately was closed (warning - need to book "well in advance" we were told). I'm looking forward to a foodie safari in the coming weeks, so hopefully I'll be back with some more foodie reporting...     
Bon voyage!   
Paul

Hi Nev, 
Thanks so much for your suggestions.  I made it to Chateau Torbillon.  The view and the light were absolutely stunning.  I got up there sometime after 3 p.m. and the sun was just starting to go down.   
I obviously got a late start.  I had hard time finding the courage to face the cold.   
I did wander around the old town, very charming.  Great for taking pictures.  Most shops there were closed, but there was a cafe open.   
Afterwards, I headed to the concert in the Catherdral.  The singers were impressive.  And afterwards, I walked around and looked at the Christmas lights.     
I missed the cake and drinks after the show.  I didnt find out that was happening until I was back home

Yes, the restaurant is a proper fondue place, they're the oldest cheesehouse in town. It's actually a raclette/fondue stube. 
 If you go up Sunnegga is another place for having a good meal on the terrace - you have that buffet with salads, soups (an Austrian style goulash yam), rösti, etc. and the prices are also very good.

Ten excusions developed by Joëlle Chautems, who wrote a few books about 
nature's energy.

I too am biased in favour of this area; here is Lauterbrunnen, described in an article I read recently as "one of the most beautiful places on God's green earth"       
The Jungfrau region is very popular with tourists from all over the world, but don't let that put you off; there are hiking paths to suit all abilities, through shady woods, across open moors, amongst rolling green turf, and by tinkling mountain streams, all with amazing views and often chiming cow bells.  Lauterbrunnen has the 2 sites, Camping Jungfrau and Camping Schützenbach, both within easy walking distance of the little town itself and the train station.  Actually both campsites are just tucked out of sight on either side of the valley in this photo.   
Welcome, and I hope you enjoy your time in Switzerland and become as fond of Bern and its Oberland as we are.

We drove to Malcesine on Lake Garda 2 weeks ago (a Sunday).  It's a good location for water sports. We left Zurich at 12 noon stopped 1 hour for lunch along the way and went over the Gotthard Pass as it was our first time and we wanted to see it.  There are a lot of roadworks on the route and a lot of traffic jams.  Despite keeping to the 120/130 (IT/CH) Autobahn speed limits we were very surprised to arrive finally at 8pm.  If you drive up the East side of the lake it's one very busy (particularly Sat and Sun) single lane road with a 50km speed limit.  The return journey took 6 hours helped by a drive-thru McDonalds lunch!

post:
I'm skiing mad... but Zermatt is nicer in summer for definite.   
Zermatt in winter, really the only thing to do is ski. The weather has a habit of being horrendous. At the top of Klein Matterhorn temperatures below -20 are a daily occurrence and often there are very high winds.   
Zermatt is summer, is warm, you can ski (although it is limited), hike, bike, walk around town without breaking your neck, it is quieter without being a ghost town.. it is generally much more chilled out and relaxed.   
Go and learn to ski somewhere else and have a nice summer weekend in Zermatt.

I used to live in Burgau just down the road from Günzburg, little town on the Danube. 
There are two villages if you go direction of Krumbach for a few Clicks Kleinkötz and Grosskötz, with B&B and some hotels, busses run every hour.. 
Interesting little tit-bit of history (warning Godwins law may be invoked) 
From the Kaiserreich onwards, during the 100.000 man army of the Weimarer Republic to our "buddies" '33 to '45 and after that up to the eighties under American control. The whole area was an ammunition storage and surplus dump. 
Lego got the area for very, very cheap but only if they cleaned the place up of all munitions, this was done with a fine tooth-comb over a long period of time, longer then the actual building of Lego land. 
Sadly three people were killed by exploding ammunitions during the clean-up. 
If I recall there is a plaque in the grounds somewhere.

3 years ago we bought a voucher for a 'freedreams' Hôtel stay in CH, where you only have to pay for meals. Had a lovely week-end, not cheap as the 'compulsory' menu and wine was quite expensive, but we were very happy, and bought another one for the Grisons- same again.   
We were then contacted by Freedreams to ask if we wanted to buy a card valid for one year, rather than individual vouchers. We agreed, but due to health and family problems, were not able to use it even once (CHF199) and forgot about it. And yes, now got a bill for 189CHF special renewal price ! for this year. Phoned them to say we didn't want it, and that we had not been able to use last year's at all- but they said it was renewed automatically- so an annual card, not a card for 1 year- and we had to give 3 months notice to cancel. I e-mailed them to ask them to reconsider- but verdict arrived today- pay up or else. And yes, I've checked and it is somewhere hidden in the small print. So you've been warned  (and yes, it is me who has often said 'never sign a contract without making sure you understand the small print   ). I thought some of you would really enjoy knowing that even the Swiss get Switzerlanded...
Nock Nock  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>      "Fly list"

post:
Thanks for all the suggestions. For some reason I didn't get to see the replies before coming back home again, but all's well as we decided to go to Mürren for a couple of days and had a fantastic time! Quiet (but not too quiet) and relaxing small village with a good choice of restaurants, ATM machines, hotels, a small supermarket, post office and some souvenir shops mostly.   
Even getting there was quite an adventure, taking the gondola from Lauterbrunnen and small mountain train at the top to the village. Going back home we took the Schilthorn gondola down to Gimmelwald where we walked around and had a look, and stopped by at the cafe/guesthouse just by the gondola. Very nice village, but I agree that there doesn't seem to be much happening there although it's most definitely worth visiting for something different.    
While staying in Mürren we also took the fenicular up to Allmendhubel (a 4 minute ride up to Mürren's local mountain top) where there was a nice restaurant, a flower trail and children's trail/mountain playground. Unfortunately they were in the midst of building a new playground/trail while we were there there (which looks to become very nice at the end of this month). Instead of taking the fenicular down again we took a very nice mountain walk (easy, mostly quite flat strolling -also with a 4 year old) and stopped by a nice mountain hut where we had excellent home made food before we continued down to Mürren again.   
And I mustn't forget Schilthorn (the James Bond film location if someone is wondering). The gondola ride isn't long from Mürren: first around 6 minutes to Birg, then change over to another Gondola for another 4 or 5 minutes. The weather couldn't be better, and what a view at 2970m!   
An unforgettable adventure. Next time we'll see if we can visit Grindelwald on the other side of the valley.

All those suggestions are excellent. Probably the best parks for your needs are Margarethenpark and Schützenmattpark. You and your daughter will meet plenty of other expats in both, but also hear lots of German. Both parks have paddling pools in summer.   
Kannenfeldpark, near the Novartis Campus, is also quite attractive.   
Bonus: all three of these parks have a café in or adjoining them (Schützenmatt's is the best, IMO).   
Okidoki can be something of a zoo (and a very noisy one at that), especially when it's raining.  I think you'll find  , a little further into Germany (you'll need a car) much more inviting and overall, more tolerable!   
And if you have a car and a full day to spare, I guarantee that your daughter and indeed your whole family will love  , rain, hail or shine. (Entry fees apply, of course -- also to Okidoki and Nepomuks.)

It the city centre!   
The bridge furthest away in the photo is Quaibrücke. Burkliplatz and Bellevue tram stops are on either end of the bridge, or you can walk there easily from HB - just turn left out of the main entrance of the station, cross the road at the pedestrian crossing in front of the large Coop supermarket, walk round the Coop to the river and there's a path that runs along the river edge all the way down to the lake - takes about ten minutes.   
The body of water beyond it is the lake, the large church on the left is the Grossmünster, and the church opposite is the Fraumünster.

post: This is a great deal, thanks for posting it.

I spent a couple of hours today with a 60chf day pass bought for 45chf on ricardo. Am not from industry and do not wear either jewelry nor watches, but still thought it was worth the time and money.    
The design and craftsmanship of the jewelry was very good.  The big names - Rolex, Cartier, etc. were about as welcoming to the non-trade public as a Nato summit would be to Putin .. however, the lighting and architecture of their exhibits, even from the outside was quite interesting.   
The day card can be used for unlimited entries and exits, not personalized. So the wife went in after me on the same ticket. Hopefully she's not coming out with a 100,000chf watch, negating all savings.   
So if you and a few friends have an hour or two each,  worth sharing a day pass for a glimpse of fashion and design.

And so I went. 
I arrived at around 8:20 or so, parked in Laax.  
People were already starting to arrive, but it was still not crowded.  
The weather was cloudy at the bottom   
I was the last person to get on the gondola, so did not have to wait, which was nice (the feeling of being a canned sardine was not especially nice, though...but you get that everywhere).   
The weather at the top was foggy, but the fog was quite thin.  
I could actually (barely) make out the mountains in the distance...on a clear day it must be magnificent. 
I went up to Cram Masegn, where we were told that due to windy conditions you could not reach higher points (e.g., the glacier).    
The snow was very hard in the morning, my joints started complaining very quickly.  
As time went by, the lower parts of the pistes started becoming softer, and as more time went by they became full of slushy moguls.  
The wind also seemed to pick up at the higher points, later on.  
So you would start skiing very hard snow at the top, and finish up over slushy moguls. 
The snow conditions did not make it the the best fun for me   
Overall it was not too crowded, i'd say. i did not have to wait more than 3 minutes in any queue.  
The pistes  did feel crowded at times, but I think that was because skiers at my level were struggling with the moguls    
The resort itself is amazing, at points it feels like it's just one huge piste.  
Everything feels new. The 6-seater lifts are children-safe, fast and very comfortable.  
The piste selection is huge and the pistes themselves are wide and well-groomed.  
With so many many of them, though, you may make the wrong turn somewhere and end up somewhere you did not intended to be (as I did a couple of times  )   
I could not unfortunately make it to the other side (Fuorcla, LaSiala), because piste 43 was closed.   
I'm definitely going back sometime. 
However, it makes for quite an expensive outing: lift pass + parking + gas make it a well over 100chf day trip.  
For me, it's probably not best for single day trips. 
Next time I'll be staying for a little longer    
Also, the ticket guy said i could not get the 5chf card deposit back  
But he asked if I had any other resort's card with me (which I didn't), so I think that it may be a good idea to bring one with you the first time you visit the resort, it may save you 5chf.   
cheers 
j.

post: Of course hiking on the Rigi or one of the neighboring mountains is always fantastic. They should have some winter hiking trails open as well.
Yverdon-les-Bains is nice, but I think the nearby Estavayer-le-Lac is much more impressive. So if you have a few hours left on your day trip then I can recommend that place as well.

The Centovalli in Tessin is one of my all time favourites - beautiful, mystical & magical, full of hidden artists, great food and creativity. 
Ascona is also very close by and watching the full moon over the lake is truly an enchanting experience ... could be that you might be awake late at night sometimes with a 7 month your old baby? 
Enjoy your journeys!

Well I didn't know how good the Snow&Tail ticket could be, especially for a whole week, including reduced lift pass and ski/board rentals, so it's certainly interesting, but the hotel offers seem to be the same prices as going direct to the hotel or through other booking sites.

It's a bit tricky for me, as although we've got similar aged children, skiing is a big part of what we do on "snow" holidays.   
For me, my initial reaction is Engelberg, heading over to Brunni rather than the main place (Titlis).   
Somewhere we go to quite a lot is Pilatus for day trips. The first stop has a play park with snow around it, but not accommodation.   
Otherwise resorts that I think would be of interest would be ones where you are near the snow at the start of the day (i.e. rather than having to treck up any mountain) e.g. Arosa, Laax, Flims, Crans-Montana (specifically Crans) and Gstaadt.   
Alternatively you could look for spa resort-type places in the mountains with no ski facilities. But I don't have any recommendations for these in mind.   
Have fun and take some spare clothes for the children!

has a nice big forest hut that the Gemeinde rents out - cost is +- Sfr100 a day/evening - but you have to leave it in clean condition by 9am the next morning. 
It has a big indoors room with benches/tables, small kitchenette, and wood stove. 
Outside, under cover of the big roof is a half-wall enclosed braai area surrounded by benches on walls, and logs for sitting on.  Huge braai grid suspended from roof.   
Price includes firewood.  Single toilet.  No electricity. Water Brünner outside. 
Can easily cater for 50 people.  Lots of space outdoors for kids to run around and play in forest.   
Its up in the forest, narrow tar road runs by,(so easy to find!) parking for lots of cars.

post:
Great offers for Hotel accom,, many with children free or very cheap- 2 nights for 249CHF per person, with breakfast, some meals and spas, etc, included. But they seem to all be the other side of Switzerland (apart from Charmey, Villars and Les Diablerets). I suspect that perhaps the Swiss German Coop magazine may have similar offers but for Romandie- to encourage people to visit areas further away. I would be interesting to swap info. perhaps.   
Included in the Romandie mag:   
Gstaad, Saanen, Zermatt, Saas Fee, Loèche (leukerbad) Wengen, Meirigen, Grindelwald, Engelberg, Birgeis, Stoss, Flims, Bad Ragaz, Davos, Scuol, Silvapoana, Lenzerheide. Ask if you want to know the detail for either of above. Some are for all dates, some exlude some dates.
Check out the Untererstrasse as well. It is parallell to the Hauptstrasse, lots of bars there. My favourite bar in this street is the Sonderbar.

It does add up though - close to a hundred bucks just for public transport (2 gemeinde tickets) if you don't return home on the same day plus accommodation and that doesn't even include lunch yet  . On the other hand, several hours train ride in one day depending on where one comes from are quite tiring. If your event could be done from e.g. 10 to 5 with a lunch break, that might be something though  .

Never been to Ischl, but have done most of my ski holidays in Austria, places like Soelden, St. Anton, Lech etc.   
In general I prefer skiing in Austria over Switzerland or anywhere else for that matter.  Reasons (general): 
- Better lifts / infrastructure. In my view the Austrian resorts have made much more investments into this in the last ten years than the Swiss.  You rarely see t-bars etc anymore. 
- Great snowmaking capabilities 
- Much better food / drink options, both on the slopes and in the resorts.  The Austrian know how to make a cosy mountain hut. 
- Cheaper

post: For those newbies scarred off by high CH hotel prices, always make sure to check out the vacation rentals or "ferienwohnungs" in CH. The main swiss tourism website lists them all, and they are typically 120 CHF for a house/chalet.  We loved the Ferienwohnung Pensa in Silva Plana, Engadin.  Beautiful views of the lake.

It is a CON - do not buy tickets for SWISS AIR.   
They went bust 2002

Heard about the Atzmännig twice. First in 1969 or 70 from a colleague who praised it for skiing. Second in the early 80ies when my parents were hiking there in summer and praised the views and the landscape

My favourite destination in the mountains is Mürren.   
I worked there one Winter season many years ago, have been back a couple of times over the past years in the Winter and also with the whole family for a few days in the Summer.    
Quiet and relaxing, cosy and small, beautiful views across the valley towards to the Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau. For an adult with a young child, you will find the Eiger Guest House, just opposite the station very good and friendly.

Check covoiturage.fr. It's cheaper and faster than public transport. If you are lucky you will find someone who does the journey every day, perhaps from Annemasse or Saint Julien en Genevois.   
My son uses this to fill his car up on Lyon-Annecy trips. It is very professional. No money changes hands and the online posting of opinions means that you can trust the people you travel with.

Just to complete the thread....   
Just been to Bern and picked up two tourist visas. All I needed to get the tourist visas was cash and the passports of everyone travelling (no photos, filled out forms or swiss visa required). We have UK passports - process may be different for others.   
Cost was 42chf per tourist visa and a 53chf charge because my wife wasn't there in person. A total of 137chf.   
I got there when it opened at 09:00 and was out just after 10:00. You hand in your passports, they get taken away and then returned a bit later along with the Visas and the bill (which has to be paid in cash I believe - didn't see a card machine). I had 3 people in front of me one of whom had something complex to do so your wait time may vary. The embassy is very close to Bern station, about a 5 minute walk.   
Guy behind the desk spoke Spanish, German & English whilst I was there.

post:
It's Sennenchilbi in Arth, SZ, on November 9 & 10.   
It's a two-day event celebrating the farming traditions of the area.     
The big day is on Sunday, Nov 10.     
At 9.00, there will be a traditional yodel mass at the Catholic church in Arth.   
At 10.30, there will be a concert from the local music club with a free apero.   
At 14.00, there will be a   featuring sheep herds, ringing of the cow bells, lots of folklore costumes, yodelling, goats, cracking the whip and many more highlights.  Right after the parade, at the Zwygarten, free coffee, Lebkuchen und Nidla (whipped cream) will be handed out.   
Following the parade, there will be folklore dancing and many other activities.   
So if you don't have any plans for next Sunday and live in the area, come on over to Arth to get a taste of Switzerland's proud farming traditions and culture.

I attached a pop-up from the most famous website where to buy/sell second hand SNCF train tickets. This popup comes up when you try to submit a ticket where there is your name on it.   
Long story short, it says: 
1. this ticket has a name on it, hence we don't let you sell it coz the person using it may get a fine of 200 euros (but again, this never happened to me, & I did this at least 10 times) 
2. next time, we advise you to get the ticket sent by post, in a sncf office, in a travel agency, or in a sncf ticket machine. (these are probably created without a specific name) 
3. next time, if you buy a "imprimé" sncf ticket, we advise you to wait for the last minute to add the name of the passengers & to not be logged in when buying the tickets (it prob inserts your name automatically on the ticket if you're logged in)

post:
We just had a lovely short getaway in Munster Valley. We've done the Alsace wine route many times & attended concerts in Freibourg, but it was our first time to Munster Valley.   
Munster town is small enough so that traffic is light, parking is (mostly) free and you can actually get lots in the centre...yet an important enough town that the Tourist Info office is well-stocked with maps, offering good advice on accomodation etc.   
We timed it so we caught the weekly Saturday market. It cannot compare with Muhlouse but is worth shopping at. During this time there's also new wine (Sauser) lots of mushrooms, great selection of potatoes etc.    
Also pop across the road (other side from the carpark) to the Union of Textile Workers building. Great bargains in linens, bedspreads, towels, really cute tablecloths and gifts for Christmas.   
Best of all, right near the market is l'Agneau d'Or. A little gem of a restaurant we would go to Munster just for Martin Fache's cooking, and to be pampered by his wife who runs Front of House. His creative touches delight & surprise, but the ingredients take centrestage. Even a starter with traditional Choucroute (Alsacien sauerkraut) is wrapped in crispy bacon, and Munster cheese melts over it as its brought to you. Please order the duck confit nestled under potato mash, with braised porcini mushroom bathing everything. The menu prices are already good but his lunch specials are amazing value. Perhaps because the crowd is light during the day, specially in this low season? Then he slips in Amuse Bouche like seafood soup....extra granitas.... lunch has not been such a pleasure in a long time.   
We decided on a B&B in the mountains, Ferme Grand Hetre. Since we wished to do some walking it was perfect. 15-20 mins drive up from town, its very quiet except for the soft cowbells in the barn nearby. Massive rooms with comfy beds, super clean, and only 65 EUR for the 2 of us (90 for 3 people) That includes a hearty breakfast of juice, coffee/tea, bread, home made cheese. Unlike some other B&B's in the area, they accept bookings for a night.   
Farmer Jean Mathieu and wife Natalie are warm + welcoming. Do take up their offer of Table d'Hote i.e. to eat dinner with their family, whatever they themselves are having. 22 EUR got us aperitifs, more wine to go with smoked pork, mashed potato, salad... coffee and liquer made by Jean M's dad... dessert. The company of other guests + chatting with the family made it a very enjoyable evening.   
Tip: besides Munster cheese, JM makes bergkase (mountain cheese) Mild yet flavourful, it will appeal to those who like Cheddar or Sprintz. At 15EUR for a whole kilo, its also a good buy!   
Tip: shopping in the many LIDL in the area is fantastic value. We thought fresh foie gras was already cheap in the Carrefour at Muhlouse but it was only 10 EUR here! Huge cans of duck confit for Christmas dinner too :-)   
Tip: in Munster, get some takeaway Choucroute. Available in bottles with meats already included.... or pick up smoked meats to heat up for a super dinner back home.   
After all, its only 2+ hours drive from where we live in Lachen (near Pfaffikon) For people living near Basel it's really a nice day trip.
A lesson I learned today, the hard way.

post: Thank you so much! That's exactly what I needed. Even in English.

We highly recommend the Interlaken area, though not the town so much. And if you have the choice of going at a time when the weather is clear, the views will be much more beautiful.    
Continue on to the Lauterbrunnen Valley, as far as Stechelberg. From there you can take the gondola all the way to the Schilthorn revolving restaurant, which is hokey but has the most gorgeous views on a clear day.    
Or, get off in Murren, then walk through the town, have lunch with a great view. Then walk to Grutschalp along the top of the cliffs and take the other gondola down to Lauterbrunnen, postbus back to Stechelberg if you parked there. The walk to Grutschalp is mostly flat, and there are other walks/hikes of varying degrees of difficulty from Murren.    
Go soon before the snow, though I am sure it is beautiful then, too.

Been there Sunday, i would say the exhibition is a bit overrated, because 
most items of the 220 pieces are "small " and behind windows. 
There are only 4 Warriors and 1 horse, to get there you have to queue up 
for about 30-40 mins, to pass the warriors and the horse will take another 30 mins, because people take all the time in the world to have a decent look( because they paid for it).The Museum was really crowded last sunday afternoon, therefor you can't enjoy the movies and the explanations. 
The guide to the exhibition will cost 58 sfr (available in French, English and German), most of the stuff sold at the museum shop is really crap (like chinese souvenirs)  and overpriced (for example cookies in a qin printed tin for 20 sfr/170 gramms).If you want a reproduction of a terracotta warrior back at home , no problem, 750 sfr plus shipment. 
The most expensive item is an exclusive evening at the museum for about 8000 sfr (don't know how many companions are allowed). 
No photos are allowed(even mobiles) !

Just popped out to check out the Benichon events in Fribourg and thought it is worth a mention here....   
If you are interested in fresh local produce, artisan producers, and a bit of good country Swiss traditional fun, Fribourg is the place to be this weekend!!   
There are food and traditional craft stalls all along Rue de Romont and Rue de Lausanne, with a huge tent set up in Place Python to eat and drink.... plus for the little ones there is a "petting zoo" setup in Grand Place where you can look at some cows, goats, pigs etc.   
There are demos of meringue and biscuit making, ham smoking, cheese making, traditional needlepoint and woodwork etc etc    
Plus the local restaurants are all having special benichon menus (for a variety of prices).   
Also all open tomorrow....Well worth checking out    
More info (french and german) here:

I did the Vendage in France for 9.5 days in the Beaujolaise. I wanted to do it for the experience, but the experience is also getting paid for what you will find one of the hardest picker jobs out there. If you want an experience working the land you can be an agro tourist in Switzerland. If it's just grapes, well do it for a morning or an afternoon for free food and wine. Because otherwise I don't see the point in breaking your back for the love of the vine.

post:
Hello music friends in Basel!    
The Münsterkantorei Basel is a concert choir affiliated to the beautiful Basel Minster and conducted by Annedore Neufeld, a very virtuous, enthusiastic and highly professional lady. About 50 singers work on high level sacred music from all epochs, a capella and with an orchestra.  
Rehearsals are usually on Wednesday night at the Bischofshof, right next to the Basel Minster.      . Some german knowledge is required for understandig the conductor    
On Wednesday, 4th of September, we will start rehearsing Bach's famous Christmas Oratorio (all six parts):    
Concerts will be on Dec 21 and 22 at the Basel Minster.   
If you are interested in joining this once in a lifetime experience don't hesitate to contact me or just come to the Bischofshof (address: Rittergasse 1, Basel) at 7:30 pm on Wed 4th of September (or any other Wednesday).       
Come and join! Don't be shy, give it a try!
thread: Sing with us the Christmas-Oratorio from J.S. Bach! (Basel)

We loved Davos this summer (although we have been quite a few times).  There are some gorgeous hikes which are easily accessible for a young one (and end at mountain cafés with great play parks .. Eg Rinerhorn).   
We stayed at the Sheraton and can not recommend it highly enough - both our kids had great fun.  The eldest quickly had a possee of friends and the youngest made lots of use of the playpark and the lovely pool.  What is more, they were incredibly helpful with my list of special requests for our youngest son who has various disabiilities, including borrowing a bed from another hotel to meet our requirements.  Plus kids go free ..can't get much better than that!     
Enjoy.

We rented an apartment in Annecy and had a great weekend! We were told when the market was.... so buying fresh food and then a trip to Monoprix (the one inside the shopping centre is the biggest) to get the missing bits, bringing it back and cooking some lovely food and we had a great weekend. We stayed at   Les Z'hirondelles and the lady who welcomed us just needs a phone call before you arrive and was very friendly.   
In Yvoire I stayed in Hotel Vieux Logis. They were a bit run down and I didn't try the breakfast there so I can't comment. We got a room on the top floor which had a FANTASTIC view over the old roofs of the village and lake Geneva and the lights on the other side of it (Switzerland). It is one of the cheaper hotels there though and desparately needs refreshing, but we were happy   Yvoire is kinda cool to walk through at night when the tourists have gone. We drank Champagne at 3am by the port ... watching the twinkling lights and watching the boats bob up and down a little.   
Annecy and Yvoire are both fantastic places I'd recommend too. Two of my favourites.

Generally I would set focus in front of infinity. Bear in mind that the sharpest point of any lens is likely to be from 5.6 to 8 stop down to 16 & you will loose definition due to defraction.   
The Nikon 20mm f 3.5 is OK, nothing special, a very old design. The 24 f 2.8 is way better. It's very difficult to build a fast wide full frame lens, which is why some wide angles are breath takingly expensive.

post:
Airbnb take only 3% commission so are preferred by some owners. Most increase their normal price to compensate for the commission. The main disadvantage is that there is no contact with the owner until after the booking has been made.    
The locations of properties is not determined the airbnb. It depends which owners decide to advertise with them.    
Renting a privately owned apartment or house is always much more reasonable than a hotel. It's just a shame that these big websites are springing up to try and sell them to customers in the same way as hotels without having to worry about quality, maintenance, cleaning or anything else other than advertising and taking the money.    
Even the normal advertisers are pushing owners into more and more expensive advertising packages and heading towards commission based models.

Branch out.  Take the S3 to St Ursanne and wander down to the "beach" on a lazy meander of the River Doubs. Stunning scenery and a beautiful minature medieval town to wander through in search of drinks and picnic tea supplies.  My son's psychomotorik therapist took him there for weeks to help him desensitise his feet.  First they paddled with wellies, then with shoes, then just in socks and now he wades in with the best of them, bare feet, to plop pebbles in buckets and generally contemplate the wonders of building a miniature damn.   
You'll love it but it's more of a half day trip from Basel.   
PS. Be sure to take little one sliding down the thick stone banister outside the medieval church .. Well known for its portico frescoes but better known as having one of the oldest slides built into its stone steps.  All those kids bottoms over the centuries have made it super smooth!
an interesting interactive map.

haha.   
OK - to give a bit more background.. what I am interested in observing is the timing at which the "false" dawn and the "true" dawn occur.    
Take a look at this video which shows the phenomenon occurring twice:       
(Keep an eye on the counter/marker in the bottom right hand of the screen)   
The false dawn occurs towards the end of night and is marked by a vertical-ish column of light appearing from the horizon in the direction of the rising sun. That then disappears and is replaced by the "true" dawn which is the horizontal spreading of light across the horizon prior to sunrise.
