post:
Now that summer has started it is time to do some weekend trips around switzerland. We usually go by car or public transport, take or tent, and do some walks, not too difficult or long ones, we like to keep it relaxed. I thought it might be nice to share our experiences, and figured here would be the right place.    
We didn't feel like getting up early or packing our stuff on friday so we left quite late in the morning by car to arrive at the camping site in Flühli just before midday. It is a typical swiss camping, by which I mean it has mainly season places. the 'real' camping site is a small grass field at the side of the main building/entrance. It has a kids playground (with swing, slide etc) on one side and according to the website there are 10 places, although there is no separation or anything. In our case there were just two other families with mobilhomes, so we had all the place we wanted. Not much shadow unfortunately but I am not going to complain about that when we are only staying one night.    
We set up our tent and searched for a spot along the river to have our lunch. Although we are usually well prepared for our trips and hikes this time we weren't, so after lunch we drove to sörenberg to the tourist info, which wasn't located there where the gps sent us, neither at the bus station where the blue "i" was, but somewhere in between the Volg and that busstation on the main road, on the left side when coming from Flühli. We found some maps, and asked for a hike to see the typical chalk formations that are on any Entlebuch photo:  
As we all know summer came late this year and there was still to much snow to go there. So we decided to do another tour. The lady advised us to take the cable car to rossweid and walk around there. We usually prefer to walk uphill and take the cable car down, so we decided to do that. We followed the wanderweg up direction rossweid until the first crossing where we choose to go direction Salwide. there we choose direction Blatte, then Blattenegg, and so to Rossweid via schwarzenegg. There was still some snow at this height and the wanderweg from blattenegg to hindere Steinetli was out of use due to possible falling rocks, but everything was clearly indicated as we are used to here in switzerland. close to Rossweid it was kind of a building pit becaus they are building a water playground there that will be opened end of july, we saw a lot of the wooden equipment which looked really nice but it didn't look like a water playground at all yet. Too bad we had not asked the tourist info lady when the last cable car was. We arrived at 17.20 (had started our small tour at about 15.00 to give you an idea about the length)whereas the last one went at 17.15 (I actually saw it going and thought well we are in time there are still cablecars moving) So we had to go back on foot, bad for the knees and we don't like going down at all, but it was fairly quick.    
A disadvantage of the camping is that there is no person of the camping permanently there, they come by between 6 and 8 pm and than you get te key to the lavatories etc. then they pick it up again in the morning before you leave. So before the lady of the camping came we didn't have acces to the toilets etc. Everything was nice and clean though, and they are even rebuilding and modernizing it after the summer hollidays so no complaints about that. After we had enjoyed some belgian beers and cooked dinner we went to the village to see if anything was going on there. We had another beer in the only pub and did some 'observe the locals' for entertainment.    
next day the lady who would come pick up the keys at around 10 in the morning didn't turn up until 10.40. So i would definitely ask whether there is a letter box where you can drop the keys off rather than waiting for her next time. Then we went on to Flühli's main attraction:  
It was nice but the water really cold (I know it is meant to be cold but for me it was so cold that it hurts, but for my husband this wasn't a problem so maybe its just me) 
We meant to grill at a grillstelle near the river (Waldemme) which we passed by on our way to the kneippanlage (indicated on the map 'anreise' in the previous link) but there was a party in the village and laziness made us decide to grab something to eat there.    
In the afternoon we drove to Entlebuch itself and walked the following route: from Entlebuch to Finsterwald via veebode and Schluechtberg. and than back down to Entlebuch via Chilewald and along the grosse entle in the end. it is 3 hours walking time according to the yellow arrows. And along the way we discovered it was mostly the same as this path  
At mettilimoos there was this place where they made a 'moorbad' to walk in with your feet (and also possibility to wash them off) which was kinda cool.  
Near Entlebuch station we ate a good ice-cream before driving back home.   
In general it is a very beautiful region with lots of walking possibilities that are all quite easy. We had expected it to be more special (as in different from just beautiful swiss nature), but yeah it was just beautiful swiss nature, which is not bad at all. We really enjoyed our trip, although we want to go back later in summer to hike to Hengst (where the picture of my first link was taken). wie also want to do the Brienzer rothorn but we will probably do that from Brienz.

Well it was lovely, and yes a bit further than expected. We actually went via Frasne-Poligny and nowhere near Geneva! Kids loved it - and I was so impressed with our primary school taking all their Year 1 pupils, some only barely 4 years old. And none of them cried about being home sick- even at bed time when we all went to our tents, 8 kids + 1 teacher/assistant per tent.    
And it really reminded me just how different Swiss schooling is, compared to UK at present. A kid had a nose bleed on the bus, and the teachers help without putting gloves on (yes, what happens in UK!), a kid falls over and a teacher gives said kid a huge hug and a kiss. A child feels a bit sad, and again gets a big hug and kiss and sits on the teacher's knee for a while. In the evening we all sit on the grass in the campsite and sing songs, with a couple of teachers playing guitar. Other campsite users come along, take photos, encourage and clap - and nobody even thinks there could be anything wrong with this. Wonderful - so much trust and old-fashioned and healthy innocence. Lovely.

i found milos too touristic for my taste (but i went in mid july)   
karpathos is a paradise for me. great, empty beaches in the end of july last year and some of the friendliest people i have ever met. i don't know, there was something there that made me love it. there are some direct flights from germany and austria. otherwise there are flights from athens and from rhodes. i was informed that there will be one from thessaloniki too soon. we will most probably go again this year.      
kythira is also a beautiful island. there is an airport with flights at least from athens. nice beaches, nice people and some nice green and waterfalls and places for hiking

for the historical sights, take two days in athens, as others have suggested  and go to the acropolis museum and perhaps also sounio

Last year a mate of mine complained that my shoot Italian was to blame that I had fallen over the Majola pass instead of the Stelvio as I had originally promised and it seems that I owe another one of my dwindling stock of friends a lunch after the poor man was forced to look at a picture of a serpentine road with a vanishing point, think Wiley E. Coyote free-falling in a road-runner cartoon, this time around it Isn't not ain't going to happen. 
There you go a treble negative in a working sentence. Suck it Shakespeare.   
Slammer gingerly mounted the Iron pig and headed to St. Moritz. 
Very gingerly. 
The day before I had been in the middle of what would have been called a casualty, mummy had shot out of the drive backward without looking, thank the Flying Spaghetti Monster for the bikes ABS and new brakes. The bike stopped, slammer didn't, let me tell you inertia is a real bitch, ergo the two little personal airbags between Slammer and the bikes tank took the strain. My eyes popped their sockets and I swear, no shit, that I burped two squishy lumps into my cheeks. 
Turned out mummy had quite a potty mouth and she went all Grrr woof woof on me, however I was a bit preoccupied by matters most, ahh, pressing to give her some well deserved stick so I was not spontaneous until much later when I was able to relax with a cold beer and a bag of ice. 
Biiiitch.   
Saturday morning waxed hot and humid, stewing in my biker rags riding through the valley of death aka. Rheintal I could see the heat flimmer on the motorway, I was overheating and looking forward to going up into the refreshing coolness of altitudes of over a thousand meters. I passed Buchs and chugged through Liechtenstein, a whole country that fits in the viewfinder of a cheap digital camera, just take a step back. Passed Chur and turned of the main road at Thusis    
first stop at Lac Mamorea.   
Not a natural lake but a dam and underneath the 10 degree cold water a drowned village.   
I had a coffee in St Moritz and spent a half hour amusing myself watching the expensive cars crash into each other, a black Ferarri had taken on a VW and lost, I think Mr. Rolex was more pissed that the crash had happened with a commoner's car than the actual damage. 
There was a sprinkling of Bikes but they ran into the Harley and Ducati type of ride, a mite out of my paycheck level. 
By now the Beemer with just over 200.000 Kilometers on the Tacho   
toasted this event with a beer, hey it is a Bavarian bike you know.   
has had it's share of knocks and scratches and looks a bit ratty round the edges, patina is what you could call it but it's well earned and I do not care if the St. Moritzians hitch their cocaine filled noses over us I rode on and left them to their lifestyle of riches, shiny Porches, boob jobs and glitter. 
Slammer is not a St. Moritz person. 
Sod `em. 
I decided to take the Stelvio from the Italian side and took the tunnel down to Livinio 
I have said it once before and will say it again, the Italians should never have been acquainted with the internal combustion engine, some god must love Italians because it is certainly not superior driving skills that is keeping them alive. 
At the intersection of the approach to the pass I stopped and watched the cabaret, white lines on the road must be only for decoration nobody took a bit of notice, bikes and cars weaved in a dance of tin. 
One guy did the Knight bus magic stretching trick as he shot at warp between two cars. 
Amazing. 
I would not be soo pissed with the Italians if they were not always so well dressed.   
Riders on the storm. 
Dum de dum de dum..     
The further up that I rode the darker and closer the clouds got. The sky was  paynes grey, drooping and heavy with wet, not much longer now I could hear thunder and the snow capped mountain tops glowed with the flash of lightning over and over again. 
As I was going up and up a steady stream of italian regged bikes was heading down and  down, maybe they knew something that I didn´t. 
At the tri-starte border, Italy´, Austria and CH I stopped again and  looked down at the road I had just drove on. 
Lightning flashed, blinding me, followed  by a immediate explosion of thunder, that was  very, very close. 
Even before I had finished shouting FUgggggg! I realized that lightning zapping a lump of metal happy to conduct a mega-volt charge of electricity possibly igniting the tank full of flammable liquid just a millimeter in front of my sore genitals could ruin my whole day. 
Time to boogie. 
I decided to spend the night at the summit there are four or five hotels but as I drove through they all seemed to cater predominantly for the MTV generation. 
It's PAARDY time, paardy, paardy. paaaardy! 
Along with St. Morizians another thing that the Slammster just can not abide. 
I carried on and down the Austrian side, just over the summit the clouds cleared and the sky became a deep vivid blue the crystal air showing the mountains in a high contrast.     
 As you see some Italians where arseing around, ahh! for the wonders of the SlamKam. 
It was starting get a little late, my balls felt radio-active, I was getting saddle sore and it was way past beer O'clock.     
This whole area is a national park with Switzerland to the west and the South Tyrollean Dolomites to the east. It is also the site of one of the more brutal WW1 battlefields, Somme, Verdun, names that have burned themselves into the collective memories, however almost forgotten is the fierce alpine fighting, mountain for mountain, valley for valley, village for village, fighting in a hostile environment always in danger of dying either by man or nature. This part of the war took men and material to the absolute limit. 
And the soldiers died like flies.   
Spot the bunker? 
Today mountaineers climb the peaks with all the flashy gadgets and glittery gew gaw's known to man, and when they get to the top and look down at the world below they feel a sense of achievement. 
Pussies. 
In 1916 soldiers of the K&K Monarchy occupied the peaks and dug in, climbing the mountains taking heavy 1875-model 10.5 mountain cannon with them and building fortifications, in some cases actually tunneling in the glaciers, all done with mules and the technology of the 19 century. The logistic obstacles must have been staggering the soldiers superhuman. 
The alpine war was fought without mercy, only last year did the glacier release five of the fallen, they where identified as Italian soldiers and taken home where they were buried with full military honors. 
Almost a hundred years on I spent the night on the former Ortlerfront in the Franzenhöhe Hotel at an altitude of 2188 meters for 50 Euros incl. breakfast. 
Red wine and grappa extra.     
Vans and a few late cars struggling up the dangerous pass, not a place to be when the light is failing.   
Somewhere there must be a law against drinking grappa at high altitudes, now along with my other discomfort I had a thick head to take care of. 
I turned over and slept until almost noon. 
I had now to choose the way home, either back through Italy or carry on down and return by the way of Austria or over the Umbriel pass and the Often pass that would put me in the ballpark for home. 
I rode up the Stelvio again and through the hotel-complex eventually turning right at Umbriel, immediately the steady stream of Italian bikes dried up and apart from just the occasional bike or cycle the road was empty. 
In short absolute biking heaven, Slammer got into a dream state and the curves and hairpins and turns rolled easily under my wheels. 
Two hours later I was home.

post:
since no one has much prior knowledge about the island ,or maybe, no one is willing to take the time to explain it out,  I might as well give you my impressions of the island. 
I went there 2 weeks ago. 
Reached Locarno on tageskarte tickets 
Just 5 min walk and you reach the Dock 
One has to travel by ferry to reach the island 
Charges for round trip are : 
Without half tax card 33 franks per person ( the tageskarte is of no use here) 
With half tax card 29 franks 
Journey time 75- 90 mins 
Beautiful views 
Land on the island and pay 8 franks per person as entry fee 
Time taken for a moderate nature lover to see the place 60-90 min  
I did take some time to feed my baby  
Not a very stroller friendly place 
There is a restaurant on the island 
Toilets - free of charge 
Ferry in every 60-90 mins, so check for the return ferry timings as you start the tour. 
IF YOU ARE SOMEONE FROM THE TROPICS , THIS ISLAND WILL NOT " WOW" YOU. 
So I would end my description with the thought that great expectations lead to disappointments  
AND PLEASE DON'T FORGET TO GET DOWN IN ASCORNA TOWN ON THE WAY BACK, I found this place worth a day or two stay. 
As I left ASCORNA , felt good, that the money spent on the ferry tickets was worthwhile. 
So the whole  trip would take the whole day if you include ASCORNA too. 
Hope you have great time in brissago islands
Our gemeinde doesn't reimburse but that's not what I wanted. I just wanted to get another day if possible.

Snowboarding really doesn't much resemble surfing, and although many people feel they can 'just do it' the slopes (previously mentioned) in Engelberg soon teach most self-starters that they really should take some lessons to learn how to just do it  .   
The Cable car opens all year round, except for 12 days in November.   
Yes, there are shops open. For more specialised snowboard stuff I'd suggest   - just turn left at the front of the station and left again at the crossroads, then it's about 100m on your left. There's also a ski/bike shop Titlis Sport at the base station, but somewhat more limited, as their main shop is in the village.   
If you're coming by rail and have a halbtax card it may be cheaper to book in advance with  . Depends on your situation, of course.   
Hope you have fun and if you'd like to meet up for a chat or a beer send me a PM.

I recently went to Paris and had exactly the same issue as you do - not being able to get the online reservation. However, there is a decent solution - you can climb the tower by foot - it is not as hard as you would imagine. It took us about 15-20 min to get to the 2nd floor. There are 700 steps to do that and you do a difference of about 170m altitude. I think for a guy enjoying the Switzerland this effort should not be a problem. The big advantage is that there is practically no queue to make it by foot. Also, you do not need to go on the top (summit) - the views you will get on the 2nd floor is more then enough. 
P.S. - the views from Eiffel tower compare to nothing else (Arc, Sacre Cueur) simply because from Eiffel is surrounded by all the famous buildings. So, just do it. Do not waste your time in the line and make a short workout to the 2nd floor. It totally worth it.

We stayed   last year over Epiphany weekend (Jan 5-6) - not rock-bottom prices but reasonable for Zermatt. It's a lovely family-run place and they were happy to let us book one night rather than a whole week.    
They may already be booked for Christmas but I reckon it's worth giving them a call/email to find out.

post: Just read   in the NY Times, walk 8 is a seven-mile walk from Avenches to Murten.

Somewhere like Rigi (a popular day trip destination from Zurich) won't have snow on top - not in July. So normal walking shoes will be fine. Of course if you plan to climb the Matterhorn etc. that's a different story.   
An umbrella might come in handy, weather is pretty changeable in the summer. I wouldn't bother with a rain coat though.   
Zurich is full of tourists in the summer, so don't worry about blending in.   Enjoy yourself, take in all the scenery and old buildings etc. and don't be afraid to be seen looking at stuff. Keep an eye on your wallet as you would in any city, but that's it.  The Old Town is quite walkable so there's no need to bother with trams unless you actually want to ride one.

post:
Kudos to you for putting a significant amount of effort into planning your trip and then coming onto EF as an afterthought. Makes it much more enjoyable to help people who have first tried to help themselves. That being said, a bit more info on your interests would help us narrow the search - otherwise I'll assume you're looking for a little taste of everything.   
Anyways, I can't help much for the first leg of your journey as it's a bit outside my stomping grounds. Although, while near Davos, I might recommend: Scuol for an amazing  ; the Swiss National Park if you enjoy hiking (stay overnight at  ); a cable car up to 3000m Diavolezza to see the glacier; or a taste of Romansch culture in  .    
For the second leg of your journey, I can also only really comment on Vaud/Geneva region. I personally would spend less time in Lausanne and Geneve as I don't think they have much to offer relative to surrounding areas/villages. Nonetheless, you'll find plenty on what to do by perusing EF. Off the top of my head: the walled town of  can be combined with the amphitheatre in   (aka Aventicum) to visit one of the largest Roman settlements;   are a MUST in September and can be combined with   on the lake (not to mention stunning views); try to get to the top of Dent de Vaulion or Rochers de Naye for some seriously gorgeous panoramas.   
Lastly, spend some time looking into any festivals and events taking place around that time. There's sure to be something.

In most forum areas, where you click on "New Thread" button to open this and other threads, there are threads at the top of the list that are "sticky".  These are always stuck at the top for people to read, learn and follow.   
You may have posted in the right area, but think about it... Using a one-word title like "Searching" is not very descriptive.  Thus, you are catching a hard time for not reading the sticky threads and following the guidelines that help keep this forum somewhat organized.   
You DID agree to follow the forum guidelines when you signed up    
So, if I were you, I would ask the moderators (kindly) to change the title to something more appropriate and better descriptive of the theme here.  Got it?

post: is another place that would be suitable.

Last Saturday my wife and I went on a day trip to Gruyeres Village. We had been to that beautiful place a couple of times before and we thoroughly enjoyed visiting it every time.   
We also discovered that there was a temporary exhibition of works of the Polish surrealist artist Franciszek Starowieyski at Gallery of the H R Giger Museum, which is located in the village on the approach to the Gruyere Castle.   
Those of you who like the style of works of H R Giger (the prominent Swiss surrealist artist, who produced the artworks for such films as Alien, Species, Dune, Batman Forever, etc.) might enjoy visiting the exhibition of Franciszek Starowieyski too.       
The exibition has been open since June 2012 but it is due to finish this spring (the exact date is not known).

Aah, yes, sorry it was.

post:
Like the previous post mentioned, Malbun/Liechtenstein is nice.   
For a quick activity, and a bit of exercise and fun, head to Steg (I believe its called). On the way up to Malbun, after you drive through the tunnel, on the right hand side of the road is a restaurant parking lot.    
Here you can park, and walk up the mountain to a nice restaurant. Enjoy the pictures of the building's/area's history. Enjoy a warm drink, a beer, some fondue, or other food on the menu. Then request a sled for you/your group members, and head back down to the parking lot on your snow sled. It is a good route, with fun turns and a nice long straight away towards the end that you can really get moving on.        
Werdenberg, in Buchs, is a nice, old village, with a castle you can walk up to, to enjoy a nice panoramic view of the Rheintal. If you do not want to walk up to the castle, enjoy a walk through Werdenberg, the old buildings, and take a stroll around the pond. On the eastern side of the pond is a nice cafe you can enjoy a Latte, or drink/nibble of your choice.    
Sargans also has a cool mine you can visit. It is called Bergwerk. A good friend took his son, and he was quite impressed. Interesting to go inside. Good food and drink and experience! Take a tour, or just enjoy a beverage or food in the mine.

Just a small headsup for those in the centre of Basel this Wednesday and fancy a long lunch.  The 27th is Vogel Gryff, a traditional festival organised by the three honourable Societies (Ehrengesellschaften) of Kleinbasel, which are called "zum Rebhaus", "zur Hären" and "zum Greifen". On this day the three heraldic figures "Vogel Gryff" (Griffin), "Wild Maa" (Wild Man) and "Leu" (Lion), accompanied by three drummers, three standard-bearers and four jesters, who collect money for the needy, parade through Kleinbasel, the part of the city that lies on the right-hand bank of the Rhine, performing their traditional dances along the way.   
The day starts just before 11 when a boat carrying the ensemble above fires cannons as it passes middle bridge and then lands at Klingental to start the day.       
The "parade" then makes its way onto middle bridge for its yearly "2 fingers up" to Grossbasel before it continues though Kleinbasel performing at various locations (mostly outside bars - see note below for times).   
The traditional dance performed can be seen here as I filmed it a year or so back:     
Other notes: 
The police put on for one-day only the old traditional style English bobby hats.  The Fisherstube Brewery brews for one day only a very nice bock beer.   
More info  (in english):         .   
If you want to see the "dance" at another time of the day this   has the locations and times on it.   
It may not have the "big bang" of Fasnacht etc, but I like it and thought I would share some information about it  .   
Pat

post: Santispark is a good place to stay.

Montreux Christmas market is one of the largest and a little different to most of the others around Switzerland.  This is mainly the French influence, rather than German.   
There is not a great deal of difference between the other markets in the German speaking areas.  Zurich is one of the larger ones and is undercover within the Bahnhof.  There are also smaller markets elsewhere around, particularly in the Old Town.   
In some towns, they are spread over several areas.  Basel and Lucerne are examples of these.     
Hope this helps in planning your Christmas market visits.

post:
Yes Le Chable is great access by train, change at Martigny. Also great to avoid queues in Verbier, as the bubble from Le Chable does straight through. Our girls when little loved doing the Royal Wave as we went pass the queuers  We used to rent a flat in Le Chable, but there are quite a few simple hotels at very good rates- but can't recommend any as such. All close to the bubble.   
If you are a beginner it is a long long trek all the way down to the Verbier (can't go down on skis/board to le Chable), with some more difficult passages. Not recommended until you are better and stronger on your board. And whatever you do - DO NOT BE STUPIDLY tempted to do the Tortin Wall run from Lac des VAux down to Siviez until you really know what you are doing. (one of our good friends has been paraplegic for a very long time as he tried when he was not ready ( .

Hey ya'll   
Was planning to get the first ski trip out the way this weekend. The itch has got too much    
Was going to hit up Engelberg, but after weighing up the options have deemed Saas Fee to be of preference due to number of runs open and overal snow cover.   
I have never been before so thats another plus that it is a new resort to venture.   
Just one friend and myself, both skiers, are making the trip from Zurich HB. Looking to get the 6:02am train.   
If anyone has been itching to get up there but hasnt had anyone to go with or simply just wants to come then by all means, join us.   
If it is of any relevance we are both intermediate/advanced type skiers, i.e. we'll pretty much ski anything.   
Here is an interactive map of the area:       
The following runs are open as well as the freestyle park/half pipe etc:     5a   10   10b   18   18a   19   19a   19b

Having skied in several resorts I'd recommend checking out the latest edition of the 'Where to Ski & SnowBoard Guide .(it comes out each year and is unbiased) Not only does it give good objective info on the resorts but you can get a clearer idea of costs and of specific facilities -ie lively nightlife or quiet and picturesque.It also gives details and ratings of the Ski schools and the relative costs of ski passes .For example while Zermatt is a brilliant resort -I would suggest for those who can at least ski red runs -its not cheap and has the most expensive ski pass in Europe I'm told!  
The Guide has a web site and last year's copy -which should be dead cheap  to pick up on Amazon-will give you a good idea.  
Have a great trip .

The first resort on the Swiss side is Torgon - and very close to you. The bottom part of the beginners' slope is very easy and wide (you can exit the poma lift at several spots before it gets steeper at the top) - with a pizzeria/café at the side, and the ski school, with the majority of instructors who speak English, right there. The great majority of skiers there British, as the Greenwich based Ski Company has it's base just below (seen in the middle at the far end of Sbrinz's link) Or you can park at Plan de Croix (by another Café/restaurant) and take the T-bar (not everybody's favourite lol) on the right- again the top is steep but you can exit before)  or take the very modern 4 (or 5?) chair-lift up to Tour de Don, and the lovely 2 slopes with Poma (button) lifts there. The return to Plan de Croix is via a Black slope - but you can return by chairlift. Fabulous views of Vevey/Montreux and the lake from the top.   
The Glacier at les Diablerets is very gentle too.   
For beginners with a low budget, Les Fourgs near Metabief/Jougne, between Vallorbe and Pontarlier is the best value. Wide, shallow slopes, with the ski hire/ski school at the bottom, with a café/restaurant above (Le Snabeuzi). Very cheap and easy peasy.

I think the descents are over, but maybe someone knows better.  (I think the beginning/mid-October is the end of the season).   
There is an Alpine Cheese Festival - where there is cheese, there are cows?
Thanks to all for your help.  Yes, it's expensive, but it never hurts to look, just in case a deal comes along.  Do folks recommend booking early or waiting a bit?  Thanks again...

I copy/past...       
The exhibition celebrates the friendship between Pablo Picasso and the American photographer David Douglas Duncan. In 1956, Duncan was a war photographer for Life magazine when he met Picasso in his villa La Californie in Cannes.    
This exceptional exhibition creates a dialogue between some 150 photographs taken from 1956 to 1973 and as many works by Picasso, thus enabling the visitor to dive into the intimacy of Picassos work and research, through a variety of media, such as painting, sculpture, ceramics, drawing and engraving.

Alternative is to take the train to Bellinzona, TiLo to Luino, bus to Varese.

A good place for photographers ( Top of Lugano ):       
Once reaching the top ( Kulm / Vettas ), walk downstairs towards the WC for a great lookout, and then walk upwards towards the Church / Museum for another great lookout, and further on for 4-10min uphill for the best the place has to offer.   
Funicular ticket includes entrance to the Museum ( operates at certain days and hours ).   
To do both cheaply, get the Ticino Discovery Card.

I agree with Swisspea and would also like to add that Eurail passes are not really a "saver" although Eurail does promote them like that. They are moreso a convenience ticket, often referred to as the "golden ticket" in blogs since you can jump-off whenever you like without queuing for tickets. A major deal-breaker is that you still have to pay a supplement if you want to travel on fast trains exiting switzerland. Lausanne-Paris TGV for example.    
For Switzerland, get your hands on a "Half Tax 1 year" as Swisspea mentioned and when planning travel, check out "super-saver tickets" and monthly specials on sbb.com. They have some great offers that will far outweigh the Eurail pass option.

I have just spent an hour in the amazing Basel shipping museum down the harbor. 
Always wanted to give it a visit but as they close at five not had a chance until now. 
Inside, the usual guff about delivered tonnage and coal imports etc. 
But! There are also little tit-bits of information that I found fascinating. For instance, the Strassbourg to London shipping line, started in 1850, Basel to London, change in Strassbourg until 1936 when the first ships sailing direct London to Basel docked in Kleinhüningen. 
Little land-locked Switzerland has in fact a sea-harbor. 
Imagine, if Big bang II had not happened British EF'ers could be taking the slow boat to Basel right now. 
They have lots of intricate and detailed shipwrights models of Swiss ships, both inland and ocean going. 
There is also a lot on the history of the Rhein and maps and Litho's of the Rhein before it was channeled and tamed. 
A large scale model of the harbor as it was in 1936, one of these things that you can gape over for ages. 
However the Pièce de résistance and well worth the visit alone is a beautiful and ethereal bone ship. 
French sailors made them from bone and wood, both animal and human bone. 
Made by Prisoners of the Napoleonic wars who whiled away the boredom, these bone ships are extremely rare and to fine one in Basel blew me away.

We once spent the evening/night in a chalet above the vallée du rhône. We picked up the key from the tourism office in a village (can't remember the name now) then drove 30min, hiked 1h-1h30 and took "residence" in this little rustic chalet in a clearing. It was a snowshoe hike, so pretty cold, and it took a long time to heat up the living/dining room. Toilets were in a hut 50m away. There was electricity and cold runnign water and lots of cookery (plates etc, and what you need to make a fondue). It was 10chf/night/person.

post:
As a bit of a fan of railways and railway travel, I have travelled over each of these routes.  If you really enjoy railway travel and are happy with seriously long days, you can probably work out your own itineraries with the SBB online timetable.  What I recommend (starting from the Zürich area), is the following "bite sized" chunks.   
Golden Pass (part 1). 
Zürich - Luzern - Interlaken - Bern - Zürich. 
This is a comfortable day trip not requiring too early a start or late a finish, and covers the Luzern - Spiez part of the Golden Pass route.  The Zentralbahn part of the route is scenic part, particularly over the Brünig pass itself.  You can do this on a regular Halbtax day-pass (or a Gemeinde day pass).  If you splash out on 1st class, check the timetable for the Luzern-Interlaken trains with a panoramawagen (indicated by a triangle symbol on the timetable).  There is no special booking required.   
Golden Pass (part 2).  Zürich - Bern - Zweisimmen - Montreaux - Lausanne - Zürich.  This picks up the Golden pass where part 1 left off at Speiz.  The most impressive part of the route is the descent down to Montreaux, with an excellent view over lake Geneva.  Again, this can be done on a regular day-pass ticket.  If you want a seat in the panoramawagen, you need to book this especially, though I've not done this myself, so I can't comment on how easy it is to get.  The regular 2nd class carriages have big windows and a good view anyway.   
Glacier Express. 
You can't really do this comfortably in a day.  If you want to do the full route (Zermatt - St Moritz) on the special panoramic train, I suggest you spend one night in Wallais, perhaps in Brig, and head up to Zermatt in the morning to catch the train, then ride to St Moritz, and stay there (or elsewhere in the Engadinn to keep the price down a bit).  You could then do the Bernina the next day, or just head home.  To ride the special train, you need a regular ticket (which could be a day-pass or a Gemeinde pass), and also a special reservation, which costs something like CHF20.  If you are feeling pro-rail, you can get back to Zürich in the evening from St Moritz (which will also be covered by the day-pass if you use this for the ticket).  I believe it is not possible to get back to Zürich from Zermatt the same day, if you do it that way.   
If you just want to see the view, though, you can do the trip in bite-sized portions that are each possible on regular trains (no supplement required) as day-trips from Zürich.  The route of the Glacier Express connects with the main SBB network in Brig, Andermatt (via Göschenen on the Gotthard line) and Chur.  You can do a single leg (eg Zürich - Bern - Brig - Zermatt and return or Zürich - Bern - Brig - Andermatt - Göschenen - Zürich), or longer portions depending on your personal endurance level.   
Bernina Pass. 
It is possible to do Zürich - Chur - St Moritz - Tirano and back in a day, and there are ordinary trains that accept ordinary tickets without supplements.  There is also a round trip involving a Postbus from Tirano to Lugano that goes around lake Como to make a round trip out of it.  This is entirely covered by a Swiss day-pass, but needs to be reserved (you can do this at any main railway station).  Obviously if you do the Bernina pass route, it involves stretch from Chur to St Moritz, so if you are doing the Glacier Express in parts on the cheap (ie without paying the supplement), obviously you won't need to duplicate this track.   
If you aren't a completionist and just want to have a day out sample trip, I would recommend the Zürich - Chur - St Moritz - Tirano (over the Bernina) as the single best one day trip.  The railway from Chur - Tirano (via St Moritz) is listed as a UNESCO world heritage site, and is quite spectacular.

Enjoy!

Stayed there in mid July. AMAZING place. Had breakfast (included, very good) and dinner twice, once on the "inclusive" option (Halppension in German) which was a 3 course menue with two choices (beef fillet was what we went for), very good but small ish portions. We went a la carte the next night, though more expensive was absolutely fantastic food except for the desert variation, which I found a bit disappointing. Agree that SPA is also good, but infinity pool is really small (compared to pictures online). If weather is good I def recommend hiking from hotel to the Engstling falls (about 2 hrs next to a mountain brook) and then taking the cable car up and walking on the Alm (amazing alpine scenery). Then a bus back to opposite the hotel (both bus and cable car are not cheap though). All in I would def. recommend this place. Have fun!!!!

post:
Hi,   
have lived here circa 11 years and tried most places.   
Since you are looking for good skiing (variety of terrain and levels, with good ski schools), good accommodations, good apres ski and dining options, and accessible by train, the best by far is Davos.   
Flumserberg is also good, and closer, but skiing is less varied, accomodation more limited, no real centre of town as such, apres ski limited, dining limited, but accessible by train.   
Best way to find accomodation in Davos is homegate or go to Davos and check out the small ads in Co-op (Davos Platz). Prices for a one bedroom with a view approx CHF 1100 per month depending on availabilty. Ski pass approx CHF 1200, but includes Flims and Lezerheide (as others have mentioned).   
I wish you all the best,   
W

post:
I took a delightful river rafting trip on the Vorderrhein with a river rafting company.   
Positives: 
- Good equipment including neoprene suits, wind jackets, life jackets, boots, and helmuts 
- Gorgeous scenery (rafting through the Grand Canyon of the Switzerland) 
- Not that strenuous 
- Not too much white water but enough to make it exciting even for teenagers   
Neutral: 
- All river rafting staff were from an English speaking country.  Some could speak German, others only spoke English.   
Negatives: 
- The group needs to lift the boat.  That's fine when the group is big but ours was small and I wasn't too keen on straining my back.   
We parked at Reichenau and took the train to Ilanz, where the company was waiting for us with a shuttle bus.  We were taken to the river, where we got our gear, instructions and embarked on our trip.   
Reservations are required.   
River rafting is a lot of fun with a family or group of friends.  All participants must be at least 10 years old.
looks nice.  I went camping a few years ago in Vallemagia just nearby.

Not many records are still in place 100 years on but the Jungfraujoch railway station on the shoulder of the Jungfrau mountain in the Bernese Oberland is still the highest in Europe, a century after it opened on Swiss national day.       
On their birthday, all persons from age 16, (children are thus excluded) are entitled to return tickets from Interlaken Ost to the Jungfraujoch for themselves and a companion at the special price of CHF 80.00 per person.   
Identification showing date of birth must be presented with the ticket to the ticket inspector on the train. The Junior Card is valid with this ticket.

Don't know about Luzern, but in Zurich there are several places. The flea market at Helvetiaplatz *can* have some lovely stuff - but remains a flea market; the market at Bürkliplatz by the lake is probably more to your tastes, with antique gems between the odd, weird and jumble.

Saw the show today. Nice enough, they just emptied the museum for her. You won^t be disturbed by the crowd, maybe 10 people inside on a Sunday pm. There is also a well-appointed natural history museum in the modern basement included in the price.
Personally, I prefer the scenery on the Visp route.

"Auch die Zirkusse Nock und Harlekin präsentierten sich aus Tierschutzsicht erfreulich. Pferde, Kamele, Zebras und Esel geniessen an fast allen Standorten Auslauf und Weide. Der Umgang mit den Tieren in den Manegen dieser Zirkusse ist respektvoll und korrekt."   
English translation: "Also the circuses Nock and Harlequin appeared pleasant from the animal protection viewpoint. Horses, camels, zebras and donkeys enjoy exercise and pasture at almost all locations. The contact with the animals in the rings of these circuses is respectful and correct."   
Much work has been done in recent years to improve the already high standards of animal welfare here in Switzerland and in the UK.  Most of these improvements follow the guidelines laid out by Dr. Marthe Kiley-Worthington in her report commissioned by the RSPCA.  This report was published independently after the RSPCA decided not to do so.     
And some animal activists do not always tell/show the truth.  I remember looking at a copy of BBC Wildlife magazine some years ago which had a photo of a hippo at Circus Knie in his travel box and implying that this was how he was kept when not performing.  I had been to the show that year and know he also had an outdoor area and a water pool he could enjoy whenever he wanted to.

It's kid/family friendly...

Hey folks,   
As a visitor to Zürich I got helped out by a nice CouchSurfer, who bought me a public transport daypass for Wednesday the 13th. Only problem is, I'm leaving the country by the 12th - a very unfortunate miscommunication.   
With the dayass (Tägeskarte), it is possible to take pretty much all trains, busses, trams, boats and other forms of public transport in all of Switzerland. Hence: if you have a day off, this is for you!   
There's no reason for me to make money off this, but it would be nice if you could pay me the CHF 44 I paid for the ticket. Probably the easiest way of getting it to you is by mail.   
Interested? Text me your address and I'll send you back my details for wiring the money. If you're afraid this is a hoax: feel free to wait before wiring until you received the ticket - in this I'm supposing you're not an a*hole.    
My phone numbers: 
+31 6 44 838 131 (Dutch cell phone) 
+41 77 93 62 315 (Swiss cell phone)   
Hope whoever's going to use it is going to have a darn good time!    
Mathijs

You could try the Katzensee near Regensdorf. There is a cafe at the badi where you can have a coffee while the kids swim, play in the sand, or in the playground. I think there are shower facilities there too to clean up before the next flight.

Did it with my work team  last year in Luzern.   Was quite fun as we went all over the city and outside too, using several forms of transport.   Stopped for a few beers a long the way too!   
I think it would be better in a bigger group than with two people.   We divided our group into three teams, each following different routes around the trail.   That way we could make it into a race, which made it more fun.
Not exactly family-run, but   has a location to die for. We stayed with a 6 month old toddler and they were very accomodating.

Thank you for the advice all!  I just wanted to update the EF on the conditions at Zermatt.  The Glacier Palace and the last leg of the gondola going up there were closed this past weekend (June 2, 2012); I didn't see any notice on the Zermatt website prior to going there, but then again I wasn't looking for it.     
So we walked across town again to catch the train up to Gornergrat instead.  The views were spectacular.  The cost is 80 CHF round-trip, or 40 CHF if you have the half-price card or other similar transportation deal.  We stayed there for quite a while, just enjoying the view.  The one souvenir shop was closed up there.  There appears to be one restaurant but we didn't go in.    
We did see a wild goat on the side of the mountain, though!  The views of the Matterhorn and the mountain range were wonderful.  Be aware that after around 2pm your photos will be backlit, but still beautiful.  It's a bit like Vancouver but you get to be really close to the mountains after only a 35min train ride, which also offers spectacular views of Zermatt and the Matterhorn.   
Overall we had a great trip and I finished it off with a yummy cheese fondue!
thread: Zermatt: Gornergrat or Matterhorn Glacier Paradise?

post: Train museum, car museum, zoo, big slightly out of town cinema complex although cannot vouch for anything being in English (not far from carrefour) and also soft play (Kingersheim but again not more than 10 mins drive from Carrefour).  Oh and teeny tiny ball pond round the corner at the Carrefour cafeteria and good children's gifts with the kids menu (snap cards, etc) if you eat the Italian restaurant in the shopping complex.

OR.....what is nice is to take the train from Grindelwald up to Alpiglen and walk along the bottom of the North Face of the Eiger to Kleine Scheidegg (which is an uphill route) or vice versa. Its pretty dramatic but an easy walk. Will be COLD though as the sun won't really have reached it yet. Or another fun walk is to go to KS and then walk down the Lauberhorn World Cup Ski route   
Have a good day whatever you decide - its going to be a gorgeous day in the Oberland

Hi there.   
Welcome to the forum.   
I am unsure if you know about Reka:     
Your husband is likely to get "reka cheques" through work - this is like discounted money which you can use to pay for a variety of things, including train travel and petrol.   
Some places of work offer 1000CHF worth, at either 20% or 33% reduced. 
Ask him to ask his work collogues about the fringe benefits.   
Otherwise these holildays can be paid for with "real money".   
You could also team up with a friend, with or without children, to go with you. 
It is always nicer to share a bottle of wine on the balcony, during these long hot summer nights

My (US-American) teenage kids will be spending a few weeks with me in Zurich starting about mid-June, and will be left to their own devices while I work. So here's what I was thinking, to get them out of the apartment: organize a photo scavenger hunt, where they have to find things on a list and take a picture of each before going on to the next.    
They'd have to be things that would appeal to a 17-year-old boy and a 20-year-old girl, both of whom would rather be at home gaming and watching anime on their laptops. I'd give them a map and they'd probably get some kind of passes for a month for all zones. Oh, and I'd rather they were in places they could enter for free. I've thought of a few things, and a friend has suggested a few too. Of course, there'd be some kind of reward for getting them all. Anybody have suggestions for things to find? They could also be things to do, like "drink from one of the fish fountains at Bellevue".   
Another idea I had was a culinary scavenger hunt, separately. So ideas are welcome for that too.

post:
Hi Guys,   
in early June a friend and i will be hiking across  Switzerland, as part of this we will be taking a hiking path up to  Leutschachhütte SAC and from there the hiking trail ends and we're left  with the step accents to Krönten, Chli/Gross Spannort and Schlossberg.  My question is if there's a reasonable (hard walking, minor climbing but  NOT overly dangerous) route from Leutschachhütte SAC in the valley to  the east to Spannorthütte SAC in the valley to the west which is east of  Engelberg?   
I ask as from satellite imagery shows some rather  large ridges to tackle and possibly glacial ice between the  aforementioned mounts? We will have suitable clothing/weather protection  and walking crampons/poles but no climbing gear (no helmets).   
Any tips most appreciated.   
Thanks.
SBB has a deal for day trips to Junfruajoch... Worth a look too, or else get an all day ABO from SBB and go touring, that can be quite fun.

There are a couple decent and not so hard climbs in the Grindelwald area. You can climb the Schwarzhorn on the First side or up the Klettersteig Rotstock at the base of the Jungfrau Massif. Both are pretty decent areas and the views are amazing. From there you can shoot strait past Brienze over to the Gothard Tunnel.

The Jura is great too - go to Nyon then up towards the Col du Marchairuz and walk the ridge in either directions with fabulous views of the Alps. Or over the top and down to Lac de Joux and walk around the lake - and have lunch at La Truite. And of course you have to go to Gruyères- along the lake to Vevey and then up towards Fribourg. From there you can do the loop by Chateau d'oex, and Gstaad, then on and over to Charmey (visit the spa baths) and down to Bulle and back to Vevey.   
Or along the South shore of the Lake to lovely Yvoire for lunch, and visit the Jardin des Sens, and back via Villeneuve and Montreux.   
Or to the spa bath at Val d'Illiez and walking in the Champéry area (take cable car to top) opposite my favourite moutains, the Dents du Midi.   
Or to the Rhone Valley and up to the spa baths at Ovronnaz. Or keep going on to Sion and up to the Val D'Hérens and really cute Evolène and the Arolla Glacier. There are virtually millions of fab places to go from Geneva, in every direction! Enjoy.

We have two medium size upright carry-on bags that we have lugged around for many years, on smooth and on cobblestoned surfaces. One is WORLDBOUND and the other PIERRE CARDIN. I bought them roughly 8 years ago at Marshalls and Ross in the US. Those shops have very nice brand name suitcases at reasonable prices. They were roughly $60-$80 each. Our bags have big wheels (in hard rubber/plastic material) that do not spin sidewards. On cobblestones do not use bags or suitcases that have small wheels and the ones that spin sidewards. The wheels that spin around are very good on smooth floors like at the airport but not on cobblestones. Good luck on finding better quality suitcases with sturdy wheels!

In the area, there's also a loop  featuring different water fountains (see #4).     *This map doesn't include the second waterfall. Follow signs (very well signposted) to Ferreyres a little while after the first waterfall.

post:
At this time of year, I doubt that you will have any problems. I have never had any problem with just arriving and pitching a one person tent, even in the height of the summer school holiday period. The only shortage tends to affect people who have large caravans and/or are wanting a spot with electricity.    
But, I don't know when the season opens here. I have cycled and camped through parts of France before, at Easter time, and was surprised to find that many camping grounds were not open for the season - I think the first weekend of May was the opening time for manym with the end of September being the end of the season.

We are very lucky in Neuchatel as Easter Friday is always a Bank Holiday, as well as Easter Monday. Which other K/Cantons have Friday off?   
If you want to join in an Easter Egg race with the children, either go to:   
Buttes/La Robella (NE) egg (chocolate) finding races will take place at 10 and 11, and a massive race for all at 14.30. Lots of activities for kids, food, and free access to the Feeline big luge run. 5CHF for adults, 2 for kids, and free fro 5 and under. Only about 200m from the train station. About 35 mins from Neuchatel or Yverdon.   
Another egg race will take place at Fribourg Botanical garden, on Saturday 7th  at 14.00, meet by the fountain Chemin du Musée.   
From 7th to 9th April  10-18.00 at the Musée du Fer near Vallorbe (VD)    - there will be a Festival des Couteliers/cutlers festival. All about knife and sword making from all over the world, with demos, etc. 
Adults 12CHF, children 6, family 27CHF   
And on Sunday there will be a big Easter market in Chateau d'Oex (VD), with demos of local traditions, farm animals, donkey rides, Swiss fighting, grass scooters, wood carving and local foods.   
In Payerne a big Brocante both Friday and Sat 10.00-20.00 and Sunday 10.00-18.00.

Thanks too Squeeeez, good tips - been meaning to go to Gruyere for ages, so might try that, am going to Interlaken in a couple of weeks - might head for my favourite, the Matterhorn, if you reckon that area could be best.

Cinque Terre sadly had massive and terrible floods and landslides last autumn, so I wouldn't go there now without checking what the situation is.   
But Tuscany is beautiful in June, with the poppy fields and wild flowers - fly to Florence, or Pisa or Rome, hire a car and just take a right or a left - and see where it takes you- and go to the sea for a few days but water might not be warm enough for you - it was 19C and we swam a lot last year in June. Or take a ferry to Elba for a few days. Not busy at that time of year, no need to book - just enjoy. I'd advise the less busy towns of Pienza and Montepulciano, but also San Gimignano and Lucca in the North. Or just drive there - you'll be in Lucca in a day - or do what we do, stop for a night in Etroubles/Aosta area - again no need to book.

HOw active are you? your friends? A novel way to see Basel is to do a guided running tour ( speed adjusted  for individual groups) through the centre.     
They are fun, with lots of quirky Basel information throughout the tour. ( you jog, stop, all the way. )   
OR: The weather is great at the moment, so how about a round the bridges walk, to see Basel from both side s of the river. Go between the MIttelbrucke and Westeinbrucke, or even up one more bridge. Take in the Tuingley museum and any of the numerous outdoor cafes along the way.   
OR: use bikes and go on a "3 country tour" between Basel, France and Germany. If it is a Saturday, include the St Louis vegetable market and a look at the whitewater kayaking in HUningue. there is a relaxing cafe just over the walking bridge, on the german side.    
HOt day? go for a swim down the Rhine.
lol, what made you change your mind? Mentioning of the theatre? Did you go to Kaiseraugst this afternoon and received some local blessing?

post:
All my favourite places have been mentioned already, but here are some more votes for them    
I agree that Beaune is very nice, however you can quickly run out of things to do as you can see everything in a day quite easily. Just south of Beaune is Chalon-sur-Saône, which is a bit bigger and is on the river. (it has a great street festival in July). Careful where you stay in Beaune as the main TGV line runs through the town.   
Lyon is fabulous, plenty of cheap eateries and plenty of cheap accommodation. You'll never get tired of Lyon if you like to eat  . Also consider getting the train there, for an even more relaxing weekend.   
Alsace is wonderful also, and another vote goes to Riquewihr although all the little villages west of Colmar are treasures.   
The French do love to eat out, much more than the Swiss, so the one thing I always do is book restaurants before I go. Rocking up to a lovely restaurant (not necessarily an expensive one) and sitting down at a reserved table sure beats the "walk of shame" when you're turned away because the place is full

post:
There are ski-busses on weekends (and Fridays) from central Paquis to a few resorts, which are very handy. 70CHF pp though - but not bad as it includes your lift pass.    
They tend to leave about 8.15am, back about 6.30 - 1hr to 1hr30 each way depending on resort. I was in Avoriaz last Saturday, and Flaine on Sunday, lots of snow still in both, great skiing!    
They are popular though, so get your tickets a couple of days in advance if you want any choice.    
Details and timetable here:   - choose "Ski Pass and Transportation" from the drop down box in the bottom right corner.    
They don't go to all resorts everyday that they list in this though, being French, they seem to randomly pick where they will run buses to any particular weekend :P Buses are scheduled to keep running for another few weeks though, so time yet to get your skiing fix in!

You can take the lift up to Schilthorn, where they filmed the James Bond movie and the views of the Alps are magnificent.   
The next day, you can take the bus (or long walk) to Trümmelbachfälle - glacier waterfalls from the Mönch, Eiger and Jungfrau, part of the UNESCO World Heritage sites.

post: Pity that they're sold out   Would have been a fun thing to do with my daughter before we leave. I tried to do a tour last year, but they said they had ceased doing them....bummer.

The price difference is certainly down to economies of scale, American are one of the biggest operators of aluminum birds, but their international reputation is very average. Swiss is better in every aspect except price. It's a no brainer if price is your only criteria, but if you want efficient service, better food and more modern IFE (In Flight Entertainment), Swiss's modern Airbus fleet will beat AA's aging B767s every time.

I popped in at the Kunsthaus yesterday evening to see the current "Wintermärchen" exhibition on images of winter from the middle ages to modernism. I wasn't expecting anything breathtaking, just a lot of snowy landscapes by minor genre painters... besides I find the timing completely wrong, by now we are all more in the mood for spring than for winter I would say. but as a convinced holder of a membership card and living in the vicinity, I do go there quite often, just to relax and be reminded of beauty.   
I must say was pleasantly surprised, so I wanted to share. There are quite a few major artists including Brueghel, Monet, Goya and even the super famous heroic Napoleon portrait by David from the Belvedere in Vienna 
But guess what? in the end I found myself stopping even longer in front of the minor genre paintings admiring the beauy of detail in rendering the particular light and changes of nature in winter. 
There are not only paintings but also tapestries and luxurious baroque sleds from the austrian empire (one even in leopard skin - possibly fake, anyway impressive ).    
All in all a great exhibition to take the kids, too! they will love the skating and sledding scenes, the fires and children playing in the snow. even a perplexed little boy dringking from a freshly slaughtered pig's bladder (don't worry, no gruesome scene involved ). or an angry woman fetching her drunken hubby home from the pub... 
the explanations are as usual very clear and really help put the whole theme into context. all in all a very pleasant evening even if you're a not an art freak!

we've done 5 flights with our 5 month old already, with another international trip coming up next week, and the one thing I can definitely tell you is each one is a little bit different    For all the flights, I have had my hubby with me, so this is what I have found works when there are two of you. If there is only one, then travel light - get as much on the other side as you can from friends if you can!   
- get to the airport early so you can go to the counter to check in and deal with an actual human who can tell you all kinds of wonderful things like if the plane is not full and there is an empty seat that they will happily give you for the little one, or if the airport that you are changing flights at will bring the stroller to you or if it will go straight through to the next flight - all are different. Most airports have family areas - ask when you check in where it is and you can have a place to go where there is at least a clean change table and usually some other little ones for yours to watch or, as they get older, play with to pass the time saving those precious few items you could fit into the bag with you for the actual plane ride.    
- we have a car seat that attaches to a quinny stroller, so it is very light weight and compact when broken down. We have been able to take the car seat onto the plane with us 2 of the 5 flights - once as there was an empty seat so we could plunk the little guy into his very own seat without being charged for it, the other time we could just put it up in the overhead bin as it folded down and the bins were big enough. The other times, the planes were a bit smaller so the bins couldn't fit the seat, so it was checked at the gate with our stroller - and as it is put in a special place in checked bags, it seems to be a bit safer as no scratches have appeared. We also have always needed a car seat on the other end, so it was a must to bring.    
- pillow - I have a boppy breast feeding pillow so it's small enough to wrap around my sides and still fit in an airplane seat, but I know most people over here have the super long pillows that won't quite work. However, if you bring a stroller, you can easily slide a normal pillow under it so you aren't carrying it and it has proved to be a life saver on the flights when we didn't have the car seat or bassinet. No one bats an eye at it as an extra piece of carry on luggage, so don't worry about that. The little guy ate on the way up, fell asleep and just slept there for most of the trip. made it a bit awkward to eat, but hubby and I took turns eating so I could just use his tray to keep things on and for once it helped that airlines serve all food items in a number of little dishes    
- security - have one of you deal with the stroller and baby and the other deal with the actual carry on bags - especially so you don't forget to tell them that you have formula or even breast milk in bottles! As long as you tell them, they let you bring whatever is reasonable for the length of the flight and 1-2 extra feeds for the other side. If you forget, then they might ask you a million extra questions.    
And don't feel like you have to rush!!  It is the nature of the event that you feel sorry for everything, but reality is, you ARE going to take a bit longer but you absolutely need to stay calm and not get flustered otherwise little one will start to wonder what the problem is and really make it a problem. Just relax, you are not the first person to fly with a baby. If they cry, they cry - do what you normally do to calm them down. For some, the airplane noise is a wonderful sleep inducer, for others, they have no idea what is going on and need to be reassured that much more - you stressing about them crying will only make things worse as they will wonder what really is wrong since you are all worked up too!

Excellent advice! Also my favourite place (we spend each summer at Rigi Kaltbad). Just a clarification.   
The cable car from Weggis only goes as far as Kaltbad. Here you have to get off and transfer to train. If you take the cable car at 20 mins past the hour, it connects with the train going on up to Kulm. The cable cars run at 20 past and 50 past.   
An excellent (and very Swiss) place for something to eat is Hotel Edelweiss at Staffelhohe. The food is locally sourced (ie Mount Rigi and surrounding lower level villages) where possible and the young couple who run it are charming.   
There are a lot of sledge runs and you can rent sledges from Kulm or Kaltbad so only need to make up your mind about sledging when you get there. Otherwise there are a lot of prepared winter walking routes .. all very accessible without special snow shoes. You will get a leaflet when you buy your cable car tickets, it shows all the trails.   
And why not get to Weggis by boat from Luzern? 40 mins. Check the timetables as the winter season is not very generous.   
And even better .. go when Weggis is shrouded in low cloud and experience the amazing moment in the cable car when it breaks through the cloud cover and out into brilliant sunshine.  Look at the webcams and weather forecasts on   and it is quite easy to work out days like this.

Not sure if this is the right place to post this but I had to share about a wonderful place we spent Christmas holiday.        
It was about 60 km outside of Geneva. Caroline the hostess was simply wonderful - we went for the catered chalet option - there were 13 of us - a bunch of my family converged from the US and Scotland. Caroline is an amazing chef and the Chalet was delightful and in a beautiful town called Samoens in France. There were 6 kids under the age of 12 and she catered to the kids tasted for dinner and the adults had wonderful cuisine for dinner. I can't recommend it more highly as a vacation spot      
We went for a ski holiday - I'm not a skier so it was a great place to learn b/c there were green beginner slopes I don't think they have here in CH. The expert skiers amongst also had a blast. There was something for everyone! Got great private ski lessons from Zig Zag Ecole at Caroline's recommendation.

Many (?) - some? - Swiss have a real passion for the US "Wild West" and Americana-style stuff.   
It is nothing new and was well documented in the books I read when I moved here a while back. One example is in the silly cars they import (i.e. not suitable to European roads).

Thanks for all your replies. I did read something on the website about them maybe asking you to change to one of their strollers but I just wanted to hear some first hand experience of this. Makes me feel more confident to go.   
Thanks again.

Evolène in the Val d'Hérens above Sion would be lovely for a romantic Christmas. A very old village, real Heidi style, with lots of excellent value restaurants. We like the Restaurant Central - lovely fireplace, oldie worldie chalet style dining room and excellent steak + excellent value. Have some vin chaud, they make it with white wine in Evolène, surprisingly good. Train to Sion and bus up (buses wait right next to station). Wonderful.   
And for an extra 60 CHF for 2 with breakfast,  stay in a lovely old-fashioned traditional hotel, built 1901 - all wood inside- simple but sooo cute and really friendly owners. Evolène is Switzerland as it used to be - enjoy it because it won't last (sadly).

post:
My wife and I took the Bernina Express last weekend and enjoyed it very much. We stayed overnight in the Bernina Hotel, just opposite the train station in Tirano. I'm not sure if it's possible to take the journey there and back on the same day, though I would imagine it's possible. Having said that, 8 hours on a train with kids in tow doesn't sound like much fun to me.   
There is no buffet car, but on the outward journey someone came around quite early in the journey with a basic refreshments cart. Just around the corner from Chur HB is a Migro zentrum which is open early in the morning (at least on the Saturday morning when we travelled), so you could stock up there before boarding. On the return journey, there were no refreshments, but we took a slightly different train which was still part of the Bernina Express service, but it went to St. Moritz and we had to change train in Pontressina and Samedan to get back to Chur.   
One word of advice, don't forget your sun glasses because the sun is very bright up on the pass.

i have been asked twice, once by qatar airways and next time by easyjet to show the card thru which booking was made. also sometimes the hotels also ask. it is just a way to prevent credit card frauds. So u might be asked.

Finally i will go to Tailand, Morocco is a good opticon (my parents come from there, so ive been there many times) but its very cold in xmas.  
I will keep in mind tel aviv and egypt....would love to go.   
Many thanks all for your responses.

post: Depends on ya Budget...and style??

You don't give us any details of the type of things you like to do, so that would help. Agree 100% with Salzburg, which is def. reachable for a weekend and would make a great place to spend one or two nights. If you get away early enough on Friday you can reach Salzburg (assuming no snow and using the Arlberg tunnel) in five hours, which would allow you to get in for a late dinner and then an evening wandering the streets of the Altstadt.    
If you had a long weekend, Vienna is the obvious destination, but more of a flight than a drive. The stretch from Salzburg to Wien is long, straight and boring. That said, if you are wine lovers &/or foodies, the Wachau and the other wine regions around Vienna offer some of the best of those wine/food thingies in all of Europe.    
If you are skiers / hikers, then Arlberg is a great place to spend a weekend and offers something for almost every budget (Montafon is pretty easy on the wallet, St. Anton a great mid-range place if you are into both ski and apres ski, and Lech/Zuers can break most people's monthly budgets over a champagne-filled weekend).    
There's a lot more on the list: St. Johann in Tirol for family skiing, Kitzbuhel for a taste of the Munich "schikeria", Burgenland, Neusiedlersee, the Donau, etc. etc. Personally, I'd give Innsbruck a miss.    
How many weekends do you have?

We had my parents visit and had a fixed day that we could travel on so we got the Day tickets 'Tageskarte-gemeinde' in Basel for 38 Chf each and then looked at the weather on the day to decide where to go.     
Our main options were Interlaken (for jungfraujoch), Pilatus or Zermatt/Gornergrat.  The weather on the day was rain for Interlaken and Pilatus and glorious sunshine for Zermatt/Gornergrat so that's where we went - and they loved it.     
With this ticket the day is fixed but not the destination and you can use the trains, trams, buses and some boats.  It also gives you half-price on the mountain railways.  If the weather is bad all over you can pick a destination with indoor appeal - like a city with shops/museums or just ride the trains all day!!

The time between late October until middle of December is not considered as a great tourist or hiking time. Fewer guests mean that running it will make even more of a deficit than usual so it is a great chance for the yearly check-up for safety and replacements.

post:
Correct. I live in Basel and fly often from Zürich, using the "Air Train". SWISS has no way of knowing whether you've used the train segment or not -- and the best bit is, you get Miles & More points for the train journey (whether you use it or not, since SWISS doesn't know) if the flight ticket as a whole is eligible for Miles & More points.   
Baggage check-in and collection is done at Zürich Airport. As snoopy1664 said, if you do want to use the train segment, be sure to check in online BEFORE you travel from Basel and print your boarding passes or get them delivered to your phone -- otherwise you will have no train ticket and will be liable to a fine (I've seen it happen). There is almost always a ticket inspection on the Basel-Zürich HB or Basel-Zürich Flughafen trains.   
And finally, as planetali commented, if you want to use the train, you don't have to use the Basel-Zürich Airport direct service. In fact, it's never the fastest option -- the non-stop train to Zürich HB, then appropriate connection to Zürich Flughafen, is always faster but involves a change.

I lived in Lyon for 5 years, and I went to the Fete des Lumières twice. You have to know that it is really crowded, especially around place des Terreaux, Bellecour and Hotel de ville. Last time I went, we couldn't even walk, we were stuck in the crowd and force to go wherever the crowd would go. Never again.   
Initially, the Fete des Lumieres was december the 8th. It is now 4 days long, but most of the Lyonnais still light up their candle on the 8th. That is really beautiful. Every windows has lot of small candles, it is magic.   
Last year, I went  to see the Parc de la tete d'or installations, and it was really nice. There was fire everywhere, and don't how they manage not to burn the parc down !   
Anyway, if you don't like crowded places, don't go, it will ruin the magical. But if you don't mind, then go ! And Lyon is indeed a nice city !   
But remember, Lyon isn't switzerland ! Watch your belongings !

the area where I live that is. Born and bred here in the Neuchatel Jura, back now with my British OH after 40+ years in the UK. It's lovely to be back and we would like to discover the rest of Switzerland, but money is a bit tight now on UK pensions due to exchange rate. And anyway, visiting an area with locals, even if adopted, is so much more interesting. I know all the best places around here, be they walks, restaus, Museums or other attractions - and would love to share them with others. We are in our 60s, but young at heart, so age unimportant, families welcome.   
So how about swaps. Not swapping houses in the 'traditional' sense, but co-hosting. If somebody would like to get to know another area- and woud be prepared to show us where they live- that could be fun. For us it can be week-end or week days. All is required is a simple but comfortable spare room. We can offer a very large double en-suite- and another if somebody has children. No dogs as our own elderly dog is jealous as hell of other dogs. On a 1, 2, 3 basis- we cook the first night, we go to a local restau (all budgets and style avalaible) and if you stay longer, you cook the next meal (btw we live a few minutes from France for shopping) and so on.   
Anybody interested?   
Cross-country and downhill skiing in winter available (equipment hire nearby), a whole array of interesting Museums, fab walks, absinthe tours, nearby France, etc.

post:
Interested in nature and traditional crafts, etc in Romandie. 
The weekly newspaper 'Terre et Nature', available at all newsagents is a great source of information. All the 'nature' events for the coming week are listed there. Here is a selections of what is going on this week-end in Romandie:   
Autumn fair in Romainmotier (VD - a beautiful little medieval town) - sale and demo of trational crafts, both Sat and Sun.   
Queen cow contest (combat de Reines) Sunday 16th in Sugnens VD from 10am.   
Bénichon (traditonal fair) in Chatel St Denis (FR) Today 9-16.00 artisan market. Sunday at 15.oo cortège on the theme of local crafts.   
Today at the botanical garden of Fribourg UNI - sale and exhibition of old varieties of apples and other orchard fruit.   
Pringy (FR) at the demo cheese place, daily demonstration of local crafts 10-12 and 13-17. until 1st of November. Sat 15th and Sun 16th demo of manufacture of miniature wooden chalets.     
Val D'Illiez (VS) traditonal rural fair, with lots of traditional music and dancing and costumes today and tomorrow.    
Les Diablerets VD farmers market, exhibition and talks on 'woodland and pasture' in harmony. Today and tomorrow at the Maison des Congrès.   
Chestnut Festival in Fully VS. Music, craft demos, food, visit of the chestnut plantations, etc all day today and tomorrow.   
Similar as above, but in Gryon (VD) from 17.00 today.   
Geneva/Presinge - today 11-19 local produce and tonight 'barn dance' 19-2am. Sunday market of local produce, demos and tastings 9.30-17.00 
At the Ferme de l'Abbaye.   
Sunday Fete de Coing - quince festival. Brunch served with lots of quince recipes, both savoury and sweet, cold and hot. Small market at bar. Need to reserve for tomorrows brunch on 0788243057. From 10am at the 'battoir'.   
Currently at Chateau de Chillon - exhibition on Witch Hunts from the 15 to 17C.   
Have a great week-end all.

We travel with our son, who has type 1 diabetes, and I can't say it takes any longer to get through security - we have a letter from our doctor explaining the medication and equipment, and that we are carrying additional supplies plus it must be carried as hand luggage.   
I guess the USA is tough (I haven't been there but have heard plenty of stories) but we didn't find it raised any eyebrows in Heathrow, Singapore, Paris, Barcelona or Birmingham airports.   
The only one where we had to unpack everything was singapore, and it was a senior staff instruction a new staff member, and by their manner (the singaporean was formal but polite) it really was for the new staff training purposes (he was talking her through the procedure) rather than because they were querying the gear.   
Hope that helps. The main thing in my opinion is to stay calm, precise, and have a 'can you help me' attitude. I always go to the first staff member on the security counter and say "oh, we have diabetes gear in here - do you need to see it?" - usually they just wave me through and everything goes through the scanner.   
I have heard of kids with pumps being asked to unplug them and put them through the scanner - I'm not sure if that's a problem for the pump, but I'm sure by now there are enough insulin pumps around that the security team should be able to recognise one if they saw it...

Sure I posted about this last year too!   
But I'm a big fan so anyway the Mathis Hof (in Bottmingen just outside Basel) Pumpkin Festival is on this weekend (24th and 25th September) if you fancy popping along for some Kurbis-everything. There are hundreds of varieties of pumpkin for sale as well as other farm produce including schnaps and preserves. There's lots of fun activities for kids as well - a Maize maze, straw castle, kids can carve or draw on a pumpkin and hit each other with pillowcases of feathers....! Check their website for location, timing etc.     
We are going on the Sunday with a bunch of people from the BCT so if you feel like joining us, the more the merrier. We're meeting at 3pm at the maze entrance (although we'll probably be there a bit earlier than that for some pumpkin-related lunch - or just sausages!)   
Maybe see you there?
