Well as Kinhorngreen rightly stated, letting speedy boarders on first is more of a commercial issue however unfair it may seem. 
Let`s not forget that almost ALL passengers HATE this free seating policy. It has recently been scientifically proven NOT to be the most efficient way of boarding passengers. It just winds everyone up - I hate it personally. 
Yes, people do rush to the gate `like sheep` and it`s pretty s**t when a lot of them refuse to budge for parents with small children. There are always people like that unfortunately. However you do have to consider how `shit`it really is now on those flights. 
I hate having to join the `sheep` and often sit back thinking `let them get on with it` . . but then when you get on . . the lockers are full. 
Why? because everyone takes hand luggage to the limit and beyond (if they can get away with it) obviously because of the claw-back charges from the airlines. Even though it is not allowed, people still take 2 bags on. 
The result is that the lockers are always full before the passengers are boarded. `Put bags under the seat in front` they announce but with minimal leg room anyway . . that can be bloody uncomfortable. 
There are the `rush rush rush` people who want a quick getaway at the other end (they always want front seats). Then there are the big/double bag brigade (they want locker space). Then finally you get the `one person from a group pays for SB and saves seat for the others` . . good if you can get away with it . . but one woman said to me`those 2 seats are taken`. . . and those 3 behind as well` . . after I had paid for SB I thought that was a bit rich! 
I do have a preference but its quite simple and for a good reason. I like to have an aisle seat because since I broke my collar bone several years ago and it never healed properly - I cant sit with my shoulders `scrunched`up. 
I dont give a hoot which row it is on . . . as long as the girl on the next seat is a (good) looker . . .oops . 
Bottom line is, as LOADDDDDS of people on the EF will tell us . . what do you expect from a cheap airline? True . . but it could be SO much better.

Remember to enjoy the traditional games and rides  you drink and eat too much.    I especially enjoyed the one where you go up standing on a conveyor belt and at the top they give you a mat to sit on and slide down a spiral helter-skelter. Did it in a Dirndl too.

post:
Looks like the right engine failed. If you take a look at nozzles you'll see that the left hand nozzle is wide open, but the right hand nozzle is closed.       
At such a slow speed the difference in thrust would have produced the sudden yaw that you can see in the video, causing the the right hand wind to drop below the stall speed, and ultimately causing the aircraft to enter a spin   
Given the low altitude the situation would have been totally unrecoverable, and the only chance for the pilot would be to punch out - as he did.   
I'm sure Assassin, or Wolli, will be along soon to correct me.   
Good photos.

post:
Ok,    
This is an old post but I thought I add my 2 cents, been europark and disney in paris now, took the car with the kids to both. Biggest difference, most of the rides in europark are outside, most of the rides in disney inside (warehouse size buildings). Other big difference the queues, in europark rarely queued for more then 10 minutes, in disney paris I recall one ride we queued for 1 hour (the ride lasted 5 minutes, if that). The shows however in disney paris where beyond comparison, truly excellent.   
Took us about 7 hours drive, about 1 hour south of Lausanne to get to Paris, not a difficult journey, no traffic (went a few weeks back). Cost of the train or plane if your a family prohibitive. Parking in disney if your staying in the park free (europark parking free too).

post: If you like a good day hike, I strongly recommend the Sentir des Fromagarie in Gruyere.  See  .  It's a respectable climb but not too difficult and the path is very well marked (it's also a snowshoe trial in the winter).  The beauty is, you can hike to different fromagaries and get some cheese and a glass (or more!) of beer.  The trail head (and parking lot) is near to the big cheese factory / touring place in Gruyere.  So while you might get some big tourist busses, if you end there at the finish if your hike, it is a very nice place to sit and relax in the sun with a suitable beverage.  Also, there's so much to do around Gruyere that it's hard to beat -- even on a Swiss holiday.

post:
By the time we were ready for our hike the clouds had moved in    
So today, when I saw almost cloudless sky, I hurried up about 160 (vertical) meters before breakfast to get some pictures.  Will do lots of editing and culling and post to my Picassa album, but for now here is a view of the Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau:     
Too much sun for a good picture, but I am certainly not complaining

Given good weather the very best views are not from villages but from higher elevations, many accessible by train or lift.  Switzerland is a surprisingly big country, and I only know a few corners of it, but the view from the Gornergrat is hard to beat.  There are many other great views, including some much closer to Zurich (Rigi, Pilatus, Titlis .. .).  If going up high on a sunny summer day (assuming we get any this summer  ) remember that the temperature drops dramatically with elevation, bring lots of warm clothes.   
Mürren is hard to beat as a village when the weather cooperates, but then we all have our favorites.

post:
The path from Lauterbrunnen to Wengen is very pretty, with good views of the valley. Allow 90 minutes to 2 hours to do the hike, depending on how fit you are (as said above, there is a height gain of 600 metres/almost 2,000 feet).   
Using the distance in kilometres to estimate time/effort is not a good idea in the mountains...   what really counts is how much height you have to gain or lose.

post:
Yes the tickets are valid for 3 days, but obviously you can only travel each section of your trip once (+ return).   
But for example if you buy a railaway from Zürich to the olympic museum in Lausanne you can do the following:   
Friday: Zurich - Bern, stay overnight 
Saturday: Bern - Lausanne 
Sunday: Lausanne - Zurich   
Or    
Friday: Zurich - Lausanne, stay 2 nights 
Sunday: Lausanne - Zurich    
Hope this helps. I often travelled like this, especially in winter with the snow & rail deals. Staying over with friends en-route on day 1, continue travel to the skiresort the next day, and go home on day 3.

As part of our week long stay in switzerland, we will be driving by a few car accessible glaciers. 
Another interest for us is water bodies. 
Not the big interlaken or lucerne type lakes, but alpine lakes in meadows with views of alps around. 
Kind of like what you see from grimsel, but with greenery(slightly lower altitude maybe) and alpine views.   
The plan is simple, drive, and hike not more than 10-15 minutes to get to such a lake.   
Avoiding gondola etc., as the CHF is going through the roof. every 10-15CHF is going to pinch!.   
Its a multi country trip, so we already have a car rented for many days, and would like to use it!

The question is, that normally, before registration for the flight you can ask a customs officer to stamp your tax free letter and inspect purchased things.   
In Zurich airport, you have registration on flight much before customs zone where customs officers are working. So either you: 
1. register for a flight together with baggage registration and they taking your baggage together with purchased things. 
2. go on border and stamp a paper together with providing of bought goods.   
in 1st case, on a border you can not show anything from your baggage (I am planing to pack everything to the baggage)   
in 2nd case you can not came back for a registration (as for my understanding)     
that is what mostly not clear for me.   
For example in Barcelona's airport, you have special customs officer's window before registration, you show him your good, he stamps papers. It is always crowdly there as well... but after that you can go for a registration and check-in..

post:
Short answer, yes.  You can buy the Swiss Transfer Ticket, the Swiss Pass, and most other "tourist"-type tickets at *some* SBB counters (NOT ticket machines), and you can definitely do it at the airport SBB counter.  They always speak English and you can even ask them for advice.  They are usually very friendly, but it is good to at least go in with an idea of what you want.     
With your other scenario, you would be just fine booking city tickets too.  But it may be cheaper to buy the transfer ticket, especially because going back and forth to airports usually costs more, which is built into the price of the transfer ticket and not usually into the city tickets.  This is something you should research and/or just ask the ticketing agent when you arrive.

post: We got there early, around 10.30am and stayed till it became very busy (after 2 pm). Hardly any wait and the kids had a lot of fun, we all loved that blitz thing where you can make funny pictures of your shadow! Also with a big family like ours it's better to take a 6 months pass, so we didn't have to go to all the attractions, have 6 months to go again..and again...and again!

If you go to the Zoo which I think is supposed to be one of the best in Europe, afterwards you could go to the restaurant nextdoor called Outpost. It has the best steak I've had in Zurich. Canadian Black Angus Tenderloin. Mmmmmm.   
If you go to the Landesmuseum and get the watertaxi (which is included in your Zurich travel ticket) you can get the boat down to Casino at Zurihorn. The boat takes you down the river Limmat going under the bridges and then zig zagging over the lake. It's really bustling round the Casino-Bellevue boulevard. Lots of people having fun on the lawns, going for a swim, playing frisbee, street entertainers. There's pedallos there for hire. There's a really cool water fountain there which is a rotating one tonne granite sphere. Take a bbq maybe. Then you can walk up to Bellevue via the Chinagarten.   
All in all I think Zurich's a nice place to live but not really that interesting tourist destination.   
I think there's a free outdoor music fest 20 mins down the lake at Wadenswil.   
Higgy Baby

post: Plenty of good passes closer to Zurich worth exploring - just stay out of my way tomorrow

Most dog owners escape this weekend with their canine friends to other parts of Europe due to the fireworks. Personally, I dont. My dog still barks when he hears the fireworks but its more alert and excited than anxious barking now.   
I am glad we decided to bite the bullet and stay - never celebrate 4th of July so dont know what its like but from what I've observed: alot of families tend to gather together and bbq or laze by the lake. Its absolutely heaving and people start setting off their fireworks before the official ones.    
Your individual gemeindes will also have celebrations. Ours this year is organised by the Womens Gymnastics Club - a breakfast buffet after mass in the morning and performances by the local choral choirs later in the afternoon before the fireworks and bonfire. Not the most exciting activities, but its a great opportunity to meet and greet those living in your commune besides your immediate neighbours.

post:
The shops will probably be closed - but check their doors, most put up opening hours posters.  There are always little shops around that are open for bread and milk etc.   
The Fetes de Genève will be on, so there will be lots to do.   
The buses and trains will probably be ok too.  Probably running on a "public holiday" schedule.  Which just means that they are not every 10 or fifteen minutes.  It depends where you live.  Just check the timetable at the bus stop or online at tpg.ch.

The Hermitage has some great exhibitions.    
She could combine it with an energetic uphill walk through the Sauvabelin woods, including walking up the Sauvabelin Tower.   
Or if photography interests her, the Elysee has Fellini at the moment  , and if going to the Elysee, it is easy to do the lovely Ouchy/Pully/Lutry walk along the lake.

I've been on the sleeper to Arnhem from Basel a few times. You don't really sleep on those things but they're comfy enough.   
Plenty of things to do in Amsterdam - but I recommend the first thing you do is take a boat tour of the canals as it does help you to get the lay of the land.   
The red light district is actually quite amusing to visit - even if you are female - just for the novelty of it. For museums, I think the Rijksmuseum (the Van Gogh was not my favourite) - or if you can handle it the Anne Frank.   
There are loads of great little bars and cafes around - my personal favourite is the Beijaard (   ) on Spui - if you like Belgian beers.

post: We took my brother-in-law up to the Jungfraujoch on Sunday. It was a bright sunny day and the views were simply outstanding. We really felt the altitude though, definitely light-headed.

If it's anything like a village off the beaten track which we once lived in, the drivers of the buses knew us - we lived there,  we paid our taxes there and were thus 'Einheimische' (local) and got a deduction in the fares on the local bus. The driver once joked that with our half-price cards, our children's cards (which were, at that time, free) and our 'Einheimische' deduction, he would soon have to be paying US to do the journey!

consider organising an event for the Tee Chee Massive to go to a grotto and cadge a lift there.   
Food is usually well-priced and you get an insight into the local eateries.   
My favourite grottos are in Montagnola and on San Salvatore.  Morchino is my favourite - the guy who bought it used to organise illegal parties there......

Travel to Biel / Bienne. Take the train to Twann, Ligerz or Cressier (towards Neuchatel), hike up to Chasseral which is at 1609 meters. 
The Twann Schlucht is a very beautiful gorge.    
Stay in chalet style hotel,   at Chasseral mountain top. They   take credit cards!    
Next day hike down the other side to St Imier. Take train back to Biel.   
Total hike is only 30 Km, but rather hilly! There is a sporadic Post Bus on the south side.

A friend of mine organises an annual cruise of custom (push)bikes round Luzern, city cruisers, lo riders and some real bizarre creations, come along if your like your bikes, you don't need to own one to join in, but you might want to give your bike a clean and the chrome a polish if you don't want to look too out of place.  Spectators welcome and some lovely bikes on display.   
Fun for all the family, the cruise kicks off around 15:00 at the bahnhof, I'm not sure of the exact route as I was hungover last year and missed it.

I've done this particular journey a few times, and it's quite a civilised way to travel, though it's slower and more expensive than flights (booked on the same date).  That said, you can always arrange to have a couple of hours in Paris for lunch if you fancy, which the airlines will never allow.   
I usually book through    
It's not very good at figuring out the connection in Paris, though.  The trick is to put in Zürich - Paris, select your trains, and when it gets to the "confirmation" screen, then go to the "add another ticket" bit at the bottom right, then sort out your Paris - London bit.  Once you've selected your trains, you can sort out payment and ticket delivery.  I don't think you can do the "collect from a machine" option at Zürich, but I have collected the Eurostar tickets at Paris Nord without trouble.   
For the uninitiated, you will need to get from Gare de l'Est to Gare du Nord in Paris.  They're quite close to each other, and if you are taking it easy, allow 20 minutes to get between them (but if you know the way and are a fast walker, you can do it in less).  Eurostar also requires you to check in 30 minutes before your train, but coming back, the Paris-Zürich train is just like any regular train, so I'd recommend allowing about an hour on the London bound direction for the connection, and about half an hour in the reverse direction to be on the safe side.   
I've it in both 1st and 2nd class, and would say that, unless you are a larger person who wants the extra seat room, there is no benefit going 1st.  Eurostar used to give you a nice meal and free booze in the cheap 1st class fares, but ticket changes last December changed that to some rubbish airline-style snack.   
If you get the 07.00 of Zürich HB, you can be in London at about 14.30 (UK time).  If you leave London at about 10.30, you can be back in Zürich by at about 19.30.  Luggage is usually not a problem (provided you can cary/wheel it between the stations in Paris), though I think bicycles require additional booking of limited spaces, but I've never tried that option myself.   
For more details, have a look at

The Vevey is not the first of this type of boat to be retired recently. When we took a CGN boat on Lake Geneva in late 2005 (maybe 2006), we learned that it was the boat's last voyage, it was called the Italia. There was a party atmosphere on board, with lots of people coming out for the trip, some of them dressed in Belle Epoque clothing.    
Many people had been on the boat all day and had already had quite a bit to drink. The captain even let a couple of people get on the microphone and they started singing some folk songs over the ship's loudspeakers. When we crossed paths with the regular boat to Evian, we stopped in the middle of the lake for a couple of minutes while the two captains honked at each other and everyone waved back and forth. At most ports that we stopped in, there were people (mainly fathers and sons) who had come out just to wave to the boat one last time.   
We were very lucky to have been on that voyage accidentally. If any of you get a chance to do so for the Vevey's last voyage then I certainly encourage you to do so.
thread: CGN call time on 'Vevey' on Lake Geneva

post:
Stayed here Friday night on a 'Tete a Tete' deal. 400chuffs, which included a 5 course evening meal, Lifestyle double room with city view and Sauna room + breakfast.    
First of all, no clear detail on their website about the fact you have to take a train to the top(i stand to be corrected) there is a carpark, but no details or signs/instructions on how you actually then get to Uto Kolm hotel from the carpark, luckily a helpful receptionist guided us up there.    
Basically take the train to (last stop) Uetliberg, on leaving the carriage in the middle of the platform follow the steps in front of you up the hill, keep going to the top!   
On arrival our checkin was swift and we were directed to our room. Room size was small, very clean and modern but minimal, barely enough to fit our beds in, we had a flat screen Sony TV which was positioned such that when the window was open it obscured the view of the TV.      
Popped to the restaurant for our meal to find no actual tables available in the front outside restaurant area, they had reserved us a table right at the back with a rather limited view and inside the building not outside, with a hanful of people seated, no atmosphere, which was a bit dissapointing. We of course requested we sit somewhere else, we managed to get a table just inside the building area, not outside still, but with a slighty better view and cooler.    
The meal itself was ok, i have to say it was pretty much hotel standard and not a good restaurant. Even though it was 5 courses the portions were just about ok, certainly not generous. So we asked for a few bread rolls on the way just to pack it out a bit! Service was good though, and friendly. (i rarely eat 3 course meal at home or we share a desert if we have starters!)   
Back to our room, to find it was still very hot, so looked for the air conditioning. None there, bearing in mind my 100chuff a night room in the holiday inn express had aircon i wasn't impressed! So we had the window wide open all night, which invited all the mosquitos in.   
Breakfast was very good, well presented and a very good range, including bacon and eggs. Couldn't fault breakfast v good.        
What i feel you're really paying for here is the view, i staggered up  the steel tower after a few more beers to watch the fireworks in the  town, an absolutely stunning view.    
All in all, nice but i wouldn't do that again. Id rather pop up for a normal meal in the restaurant, prebooked out the front. And enjoy the view then head home.    
Pros: Fabulous view from room and restaurant if you're seated in the right place, nice lively atmosphere in the evening(only outside though).   
Cons: Small rooms, No airconditioning, no shuttle service to the hotel. And no clear directions. Restaurant set course forgettable. Cost seemed high for what it was, although im quite fresh from the UK ferry still (6weeks) so im still sensitive to prices here!      Having 2 nippers of our own we noticed a few  gaps around the perimeter where an 'untethered' 2year old could easily  slip through and then fall a long way down. Keep nippers close to hand.

post:
From Delemont to Herisau, I completed my own personal 26 canton challenge on Monday when I hiked over the Surenenpass and visited Stans, the capital of Niwalden, on my way home which was the last piece of the puzzle. It took me one month and I saw every cantonal capital, plus did tons of hiking and visited other towns that I was interested in.   
In the end, my favorite canton was probably Uri.   
I learned a lot about this nation and its history along the way. It's amazing how diverse Switzerland is for such a small territory. In the end, I think that's what surprised me the most. Even though I have traveled here before moving, seeing each canton really makes you appreciate the differences a lot more.

Although Indian painters were celebrated as “wonders of their age” by  their contemporaries, for a long time very little was known about their  lives. There are no Indian equivalents of sources such as Vasari’s  biographies of European Renaissance artists. The fact that artistic  traditions were shaped within a family, a workshop, or a court, adds to  the difficulty of attributing works to individual artists.   
Thanks to many years of painstaking research, the deciphering of  microscopically small signatures, analyses of pilgrim registers, and,  especially, stylistic comparisons, more is now known. For example, about  Farrukh Beg, who painted in Iran, in Kabul, Lahore, Bijapur, and Agra,  or the brothers Manaku and Nainsukh who, despite their joint training in  their father‘s workshop, differ significantly in style.

post: Sorry, on the other side of the country, but it sounds like fun. Good initiative. I hope you get a whole pile of riders to come out.

Just look the connections on   it's all there. I don't reserve seats, I would however just go to a station near you and just tell them the train you want.   
Normal connection, every second hour: 
Coming from Basel. train in Zürich, 
then Zürich - Chur 
over to Rhätische Bahn Chur - Samedan (direction is Skt Moritz) 
Samedan change train to Pontresina, go to track 1 
In Pontresina, the train to Tirano is waiting onthe opposite track.   
It takes more time to go to Skt Moritz and then wait there for the train to Tirano, but you may enjoy a little walk by the lake.    
It's perfectly organized, just follow the flow... the line is touristy, announcements are made in English too. Enjoy also the ones in Romansh :-)

Ahhh Springtime! Everything is green and lush and flowery, the air is fresh and the world is reborn, the thoughts of young men turn to the willowy freshness of young women, mine however were trying to ignore a sore back. 
I had spent Saturday on the banks of the Rhine in Basel with my feet in the water doing the dirty old man thing watching the bikini-clad chicks flout their stuff. 
Laying on the hard ground had done my back in. 
Time to grab the bike go for a ride and get some other thoughts in my head, by now the beemer has 230.000 Klicks on the clock and after last winter she is has accumulated quite a bit of patina, the gaskets in the front fork are banjaxed and she is leaking oil allover the front brakes, the good thing is that they no longer squeak, the exhaust has a hole somewhere, the brake-pads are down and I think she needs a new cable on the clutch. 
Spares have been ordered from BMW but delivery is not for another three weeks. 
Oh poop! 
Silly me, I always thought I lived in Europe and not Outer Mongolia.   
But I have never been one to waste a perfectly good riding day, so come eight we bubbled (rather loudly) onto the motorway heading north. 
I did not have any plan and just followed the front wheel, it asked me if I wanted a coffee, I said "yes" and we set course for Colmar just over the border in France. 
In my minds eye I saw myself sitting at an outside table in the main square with a coffee a basket of Croissants whilst reading the International herald tribune to the sound of a motorbike leaning at a jaunty angle on it´s side stand, ticking gently as it cooled down. 
Just how bohemian is that?       
Nice pictures indeed, and on the side of the cathedral is a top-notch medieval WTF   
And we think today´s priests are weird   
Colmar is a wonderful medieval town but there is the worm in this otherwise quaint half timbered apple. The first thing that I saw was a tourist carrier in the shape of a choo-choo train, a fat Germany guy wearing shorts and a (very) loud unbuttoned shirt, he was trying to talk to the driver, "Parleez voo Deutsch?" at the same time complaining to his wife that nobody speaks the Deutsch. 
I cringed into my coffee wishing the bugger would go away and stop ruining my morning. 
Too late. 
Finishing my coffee I grabbed the bike and bubbled off following a sign that proclaimed Touts directions, or "that a way" 
A bit later I saw a sign for the Wine road, I turned right and went to the Vogese mountains.     
On the way up, following the wine road.   
Getting there   
Yeh! At the top   
Looking over the rhine valley, bad tongues will say that the fault-line is France´s way of getting away from Germany.   
Everybody knows the black forest, the cuckoo clocks and the Dirndl local clothing with the three red pompoms on the hat, Grimm´s fairytales and all that guff. 
If you think that the Rhine valley is actually a fault line in the earths crust, to the east is the black forrest and over the plane of the valley to the west is the mirror image of the Vogese mountains. 
A mirror image but without the tacky tourist tat, empty open long winding roads, through leafy forrest, this is BMW LT country.   
I love to drive slowly down roads like this, so slow in fact that the bugs get time to veer out of my path. I killed the engine and coasted down in silence, the closest to flying that you will ever get. 
I headed to the Ballon d´ Alsace, a 1171 meters or 3.842 ft high mountain, the highest in the area. 
Up until now I have lived in the eastern part of CH, with all the pointy bits just a half hours ride away there, people have a somewhat robust idea of hight, so I tend to regard anything under 1000 meters as a speedbump. 
Slammer´s alpine motto: "I get my kicks above the tree-line sunshine!" 
The Vogese are different I must admit, but every bit as enjoyable to ride as the switchbacks and hairbends of the high passes. 
The ballon d´ Alsace offers a 360° view of central Europe, the air was clear and I could see the Alps  in the distance and the valleys and fields below. Every meter traveled was enjoyable. 
I flashed past a stone. 
Something had caught the corner of my eye, a few hundred meters on I stopped and turned back. 
It was a memorial stone.. 
..On the 2nd of December 1944 a Halifax bomber took off from Skipton, she dropped her load south of Essen, most likely the aircraft was hit by FLAK, unable to keep hight she crashed killing all but one of the crew, who later died of his injuries. 
Things like this stele make me realize that people like the owners of the names on the stone created a world where my wonderful children, British-German, maybe the best of both worlds, can exist in peace. 
Somebody cares enough to put fresh flowers down by the stone, it faces the Rhine valley over one thousand meters below.     
No words.   
I rode on, somehow I must have gotten a draft around my visor because my eyes had gotten moist, the sky seemed more intensive blue, the grass greener, the air clearer. 
Surely there where giants in them days.
Thanks that's just the sort of thing I was looking for  . I'm sure that my OH and I will really enjoy it

Basically for those of you who like cycling, blading, walking, running, etc... (no motor vehicles) the SlowUp (Swiss translated from SlowDown) is a circuit on the mainroads when once per year these roads are closed to cars and open to pedestrians with non-motorized means of traveling. The link above provides details, dates and areas. (Fr,Ge,It).   
Our SlowUp (down), is the 26th of April which circles the lake of Murten. No entry fee, lots of train/tram stops, loads of people, and many snack / drink bars along the way, distance is 32 kms if you go all the way around. Bikes can be rented locally.   
Maybe see you there since our house/office is just off the main road field, look for the Canadian/British/Swiss flags..

post:
What are you interested in seeing? There is so much to see and do in Basel during the day, it is really tough to simply pick and choose for someone else.    
If you like enjoying "nature", I like the Basel Zoo, also, Lange Erlen is / has sort of a mini-zoo with mostly local wildlife, both provide some nice stroll with interesting view. If you prefer fewer caged animals, Grün 80 is also a nice stroll, more of a garden / green area with walking paths.   
There are many many museums in Basel, so it should be pretty easy to "get your culture on"     
Ueli and Unser are both local beers, one (or perhaps both?) of the brewing companies have a brewhouse with bar / restaurant attached. I'd say for someone visiting Basel particularly, this is something of a "must" - although as my hubby is a Basler (and non-drinker), I've not been. I HAVE been to Lolle König (literally, the tongue king) restaurant, there is a story behind the name and the placement of the restaurant I believe, so also definitely worth a visit.   
If you're not adverse to going slightly further afield, rather than in Basel "proper", I was taken to Augusta Raurica when I visited prior to my move. I was quite impressed by the "living history" there.     
Anyhow, just a few ideas to get you started, hopefully some of the others who get out and about more locally will have some other ideas. (My hubby and m-i-l tend to want to go away from Basel  )

I've lived in basel for 3 months and love it.  Met lots of nice people (and very few not-nice people).  You can find bars, clubs, salsa dancing, cinema, up-market, down-market, red light etc etc. and all within a 5 min tram ride.   
Maybe I've just been lucky but I don't recognise the comments about being difficult to make friends or Basel being boring (and I come from London so its not as if I am dazzled by the bright lights.... )

But if you can't afford the time (or hotel/hostel!) then go for a day trip rather than not go at all.   
Take an early train, but spread your activities out once you arrive.  If you go straight from Zermatt station to the cable car, to the gondola, up to the top of Klein Matterhorn (for the view and/or the glacier cave) expect to get some altitude problems.  So ... late breakfast in Zermatt first.

For those who haven't done so, I'd recommend signing up for the Swiss Newsletter.       
If the link is rubbish, select it on "Quick Links" of the main   page. 
Note: You must be in "Switzerland", not in the UK.   
I predict more of these " ", most likely on other Basel Routes. 
It's going to be a "hot" summer as Swiss fight Easyjet.   
Trust me on that...
feldberg is great if you ski but very boring if you dont.............go to engelberg

Hertz has cars from the airport (French side) on a Sunday.  Prices start from about EUR100- for the day.     
In this case, cheaper to rent from the Swiss side.  Same dates, cars start at CHF109- for a prepaid rental, 120- for a pay-on-return rental.   
Cars rented from the Swiss side have the added advantage of having a vignette.  French cars won't have one, as a rule.

Hey, yeah everything closes at around 6, anyway, if you wanna do some night shopping, you should try the Piccadily in Viganello(gas station mini-market), right next to Coop in Viganello.   
Then you have the Piccadily in Molino Nuovo, at the gas station, nearby the cementery.   
Then there's the Aperto(changed names a couple years ago, I dont know the new name), but it's the mini market at the train station.   
All of these close at 10 o'clock and all of these are more expensive then regular markets and some charge more for alcohol after 6 o'clock...   
You're better off doing your grocery shopping before 6 and if you didn't know already, on thursdays, shops close a bit later, 7-9, depending which one and where.

Have you tried Aquaparc at Bouveret for a day out. I think they still have a McD inside the park for the kids.  
It should be no more than 2Hr drive from Basel

Finally made it to Lenzerheide yesterday, and can only endorse what Eire and others say about price and crowds. We had a twofer ticket from Coop, so two days passes only cost 75 francs (including 5 francs chip fee).    
The main draw I think is how large, spread out and varied it is, and we only skied a tiny part of it. No crowds whatsoever on the Rothorn side despite beautiful sunny weather, though we set out a bit later in the morning. We were told the slopes would fill up during the afternoon as skiers came over from the west side, where apparently it doesn't stay sunny as long. They did, but still not what you could call crowded.   
If you're on a budget, the half-off of food with a Halbtax or GA at self-service restaurants is very nice too. All in all, thumbs up--I really wish I were there today as well.

You can't go wrong with Murren or Wengen. Both are up in the mountains and absolutely beautiful. We went to Murren with an elderly lady and did a short hike and she had no problem at all. 
If money is no object you should definitely see the Jungfrau Joch. 
Be prepared to spend quite a lot of time in cable cars and trains if you want to stay in Interlaken and get up in the mountains.

Finding very little about the Fondation Bayeler on EF, I wanted to tell you about my enjoyable visit there. I was in the Basel area last week (dropping off relatives at the Basel Mulhouse Freiburg Euroairport) and decided to visit the Segantini exhibition at the Fondation Bayeler. There is an underground car park right opposite the museum, which is in a small town/suburb just outside Basel. The exhibition was great and we saw some of the permanent collection (part was closed for rearranging). I very much liked the building with the rooms full of natural light from above and some rooms looking out on to the small lake with lovely grounds outside. After viewing the collection we had a cup of tea in the cafe and found the staff helpful.   
Not a destination for small children but a great place for art lovers.   
The Segantini exhibition continues until April 25th.

I recently interviewed a candidate from the States, and he came over with his wife to look around.  I was surprised at her itinerary, because it looked a lot like yours.     
If I had a short visit to Basel, my list of things to see would be very different.  I wouldn't bother with most of the tourist sites (they'll still be here when you move back).  Instead, I'd spend my time visiting things that would help me understand whether I would be happy living here.   
It's a somewhat unusual itinerary, but I would spend some time browsing a grocery store, getting an idea for what's available and what I'll miss from home.  I'd go to the local tourist office and ask about things to do on the weekend.  I'd visit the community park, swimming pool, ice rink, etc to see what's available for leisure time.  I'd ride the trams to get a sense of the city and its scale.   
If you're coming to Basel, you might even rent a car and drive across the border.  There's a lot available just over the border in St. Louis (France) and Lorrache & Weil-am-Rhein (Germany) that won't be on your relocation tour.  Cross-border shopping can make a significant impact on your cost-of-living, so it's worth getting a feel for.   
Finally, if you have any question about how the tax system, health insurance, retirement plans, etc work, now is the time to ask them -- you and your husband could schedule time with the interviewing company's HR department to answer just such questions.   
If, after all this, you've still got time on your hands, then wander the town and hit the tourist sights!

post: Go to Bern. Head immediately into travel/info office in the train station. Tell them you'd like to take the ipod walking tour of Bern in English. (Bring your own headphones/earbuds). Take as much time as needed and discover the whole town including tidbits of history and lore. If I recall, it's incredibly cheap, though there's a deposit on the ipods. Finish tour. Return ipod, get deposit back. Go home. One day done and enjoyed, from the bears to the rose garden, various fountains, evidence of the only shot fired on the city, the reasons for the two bridges, etc. You can pause at any time to explore more or take a meal or coffee. I did this with my sister when she was in town and it was her favorite part as we explored areas I'd never seen in the couple years living near Bern. There's also one in Zurich. Lather. Rinse. Repeat.

Thanks for all the tips.  I think we will try Verbier as many people have mentioned that both on EF and in person.   
We did plan a multi-day mid-week trip to Zermatt and then take the Glacier express to St. Moritz (might as well, I have the GA and he the swiss pass so its almost free).  Will be doing 2 days of skiing (me) and boarding (my friend) in Zermatt.  We were hoping to do some in St. Moritz as well but hotels are CRAZY expensive there even mid-week.  For example our 3 nights in Zermatt were only about the same as one night in St. Moritz.   
After that we are going to try one of the local recommendations ... I'm hoping for snow, forecasters are saying snow local on Tues and Wed, but then I have already seen in just a couple weeks of being here how off the forecasts are here    
Oh for skill.. I don't know how it equates in switzerland.  I usually ski single black diamonds or more interesting blue runs in the US but stay away from chutes and I'll do moguls only once in a while cause I'm "old" now and not so good at them so I get tired (use them more of an excuse to justify fondue AND dessert).  My friend is hard to judge, he has 4 yrs or so experience but he is very fearful of getting hurt so no matter the terrain he goes very slow.  He prefers off-piste but defined runs or days when the piste runs have powder on top (I know, a rare combo and probably not going to find good stuff like that this year).   
See you on the slopes!

Thanks for the suggestions everyone. We spent 2 nights in Colmar this week. We stayed at the Mercure Colmar Champ de Mars which was good as it enabled us to get connecting rooms. Nothing special about the hotel, typical Mercure, but it is located within easy walking distance to the old town of Colmar and is situated on a large park with playground for the kids and an old-school Carrousel. Colmar is a nice little city for walking around.   
Second day we drove from Colmar to Freiburg and then up into the Black Forest. We drove by Titisee and Schluchsee and then had lunch at the Rothaus Brewery. Good food and good beer. Walking around the brewery grounds was nice. We drove back to Colmar via some winding forest roads to Mullheim and then back on the main roads. Countless hiking trails in the area: mainly just forest strolls but a nice contrast to the alps.   
On the way home, we drove through some beautiful little towns in the 
Colmar area: Ingersheim, Niedermorschwihr, Turckheim, Zimmerbach, Wintzenheim and Eguisheim. Walked around and had lunch in Eguisheim which was very cool.    
A few photos:   
Colmar                   
Rothaus Brewery           
Eguisheim             
Overall, a good trip. Easy to do with 3 young kids and dogs. Could easily spend several days in the area. This time of the year was nice as there was nobody around. When the kids get older, we'll have to head back with bikes as well. Reminds me of the Napa/Sonoma region of California only with much nicer towns.
Some links worth checking out:
South of France: Camargue, Provence, Cevennes.. If that sounds interresting to you, -> PM, I could give you quite some good tips for that region.

Never went there again.

It is pretty certain that there will still be a considerable amount of snow around, especially along the northern sections.   
This is the Bernina road pass last April       
As well as the Bernina Express trains, there are the scheduled trains that you could transfer to. These don't have the Panorama coaches though and you wouldn't have a reserved seat.   
If you break your journey, it would almost certainly mean that you would not be able to undertake the whole Bernina Express route. Chur-Tirano is over four hours each way.   
Your realistic options would be to either just travel part of the route, or get an overnight stop on the way.    
If you haven't done the Bernina route before, I would opt for the full route without a stop, or find overnight accommodation

Some things our guests have loved that are not too far from Olten:   
1.  Gruyere, including the H.R. Geiger Alien bar and the chateau, short bus trip up to Moleson for fondue and picture taking, tour (very short, yet very interesting) of the Gruyere cheese factory.   
2.  Train to Gstaad, walk around village, ogle at rich people, fondue at one of the fabulous restaurants.  Other nearby villages to see, Chateau D'Oex, Rougemont.   
3.  Walk along the lakefront in Lausanne, visit the Olympic Museum, take the Metro to Lausanne Flon, eat at Le Nomade or Kai Zen in the city center.  Take the Metro one stop further to Bessiere, walk across the bridge (multiple photo ops) and up to the "Old Town" around the cathedral.

OK, I am not saying that you are not telling us the truth, but that sounds very strange. Airlines can't just refuse to accept responsibility for damage if it was caused negligently. But, is there something you are not telling us? Just how loyal a flyer are you by the way? What colour FF card do you have?   
This passage comes from the Swiss website:         
The air carrier is liable for destruction, loss or damage to baggage up to 1'131 SDRs (approximate amount in local currency). In the case of checked baggage, it is liable even if not at fault, unless the baggage was defective. In the case of unchecked baggage, the carrier is liable only if at fault.

You may have trouble finding an   place up by the lifts for one Saturday night, but near us is the Bergheim Hotel. I know they have rooms that sleep up to 4 or 5 people and I seem to remember that they are very cheap. Unfortunately you would have to get the bus from the hotel to the lifts and the last one down is at about 8pm.... the hotel is located at the Bergheim hairpin at about 1100m.   
Otherwise, think about staying at Untertezen and getting the long cable car up from Wallensee in the morning.

There are several options and it depends a little on what you want to do and on your budget.    
One option would be exploring Switzerland. As you life close to Zurich that could easily be done from home which means you could spend the nights at home and spend the money safed (meaning not spent for hotels) on other things. Depending on what you've already done you could go to see Lucerne ( ?), the Zoo in Zurich ( ), the Technorama in Winterthur ( ), the children museum in Baden ( ), the Alpamare in Pfäffikon ( ). You could go ice-skating in Zurich or Zug or you could "to the mountains" for some walking or to go sledging. There are many option within easy access (even by train). For children I would suggest Braunwald or Elm maybe Hoch-Ybrig or Flumserberg (but check if there is enough snow for sledging). Braunwald has a nice Kinderhotel more info  . But note: all these places might get crowded as everyone is on vacation...   
Another option would be to go outside of Switzerland. Just walk into one of the Hotelplan (should also offer Migros-Reisen or M-Budget Ferien) or Kuoni or TUI travel agencies they might be able to provide you with ideas. Also Aldi and Coop have flyers with offers.    
Enjoy the first holiday here!

post:
Yes, it is do-able and not too difficult with careful planning.   
A few tips: 
--get one of these to help in travel, a very useful investment  www.lillygold.com     --a lot will depend on the age&temperment of your children.  We tried to avoid such long airtravel when child(ren) were between 1.5 and 3 years, the worst age to travel in our experence.  Younger and older were better ages to fly.   
--search and get direct routes when at all possible, even extending a terminal drive in car by a few hours to avoid another shorthaul flight.  Connections are always problematic and high risk of missing connecting flight, avoid at all costs.   
--search airport play areas or places to let off steam in advance.  Plan to go there during stop-overs, delays, etc. and make them run around during that time, they will then sleep more during travel.  Ditto for getting out to play before leaving for airport.   
--preparation and plan ahead, ie. read books to young children about flying to get them used to the idea, pack activities and comfort objects, bring snacks and non-messy finger foods.

They have completely flat runs for absolute nubies, and then two or three easy slopes for people who want to branch out from their snow-plow stances to a more parallel stance.   
Highly recommend.

I think the tourism website   offers exactly what you're looking for. They have access to a MASSIVE database of holiday homes and apartments throughout the country; it includes all the listings from Reka, Interhome and e-Domizil, and private listings too. Their search function is also highly useful: not only can you refine your search based on the obvious things (region of the country, rental location [in a village, on a lake, in the countryside, etc.]), you can also discriminate based on more specific needs you may have, such as wheelchair accessibility, acceptability of pets, swimming pool... etc.   
This is the largest database for holiday accommodation in Switzerland I've found so far. Hopefully you can find what you need for a great holiday.   
HeatherM

post:
Ah indeed it seems so, didn't know about that one.  Once a day -- departing Neuchâtel at 9:10 AM.  Also arrives at Paris Gare de Lyon though, so you still have to make the way through the city to Gare du Nord.  And coming to Gare de Lyon at 13:03, you are going to just miss by a short while the Eurostar leaving Gare du Nord at 13:04.   
Still not bad.  Taking this service, you can then continue with the Eurostar departing Paris at 15:13 to arrive in London at 16:36.  That's a total of 8h26m, including plenty of time for changing over in Paris and getting even a proper meal there.  Great if you have acquaintances there you can arrange to meet for an hour and a half.        Do you know of any other operator taking passengers through the tunnel? 
Of course others operate cargo trains, and Eurotunnel itself operates the shuttle for car transport.  But as far as I know Eurostar is the only passenger service.   
According to   last year, it will be opened up for competition though, and the competitor might be Deutsche Bahn.   
  -- Tom

post:
Check the other recent skiing threads -many resorts for easy Geneva access. 
French side: La Clusaz nearest I think, Morzine, Les Gets, Avoriaz= Portes du Soleil. Or Portes du Soleil resorts from Swiss side : Torgon nearest with access to Chatel, super Chatel, then Morgins, Champery/Les Crozets (from there ski down to Avoriaz), Villars, Leysin, Verbier 4 Vallées (cheaper to access from Veysonnaz, Thyon 2000, or Haute Nendaz. All great resorts with their own character. Geneva-La Clusaz 56 mins according to tcs.ch. I like La Clusaz because it is a real small town, rather than just a resort.   
You've also got the Jura- much cheaper and great for day trips. But check the snow levels, as they are much lower altitude. StCroix/Les Rasses, Metabief/Jougne, ans so many others.

Everyone and their dog want to deal in real estate, especially in a "hot" area such as Lake Como (and yeah - it's all George and Giorgio's fault, LOL). 
Ideally the best thing would be to go through the for sale adverts in the newspapers and look for anything with "No intermediari" (i.e. no middlemen) or "No Agenzie" (i.e. no real estate firms), which implies that the owner prefers a direct P-2-P sale.

post:
Hello from southern Ticino :-)   
The Biasca region...hmmm. 
You will definitely like Val di Blenio, there's plenty of hikes up to the dams (Diga del Luzzone), and up to the Lucomagno (Lukmanier) pass. 
In Olivone you may have some chance of finding cozy accomodation (and good food!) at the Osteria Centrale ( ).   
In the Airolo region, you will want to hike/walk up the Val Bedretto and the Nufenen pass. An amazing variety of cheeses are produced up there by the way. I have never slept in Airolo / Bedretto so I cannot recommend any hostels firsthand, sorry.   
Do not miss the Ritom lake - a panoramic cablecar will take you up, and then it's up to your legs ;-)   
You might be able to find bike rent in Airolo @ the sports shops.   
If you need anything else pls feel free to drop me a line!   
Paul

Having travelled across most of Switzerland, the only places that I wouldn't be in a hurry to visit again have been the 'up-market' resorts of Davos, St. Moritz and Verbier.     
As towns they have little to offer in themselves in the way of Swiss individuality.  I would only consider them as stopping points for other attractions in the area.  I am sure that they have their fans here, particularly among the winter sports enthusiasts.   
Switzerland is such a diverse country that you are likely to find something of interest wherever you go.

post:
I went to the one in Charmey about 4 years ago. However I arrived a tad late and was queueing in traffic up to the village just when a load of cows were running down the road, and one managed to drag its cow bell over my bonnet, leaving a lovely scratch and a dent.   
When I rang the insurance company (Zurich) and explained, they said no problem, they get dozens of claims for cow damage this time every year. 
At the end of the cow running day, there were an awful lot of cars parked along the main road out of Charmey with dents, scratches and mirrors hanging off.   
It's a great event, well worth seeing.  
For Charmey, arrive early and don't park on the main road though. 
It's also very, very busy.

post:
I would agree with the more recent posters. The lake route is not really by the lake. There are some charming villages to negotiate (Coppet, Nyon, Rolle) but there's not much of a view and you can't see the lake. Nearly all the way the strip of land between the road and the lake is wooded private property with villas and chateaux. And there are some rather miserable bits as well: the charm of la cote shopping warehouse area anyone?    
The autoroute out of Geneva is quite scenic (so long as the traffic is moving) and you get good views of the French Alps and the Jura. Then take the route vignoble and you get superb views across the lake.

From what I understand Mystery park closed down some time ago. You can still see the tacky completely foreign looking buildings there. Yes the cheap commercialism really irritated me as well. I guess money is king.    
My original roots are in the Himalayas and I personally feel at home in Switzerland as far as nature is concerned. What I find most amazing is that mountains back home were in the 7000-8000+ meters region compared to Jungfrau which is only 3500-4158 meters high   Jungfrau does not even feature in the top 100 highest mountain peaks of the world    
As far as access is concerned Jungfrau probably wins hands down. Definitely an amazing engineering feat! Once we got on the actual glacier the typical tourist crowd disappeared. We walked for hours on the ice away from all the Bollywood and Japanese/Chinese/Korean crowd. Bless them all but we wanted peace and quiet with mother nature.    
I am still very ill and stuck to bed. Fever is not in the 40°C region anymore but still constantly around 38.5°C. Feel like a wreck and dizzy all the time

Get a Zuri card (20 CHF) its gets you free travel on the network and a host of discounts   Walks, to get a view of the city and if it’s a sunny day, head down to Zurichhorn (by tram or car) and then walk along the lake side park to Belleview (it will take 30 mins approx) You get wonderful views of the lake and the city a s you walk up. With a few places to stop and get a drink. If it’s a weekend or evening you get to see a lot of the locals and sample a bit of Zurich atmosphere.     For culture, head town to the Kuntshaus  , its has all the big names, Picasso, Monet, Van Gough. Plus its free with a Zuri Card and about 10mins walk from Belleview     Of course the old town and Utilberg are worth looking up too.     Things in my view to avoid:   1)  The landesmuseum (or Swiss National Musem) you can go and walk around the court yard for free, which is good. But inside I found it rather sterile and noting of significance (especially compared to the British Museum etc al)   2)  Langstrasse (RLD) a lot of tourist books give the impression that’s it’s the edgy/ bohemian part of town and, but in reality if you are looking for that then you are in the wrong town and it just a bit dirty and grim. Useful place for a large pub crawl.   3)  Buy gifts from the shiny shops in Bahnhofstrasse, most things are way cheaper in Migro/Coop and of the same quality, actually my family prefer the chocolates from Coop rather then the swanky stuff I used to get from spungli!

If you want to get up into the mountains fairly cheaply I'd recommend heading to Villars, because the lifts are free for those under 6 and then only 10SF a day for a pass for adults and over 6s.  Our usual walk up there (done with a 4 yr old) is to park at the cable car Roc d'Orsay and take that up to the top, where there are great views of Mt Blanc and Dents du Midi, then walk down to the station (a streep but wide path) and carry on to first the Lac de Bretaye, then the Lac de Chavonnes (good spot for a picnic)  Then it's around the lake for a bit of a steep climb towards Perche, and traverse back to the station, where you can take the mountain train down again.  The whole walk is about 5 - 6km long and should take 3 hours of walking time at slow child pace, but the scenary is great and the kids love the cable car and the train.  If you have time (and energy) left after that, your pass also covers the swimming pool in Villars and mini golf and the ride-on train in Gryon.   
Alternatively in the other direction, Moleson is great too, as Ittigen suggested - take the funi up for 10SF and come down via les cles.  It's a 2 hour walk at child pace, and our daughter loves the toboggan at the end.  It's 6SF a go for adults, but if you can find the "idees-loisirs" vouchers they give away at tourist offices and other attractions, you can get 2 tickets for the price of one.

post: The waldenburg hike was great! We just got back. We saw llamas, cows, sheep, goats, waterfalls, etc. The restaurant at the top of the mountain was good too. Their sausage was homemade and well worth the trip. On the way down you have 3 choices: the cable cars, renting mountain scooters (basically just scooters fitted with sturdier wheels and hand breaks) or walking. We walked and were so glad we did. We would have never seen the waterfalls if we had taken the cable cars. We then walked through a town before we picked up the bus. A few of the houses sell homemade jams, cider, and syrups. All in all a very fun day.

I think the interesting part is that you have access to the Dufour maps (1850s), the Siegfried maps (1890s), and the current maps on top of each other.  
It is interesting (at least for me) to see the expansion of cities, villages that have disappeared, names that have changed, the diminishing size of glaciers etc...

thread: Hotel tips in and around Geneva

post: And all hotels now give the free public transport pass for your stay as well.

Firstly, enjoy as it is a great and wonderful place in both summer and winter. Depending on how much time you have and how inclined you ar to enjoy the outdoors you can squeeze it in to one day, or enjoy several days.     
I have stayed in the Hoheneck (cheap & cheerful), Sonnwendhof (good with access to the Ramada pool and facilities, so value for money) and the Ski Lodge (fun and occasionally offering deals). So the best bet is to scout the internet for some deals.        
Loads of people go just for the day and head up to the Titlis. However you miss some of the beauty of the place and a lot more that there is on offer.     
Great beginner Via Ferrata for those inclined to easy and fun climbs. From the Brunnihutte and you can hire kit from Intersport in town for 25CHF for the day.       Markers with easy-to-understand information on the flora found at the foot of the Titlis, on a variety of flower species and on how they thrive.  
Details: easy, 1260/1760 m, ¾ h. My top tip here though is to walk down from the lake to the untertrubsee and then you can hire Trotti bikes (like a robust scooter) for ~5-7chfs. Then instead of walking the last bit to the village you can free-wheel back to the bottom. Great fun and I have seen ages 8-62 enjoy!      The tickle trail by the top station of the Brunni chairlift offers a special kind of thrill. The barefoot path round the idyllic “Härzlisee”, at 1860 metres above sea level, is unique in the mountains. Over a 220 m route nature can be experienced at close hand and your general well-being enhanced. It only take 30 min to walk the last bit and the going is easy so you can skip the chairlift if you are feeling fit & healthy. A walk up to the Brunnhutte from the village is probably 2-3hrs depending on fitness and you can always take the lift down again!     
Still plenty of nice places to eat during the evening, so not totally closed like some smaller resorts during the summer.   
Go for it and enjot!
Probably the nearest guaranteed snow at Titlis. The snow line was at around 2500m a couple of weks ago. By the time yo get to the top at 3000m it is like winter

This   14th-15th August isn't really folklore in its original sense, but given the venue and the background, the bells and the flags, it isn't an ordinary 'day out' either.   
Great fun to watch and be part of. Take something to sit on (on the grass slope); if the weather is sunny, take sun-cream, plenty to drink and a sun-shade.   
If you walk to the hill from the station along the Alp Stream at the back of the houses and someone says something about 'private'. Don't jump to the conclusion that he is complaining. It might be the same guy who talked to us last year. We thought for a moment that he was moaning about us going using his private path - actually he was apologising that this was his private path and he should have swept it better!    
Have fun.

post:
Possibly the beach and islands that have been built on the shore of Urnersee from the basistunnel excavations just at the mouth of the Reuss. You can get there by parking behind Fluelen station then follow the footpath signs for the swiss way. There is a wide rocky beach for a few hundred metres, childrens play area, several bbq spots and a further 20 minutes walk to the restaurant at Seedorf. Great place to take the kids for a day.    
Or just get the train to Fluelen its an easy flat walk with kids that would take about 40 minutes.   
see link and associated PDF for details, I can't think of anywhere else from your description but it seems a long way to travel to Fluelen from Hunenberg for a kindergarten trip.. Good Luck!

A few of my friends and I are thinking about booking a chalet for a weekend in the Lauterbrunnen area for a group of 10-12 people. The idea is to go hiking/cycling/rafting in the mountains and be surrounded by scenic views. Based on some initial research, it seems that Lauterbrunnen/Interlaken would be a good place to go. We are planning on going either over July 23rdor July 31st weekend, or will end up postponing the trip until first week of September. I have a few questions and would appreciate help from you guys on the same!   
1) Renting the Chalet - Is there a website that lists rentals for such a large group? I tried googling it but most of the cabins/apartments I find cater to a group of 4-6 people. Is it too ambitious to expect to find something for 10-12 of us?   
2) Weather: It's about 80F in Zurich, so I'm expecting Lauterbrunnen to be around 65F (I believe that's around 20C?), would this be correct? If we do push the trip back to September, what kind of weather should we be expecting?    
Thanks in advance - may come back with a couple of other questions as we get closer to picking a date and figuring out all the different things we want to do there

post:
It depends on 1) your driving skills and 2) where you go.    
Some of the Autovia's I've been on are literally "whiteknuckle" experiences. I remember driving to Genova and then Livorno and overtaking hundreds of trucks whilst weaving up/down a mountain is not for the faint hearted. I'm a good driver and it was a small challenge for me.   
Parking in Rome and Milan etc is a nightmare. City car parks are not as expensive as you think though and if you find hotels with FREE (or relatively cheap 10-20Euro/night) parking then I'd drive as long as ur confident with your ability.    
The main reason to drive is the cost compared to the train/plane option. But its horses for courses...... take care and enjoy   
PS hire a scooter in Rome, its an amazing experience - when in Rome blah blah. I take no responsibility for ur safety though as its a personal risk thingy.

You can pick up a train to get to the bottom of the Glacier 3000 lift from either Aigle or Montreux. I don't know the journey via Gstaad, you need to catch the post bus, but they are similar times. You could go up one way and back the other. The Postbus runs from Gstaad to Diablerets via the pass Col-du-Pillon.       
Set the departure as Montreux or Aigle, and destination Glacier 3000   
At Diablerets there is a Postbus which stops next to the station, and takes  11 minutes to the cable car.

Agreed, the Niesen has an awesome Panoramma.   
If you have a car you can make the Jungfrau cheaper by driving to Grindelwald.   
If you're up for a hike do First then walk to the Faulhorn then down to Busalp then down to Grindi, that would be a pretty cheap day I think.   
But for me the Jungfrau is awesome and a once in a life time thing. If you can walk from there to the Munch hutte - extends the day and they do great soup!
Leave the car and rent a bike. Bodensee's got lovely bikeways and it's all flat ... !

post:
Here some tips for travelling in Switzerland. Something that I had liked to read when I arrived here.   
If you want to travel around Switzerland during your stay here, it's good that you think 2 thinks, when are you gonna travel and how often. If you are thinking on travelling to all the famous and nice cities of the country (recommended) it's worth that you buy the halbtax card. It can be also interesting that you buy the Gleis 7. However as I said, all depends on where are you gonna travel. those cards seem to be very useful, nevertheless if you have no fixed dates for your trips you could just wait for the offer. In that case it's good to know that during some periods, sbb puts the Supersaver tickets where the price different between have or not to have halbtax is pretty small.  Also the daypass tickets which price changes in time are really good. With them you can travel wherever you want and as many times as you wish during 24 h. Some weeks ago I went with my friends to Interlaken and we decided once over there to go also up to the mountains. the ones without halbtax nor Gleis 7 bought the daypass and the could go around the mountain and the city for 45 ch (daypass price on that date) however in my case, having halbtax and gleis 7 I had to pay 48 ch without going even to the very top of the mountain and having the limitation of coming back only after 7.   
So summarizing get to know about every option before you buy your tickets. Personally I didn't take profit of them.

post:
We have been to Dubai 3 times and I think you should definitely get out of the airport. Anyone staying in the Dubai airport for 19 hrs is crazy -- there is nothing to do. You have to go through customs anyways.   
Yes it's hot, but so what. Stay inside. The cabs are cheap and will take you anywhere you want to go. Want to check out Palm Island and see The Atlantis Hotel, the cabs will take you there. Want to check out the largest mall in the world, the cabs will take you there. The malls are amazing, more decor and thought put into the design than anything I have ever seen in my life. Want to eat amazing food for cheap, this is the place. Go to Jumeriah Mosque for a tour -- one of the only mosques open to the public. Check out the spice market, gold market, in old Dubai (outside) or the diamond market, which is inside and also sells lots of gold for cheap. Go skiing in the mall, pay for 2 hrs and they rent everything to you.    
Oh and you can negotiate with the cabbies if you want to hire one for the entire day -- they are in need of $$ and will negotiate.   
Good luck, explore and have fun!

I presume that your son actually registered here as a member.    
If he had given us a little more information it would be easier to give advice. The Student Card should enable him to have reduced entrance to Museums - but I don't know by how much. At the Landesmuseum in Zürich the difference is only Fr. 8.- to Fr.10.-    
A  would give him free entrance to many Museums but there doesn't seem to be a cheaper Pass for a student. Some Swiss Travel System cards are also valid for free entrance but not the 1/2 Price Card and there are special arrangements for Raiffeisen Bank clients holding certain cards.    
Whether your son would save money by buying a Museum Pass depends completely on how many Museums he intends to visit. Pure maths.

Colmar is not just a great little spot. It is a must-see destination. I  could give it a pass only at Christmas, when the Christmas market comes  unto the town and obliterates it with people and people and people and  things.   
There are many lovely spots in Alsace, but what makes Colmar a must is  the Isenheim altarpiece at the Museum  . It doesn't matter if you like art or not, these works are worth crossing Europe to visit. A trip to Colmar without seeing these paintings would be woefully incomplete.
I live in Zürich and found the book really useful. I was lucky and found it for 2chf at the brocky too!

post: A quick day-trip if you enjoy sun, steep hikes, history and castles is the gorgeous town of Bellinzona in Ticino. I was there last weekend and it is amazing. A quick 2.5 hour train ride from Zurich makes it easy to do in a day trip. You can do a variety of hikes from cardiac-arrest to easy sightseeing ones that include access to the main castle by elevator. Plus you get to practice your Italian...

I tried posting this in the Pet corner but it didn't get much response. In any case, if anybody is interested in spending 6 weeks (June 24 - August 6) in Engelberg this summer rent-free you should read further. The house is a private chalet with the following view:       
and here is a view of town from the Hahnen:       
Here is some information about the deal copied from the previous post:   
                          Anybody interested in house/pet sitting for 6 weeks from late June to  early August in Engelberg? We have two friendly Australian Shepherds  (age 11 and 15). The younger one likes to go on hikes but the older one  can only handle short, level walks. The house has a small lawn that  needs to be mowed once every couple of weeks (20 minutes max).   
The house is located on the edge of the main town (5 minute walk to the  Dorfstrasse). Engelberg is very nice in the summer with endless hiking  possibilities, decent mountain biking, tennis, golf, swimming, ice rink,  etc.,...   
Ideally this would be for a retired/unemployed individual/couple who  would be around town most of the time and not leaving the dogs  unattended for hours on end. Daytrips are not an issue as there is a  fenced in yard but we would prefer that they not be left alone on a  daily basis. It would also be good for a family with some young kids who  want to enjoy the mountains for a few weeks (we have 3 young kids (2, 4  and 6) and the dogs are great with them).    
We would be willing to pay a nominal fee for this service but we don't  want somebody who is just looking for a job. We want someone that likes  dogs and likes to be in the mountains primarily and has some spare time  to enjoy them.   
Send me a pm if you are interested or want some more details. Thanks.

Thanks for all the suggestions.  Here's the books I've looked at so far and some feedback as I was able to borrow a couple:   
Eyewitness Switzerland - glossy & heavy, though nice photos to get you motivated & inspired but lacking details   
Rick Steve's Switzerland - geared for visitors coming through Switzerland for a week or so, with good itenary and basic recommendations, not too much detail   
Lonely Planet Switzerland - best of the lot so far, fairly detailed & with good recommendations, the hiking section is integrated in the book.  Some of the info or accomodation listings were dated.   
Rough Guide....next on my list, sounds very positive from the comments mentioned!     
TBG

post:
What a day, It was fantastic to see y`all in the Verkehrshaus and I really enjoyed your company, just a pity that our timing was a tad out of synch, but we really must do that again. 
I had to run along as I feared that I would not be able to dodge god´s wet bullet, I did not. 
60 Kilometers short of home the sky´s opened and I got "wet" wet is in this case a understatement I could not have gotten wetter if I had stood under a ice cold shower wearing jeans on a mo´bike at 100 km/h in watered down wet water, ice cold watered down wet, very wet water, even the bike started to splutter, poor thing had gotten water in the air intake and we lost a cylinder just a few clicks beyond Zürich and then on the creepy stretch of A1 between Zürich and St. Gollum also known as Swiss-Congo where there is no fuel station the red light came on. 
Iron pig wanted gas ASAP. 
Running on fumes, quite literally, I turned of the motorway filled up and dripped my way to pay, as I opened my wallet, poured the water out to find notes that had turned to pap-mache. 
Anyway life is a adventure and as soon as I thaw out I will look back to today with fond memories.
No problem in Business class to travel with a child as long as you pay

post:
Do you have any home country tradition for Ascension?   
I would like to share with you an almost vanishing tradition that we have in Florence (Italy) for this particular day. On Ascension day (and more recently, as this bank holiday was abolished in Italy, on the following Sunday) there is the "Cricket Festival". I know you might think about long lasting plays, etc. This has nothing to do with sports, but with cricket insects. In fact families used to gather in "Parco delle Cascine", the biggest park in Florence, and buy crickets in small coloured cages for the kids. Once at home kids were supposed to take care of the cricket and I remember giving lettuce to mine. The festival is still taking place, but as animal activists have forbidden the sale of crickets, you can still buy the coloured cage, but only with a fake cricket inside. 
This tradition goes back to several years, and there were people that lived out of selling crickets and building the small cages. No one knows the origins of this tradition. One idea is that the singing of the crickets announced the arrival of the nice weather (not this year!!!). Another theory is that crickets were damaging the agriculture, so capturing and selling them was a good way of getting rid of the problem!

It took a total of 70 minutes and I'm rebooked! The earliest flight that they could offer me out of Geneva is on Sunday, the 25th of April. I decided to postpone my trip until May in the hopes that the unpronounceable volcano stops erupting by then.   
Some advice for those of you who will be rebooking your flights -   
Go to the bathroom before you call! 
Use your speaker phone and try to ignore the sounds of whatever music comes out of the speaker. I was rebooking with Orbitz, so maybe others will have a better experience.   
I swear that the CIA could use the Orbitz tape for the advanced interrogation of suspected terrorists. I was ready to crack and tell them everything they wanted to know! Fortunately, the guy only wanted my reservation number, name, etc.    
Once again, I wish anyone else in the same position good luck and a healthy dose of patience.

post:
Lago shopping center and just around in the old town. 
When its nice weather its like being on holiday down by the lake

All of these places can be done very cheaply. They nearly all have hostels and lower price hotels too. Also for St. Moritz stay in Celerina or Pontrasina. They are much more traditional towns and much less pretentious then St. Moritz. You can still take a stroll through St. Moritz to window shop at the designer stores if you so wish.    
Remember that at that time of year it will be starting to get quite cold in many of those places.    
Try to get a night in Muotas Muragl in Pontrasina. Its at 2300m overlooking the Engadin Valley and apparently has a very good restaurant. I haven't made it up there yet myself but its been on my to do list for quite a few years.    
At that time of year the best thing about Arosa will be the train ride up, but if you like hiking you could use it as a way of getting to Lenzerheide if the lift at Hornli is still open (or if its closed if you don't mind a bit of a slog).    
Again Davos itself is a bit of a let down, the town is much prettier in Klosters, but there is also some great hiking from Davos to Arosa should you so desire.    
Scuol is well worth visiting if you want to look at some nice traditional towns.    
It really depends on what you want to do.

We've done most of the lake on the CGN boats. In the Spring schedule, which starts this Sunday, they will add even more routes than there are currently. The nicest section is certainly at the east end of the lake - from Lausanne to the Chateau du Chillon (just past Montreux). You'll have vineyards to see on the north side and 2,000m high mountains to the south. The part around Geneva is still very nice, but not AS good. After you get off the boat, you can go visit the Chateau, then maybe head back to Montreux (by bus, train, or boat) for a stroll along the lake and an ice cream or drink.

The Haute Cime is, strictly speaking, non-technical, but from the descriptions I have read it is beyond my ability, as there are several hundred vertical meters of off-trail scrambling.  From  :   The traverse of the Col de Susanfe, from the Val dÍlliez to the Vallée du Trient, with an overnight at the Cabane de Susanfe, seems much more doable.

Thanks for the advice on hotels in Chur.  Having checked out several hotel details I have settled on Hotel Schweizerhaus.  It is just away from the Old Town almost opposite the Brambrüesch cable car station.   
If anyone is looking for budget accommodation for a break, this seems to be it.  CHF50/night including breakfast.   
I will let you know how it is after my visit

Friend of mine mentioned something about renting private flats right in the middle of manhattan. Apparently found this on the internet - try googling this?   
The Staten Island Ferry is the best thing in New York, and almost free! 
If I would like to look at the Statue of Liberty without having to be on the Ellis Island itself, then I would take the Staten Island Ferry. It passes right next to the Statue of liberty and will cost you only about US1.50. If you are lucky enough not to be asked to leave the ferry and reboard at staten Island, then it is free (you only have to pay if you come on board from the staten Island side). In contrast, the Ellis Island ferry costs about USD12 !!

heres a recommendation of where NOT to go:   
Mercure Bristol Leukerbad in Leukerbad, Wallis   
I'm SUPER dissapointed in the place. They made us make our treatment reservations well in advance, but didn't comply to our wants in any way. We couldn't have our massages together, we had to have them at 2 and 3 pm, rigt after our check in. That, she claimed, was the only available slots during our stay. My Pedicure could be arranged the next day at noon. we dropped all other special treatments because it was just to complicated to reserve and then scheduel around.  
As the room would nly be available at 2pm, and our first massage was aso at 2, she assured us on the phone we would be aloud into the room earlier so as to get adjusted and not miss the massage. we showed up at 1:20, the room was not ready until exactly 2 pm (having worked in a Hotel many moons ago, I know that preparing an arrivé room can be done in 20 minutes, after seeing our room I figured it cold have been done in 15....there were no other people checking in during the 40 minutes we waited for our room.)  
The "wellness area" was kept at about 20 degrees celcius, cool if you're not wet and in a bathing suit. the water was abrely warmer, in any of the tubs. The sauna was mysteriously locked for the most part, without explanation, an no one around to ask.  
The pedicure was brutal. I could go into step by step descriptin and even someone who has no clue as to what a pedicure should entail would be appalled. She barely treated my feet, the filing is aweful, she used the cheapest nail polish ever, which had gone goopy with age and did not apply nicely at all. it was very frusterating to watch and know that I was paying 75 CHF for a service I could do MUCH better on my own. my 11 year old cousin could do better. To add to this I got the entire treatment from the comfort of a folding chair. yes, a cheap, uncomfortable folding chair. 
my feet have never had a worse polish job. seriously. not even when i was 5 and painted them with magic markers did they look so bad. 
But really, the pedicure was just the crowning point. the whole hotel is ****, and costs way too much.    
I also didnt mention that the esthetician kept speaking to me in Portugese, despite my CONSTANTLY telling her I did not understand portuguese. and, no word of a lie, she  !!!!!   
NEVER GO TO THAT HOTEL! YOU WILL RUE THE DAY!
I second the catacombs. I have been there several times and never get sick of them. Fabulous!
