post:
You're in for a nice week. Try and arrange your around the jazz festival in Ascona: a very pleasant time to be there. The Maggia valley is indeed a hikers paradise, if you don't mind sharing. It gets kinda popular - especially with Germans - but there are many routes which, with the right weather, afford magnificent views over Lago Maggiore and the Alps.    
A very easy starter would be to base yourself either in Locarno or Ascona so you have some civilisation to hand and do day trips from there. Monte Bre (Locarno, not the other one in Lugano) has a fab cable car that takes you beyond the village of Bre - one hotel, also an option - to the Madonna and you can head up the Trosa. From there you can head where ever your legs can take you. Happy trails.

We've recently used   and   for our accomodation bookings.    
There are a few more websites but they were either more expensive or we didn't like their terms & conditions.       
And Ofcourse whatever you do, avoid the gypsie kids.

I've used hrs.de for booking hotels in Italy (including Rome) several times. They provide a good service. It's a relatively safe bet to choose one which is rated above 6.5 out of 10.    
Tip: If the hotel you like isn't in the city centre, it's fine if it's near a Metro station. The site gives all the essential details of each hotel and its surroundings.

I spend quite a lot of time in Liechtenstein and I can see what people are saying here. It's quiet and sleepy, but a lovely place. However, if you are not in a rush, FL has plenty to offer.   
Malbun is a nice ski resort (of course nearing its closure for the season), while the Fürstenfest on August 15th is a   party.  For a day trip, I'd  recommend taking the train to Sargans, hopping on one of their ugly fluorescent buses, and taking in the surrounds (Feldkirch +1 vote) and take the chance to tell people you've visited 3 countries within a few minutes! When you hit Vaduz, be sure to take in the Kunstmuseum and bask in the awe of the public art (I have never seen so many sculptures on one street!)   
Incidentally, you can have your passport stamped in the tourist office in Vaduz. Much as this sounds like a nice idea, beware that it unfortunately says "tourist office" on the stamp - while it's legal, it could end up looking a bit odd in your passport for the next ten years...   
p.s. my post has been audited by a Liechtensteiner who is in approval of my ramblings

My thread about the Bernina Express ( ) got me thinking about the other World Heritage sites in Switzerland.   
There are currently 10 sites listed in Switzerland:   
Benedictine Convent of Saint John (Claustra Son Jon) at Müstair 
Abbey of St. Gall 
Old City of Berne 
Tre Castelli with defensive wall and ramparts in Bellinzona 
Jungfrau-Aletsch Protected Area 
Monte San Giorgio 
Wine-growing area of Lavaux 
Sardona Tectonic Area 
Rhaetian Railway (shared with Italy) 
La Chaux-de-Fonds and Le Locle, architectural heritage of a watchmaking area.   
There are another two tentative sites: Prehistoric sites around Swiss lakes and the architecture of Le Corbusier.   
Would you rate these as the 10 most important sites in Switzerland? 
If you had the opportunity, what sites would you add to the list?

From what I understand Mystery park closed down some time ago. You can still see the tacky completely foreign looking buildings there. Yes the cheap commercialism really irritated me as well. I guess money is king.    
My original roots are in the Himalayas and I personally feel at home in Switzerland as far as nature is concerned. What I find most amazing is that mountains back home were in the 7000-8000+ meters region compared to Jungfrau which is only 3500-4158 meters high   Jungfrau does not even feature in the top 100 highest mountain peaks of the world    
As far as access is concerned Jungfrau probably wins hands down. Definitely an amazing engineering feat! Once we got on the actual glacier the typical tourist crowd disappeared. We walked for hours on the ice away from all the Bollywood and Japanese/Chinese/Korean crowd. Bless them all but we wanted peace and quiet with mother nature.    
I am still very ill and stuck to bed. Fever is not in the 40°C region anymore but still constantly around 38.5°C. Feel like a wreck and dizzy all the time

Be prepared for official campgrounds in Europe to be very different from those in Canada, with the main difference being the reduced amount of space.

post: Consider a hotel in or around Wembley, NW London. Its not a particularly scenic part of town, but there are plenty of hotels in the area and if there are no major events around your dates you can get some amazing off peak rates. However what makes Wembley so attractive is the fact that there is a fast Metropolitain line train that gets you into The West End in 10 mins.

London Gatwick airport is also excellent. There are cheap trains to London Bridge for example.    
First Capital Connnect trains are cheaper than the Gatwick Expresses.

He wants to do all that in 10 days?    
I think he should pick up 1 or 2 places that he really wants to visit in Europe and keep the others for next time.   
It also depends on the place he'll stay in Switzerland (i.e. from Bern / Fribourg, he can go anywhere in Switzerland within 1h / 1h30).    
IMO, you should plan something like this:   
1st of April - 4th of April : Switzerland. Let him recover from the flight and the jet lag. Take him to some places in Switzerland.   
5th of April - 8th April: Paris. There are trains from / to Geneva (as he needs to be there on the 9th of April  ). The journey takes 3h something as far as I remember.   
9th April to 11th of April: Switzerland. Visit Geneva and enjoy your concert the same day. Then take him to other places in Switzerland.   
Your travel agent

In the Bernese Oberland, we've been sledging at Niederhorn, Kleine Scheidegg - Grindlewald and First - Grindelwald.   
Niederhorn had fantastic views but the initial section was a bit steep and icy with small kids. Although later in the day it got softer and easier.   
Kleine Scheidegg (the Eiger run) was quite gentle and gave fantastic views of the Eiger north face.   
Our favourite was First. There's a lot of sledging here and you can combine a good walk (snowshoeless!) with a sledge.

post:
Wow, there are a lot of advice and comments.  I'm a middle-class Thai lady and I have a decent job in Bangkok.  I love travelling domestic and abroad.  I would like to touch a little bit about Pataya, it's only 1-1.5 hrs from Bangkok.  Pataya is not all bad, there are also some areas for normal tourists who do not aim for such entertainment such as Jomtien beach.  You can also visit Koh Lan which is about 30 mins by boat from Pataya, there is a white sand beach there. There are a lot of fun activities to do in Pataya too such as Paragliding, water scooter, sailing, paintball, Go-kart and so on.  Cabaret shows by lady boys (queers) are quite interesting, just think about it as 'performance'.   
I myself like to go to Samet Island, it's about 3 hrs by bus from Bangkok to Ban Phe, and about 30 mins from mainland (Ban Phe).  I like to stay in Ao Phai (Phai Bay), there are a lot of wooden bungalows there such Jeab's, Ao Phai Hut and some others.  Silver Sand and Samet Villa is a bit more luxury with concrete single huts.  You can spend a few days there, the beaches are nice and you can go around the island by Song-thaew (pick-up truck) or rental motorbike.   
I will write more later.  I have to work now.   
Take care.....Mushroom   
You can buy prepaid sim card (AIS, DTAC or True).

Engelberg is not a particularly good place for on-piste skiing. Its great for freeriding and off piste but it has a lot of steep, narrow and icy pistes. It also has huge lift bottlenecks on busy days so certainly not what I would consider a good area to get back into it.
thread: Where can I take my sister skiing??

post:
Arosa is good - lots of walks up in the hills that are marked off for walking alone (i.e. no dodging skiers). Although in March, don't know how good the skiing will be - it is in a South-facing bowl, as I recall, and snow can be slushy.   
Betmeralp/Reideralp also has several non-ski activities.   
Rather than Saas-Fee consider Zermatt.   
Flims-Laax also has stuff, but you need to make sure you are in one of the larger villages that makes up the resort.   
Further South, in France, Chamonix has excellent skiing for advanced skiers, but has the advantage of being a large village/small town so more non-ski activities.

If I were you I would go for somewhere in the centre of Lausanne itself.  At least there you will have a variety of shops, restaurants and cafes open and a bit of a buzz going on.   
Alternatively, if you want to be near the lake.  I would look for a hotel in Lutry, Vevey or Montreaux.  All these towns are right on the lake so you will get the best of both worlds.  And it would probably be more fun for the kids too.

Hi Samanthas, all 
it sounds to me like you're going to be sliding around on snow   I have *no* clue about all these rail passes for Visitors, Flexipasses etc (I've lived here for 20-odd years) but you might want to have a look here:   
In the past I usually drove my trusty 4WD Golf to the hills but doing a quick weekend day out at e.g. Flumisberg was just getting too painful (traffic, parking...). Depending on how you look at it, they're almost giving away either the lift ticket or the train fare. 
Either way it's much greener and very relaxing (ok it can get crowded..). A friend & I even did a day in Arosa once (from ZH), we figured the lift ticket was CHF 10.- But as I say I don't know if these deals would work for you. Maybe the first one..

Have loads of fun but please make sure that you can stop the sleds if need be. I have never forgotten when my young son was on his sledge and it changed direction and went zooming down towards the road. I could not catch him and was screaming in panic, luckily, someone else saw what was happening and stopped him in time 
I have read over the years of the same thing happening again & again

post:
Bear in mind that the time of year you are looking at is the end of ski season and that a lot of the usual passes that I would recommend for great summer hiking will still be covered in snow. Some of the passes and wanderwegs will be open albeit they will be covered in snow   If you have the correct equipment and are interested in snow shoeing or hiking/climbing with crampons then this can be fun   However, I would say if you are not experienced with this sort of hiking then please use a guide as you will be hiking over snow and ice and accidents can and do happen.   
If you are looking for something at a lower altitude with less snow then I can highly recommend the   though there is a chance that even parts of this route will be unpassable and still have snow as from what I remember there was still snow in some of the higher parts of this route in early May this year.   leg of the route 5 is a nice hike but even I wouldn't normally do this until end of April beginning of May.   
Some sites you may find useful in planning your walks....              of which I'm an organizer but to be honest most of the hiking doesn't start until mid/late April depending on snow/weather   
edit - as an afterthought and going along with what Swisspea said, there is a nice hike along the river from Schaffhausen down to the Rhine Falls (approx 5-6km) and there are also a couple of valley walks in the Sargans area which should be fine and free of snow.

post:
In case anyone is interested, it was great.  The Valbella Inn was fantastic for kids - a newly renovated kids playground with child minding.  A pool (that was to cold) with a spa (warm).  A massage area (extra).  The restaurant has a kids menu.  Very friendly and helpful staff.  And there were lots of families staying there.  It's not cheap but everything is well done.  And if you get a suite then there is also a tiny kitchen - fridge, sink, basic cutlery, crockery and some utensils, and a little stove (no oven, no dishwasher!!).  But enough to be able to get lunch and/or a very simple dinner.   
And best of all, the kids ski school area is maybe 50-100m walk from the hotel.  The only issue is that the kids lifts can only be used by those in the ski school.  Our kids went into the ski school, so that was fine with us.  But if you've got young kids who've never skiied and don't want them in ski school, then you'd need to catch a free bus to Fadail.   
As to our (adult) skiing - compared to Aus it's great, although you either need to catch a bus or traverse uphill in places to get to a lift to take you higher up the mountain.   
There is also apparently a great toboggan run.  We didn't do that as our kids were enjoying the skiing too much.  But quite a few people recommended we do it.   
So we liked it so much we're thinking of booking for next year.

Yes I know, earlier this year I also managed to book returns for less than 50chf each incl. all charges. But somehow, now the 0 chf flights end up costing well over 100 chf - in that price range I prefer other airlines.

2 liters is allowed and it is cheaper to buy at the airport on arrival, however some shops do not take credit cards so make sure you have either ruppees or US$.   
Also not all airports have shops but if you are flying in Bombay or Delhi you will be fine. Also note that in some states they still have prohibition so if you are going there be careful. As a foreigner you can get a license to drink.   
The other comment is that the selection in the Indian airports is far more limted than places such as Dubai, so if you are planning on something special don't buy in India.

post:
We are a couple planning on visiting friends in central-east Paris for New Year's weekend.  Would like to leave Wednesday evening (30th) and return Sunday during the day (3rd).   
Expected cost is CHF150 per person round trip (see below).   
We are a married couple, looking for preferably another couple or two individuals to share costs.  I can make the rental and drive entire route.  Some flexibility in timing is allowed.   
Comparison per person: 
* Flights are CHF330 and up;  
* With half-fare card, TGV is CHF330 
* With half-fare card, non-TGV train is CHF240.   
Expect ~CHF630 cost to be split equally among passengers and driver. We are two, so if you are one, its about 210, and if two, about 160 per person, so definitely a significant savings.   
(A compact rental can be made for about CHF300 and seat 4 with little luggage (a backpack per person + what you hold). 1500km @ 7L/100km  ~= 105L fuel @ conservative 2.00CHF/L =  210CHF.  Parking in the city would need to be included. Not certain what to expect.  As much as 30CHF per night wed, thur, fri, sat, so 120CHF.  So, would work out to 300 rental + 210 fuel + 120 parking = 630CHF to be split four ways, or about 160 per person.)   
Please PM if you are interested.  As I said above, there is some timing flexibility, for instance to leave on thursday, instead.  If you are along the way, we might be able to swing something, too.

That is a reasonable budget. It depends on your flexibility of dates, type of accomodation and location.   
Air fares can vary substantially on different days of the week.   
The main ski resorts should be avoided if you want to keep the prices down.   
Accommodation can be found from under CHF40 each per night if you are happy with very basic hotels/hostels.   
Self-catering can also be a great cost saver. Eating out can quickly use up the budget.

We've done rome for 3-4 days with a toddler. By the fourth day everyone needs a day off..   
There are cobblestones and uneven paths everywhere in rome - pushing a pram/stroller/buggy is hard going.   
I've only done Rome, I haven't done any other italian cities. We did the same stuff in Rome twice (once without kids two years ago, this time with three kids and grandma) - and enjoyed repeating our adventures.    
I can recommend the Rome B&B association for a private apartment rental within the city - check the exact locations. We stayed near the colosseum both times.       
The advantage of a private rental is you can eat/drink and be merry and if the child wants to run around they can...more room than in a hotel or motel...   
We can also recommend in some ways the hop-on-hop-off bus, however, be warned that they have an unreliable timetable and waiting on the side of a narrow busy street in the cold/shade/wind for 45 minutes for the bus is not fun.   
I would not expect taxis to have appropriate baby seats, or bother using them...   
I would not recommend taking the public trains with a baby/stroller - you are an absolute target for pickpockets and beggars.   
I would probably recommend the public buses with a toddler, but not with a pram.   
So, my recommendation -    
Fly to Rome or take the train.  
Take the express train from Rome airport to Rome main train station.  
Get accommodation between the main train station and the Colosseum.  
Plan to do the colosseum and roman forum one day. 
Vatican and St Paul's Basilica one day. 
Trevi fountain/spanish steps/etc third day. 
Use the hop-on-hop off bus for the two days (vatican/trevi fountain etc).   
Take it easy.   
There is so much to see in Rome.   
As they say...Rome was not built in a day.   
oh, and watch out for pickpockets/beggars...   
Final tip - the people who offer tours in English outside the colosseum, may actually be legitimate tour guides- ask them for their ID - we did an excellent walking tour of Colosseum and the Roman Forum - you jump the queue, avoid the traffic, and you are free to leave the tour whenever you've had enough. They went slow enough for our children, and we managed it with a pram...it was I think 20 Euro for adults including entry and the toddler was free...

post:
Just got back from Lugano. We didn't get much time to do any relaxing but had a really good time all in all.   
We stayed at a decent 3 star place called Walter au Lac bang in the center right at the lake. Great location and great views from our room.       
The hotel was typical for a 3 star; basic but also clean and comfortable. Thanks god for the airconditioner, it was really hot down there.   
We also ate some great food. Unortunately didn't manage to eat at a Grotto, but add some great Italian at small intimate restaurants.   
We also went to Fox Town when the weather was bad and found some really great deals at the outlets. There are more than just designer stores, lots of sports outlets there as well; Adidas being my favourite sports brand.   
Finally we went to Monte Bré and had a great time walking through the hilly forests. They served some decent Ticinese food at the restaurant by the funicolare.   
All in all, a superb time.   
Next time up, Ascona!

post: Ok, there is not only the passport check: In Germany, you always need to have some sort of ID with you, any cop has the right to check it when he wants and where he wants - nothing to do with border or Schengen. So if the passport is invalid, I would expect the Ausländerausweis to be sufficient as an ID - if it is the card format already since this is the same all over the EU. (I usually just show a driver´s license and never had any issue as long as it is an official document with a photo).

Is there not a train that you can just sit on at Interlaken Ost and it takes you to the top of Jungfrau?   
Sorry I'm confused

I would generally agree, but I live by the airport and have not noticed a significant difference between the amount of East/West flights. My suspicion is confirmed by this, albeit oldish (first half of 2005), graphic from Geneva airport's website        
(Green - Landing, Blue - Take off)    
So, if you're landing at Geneva it's a lottery, but personally I would plump for the left: should you land to the east, depending where you've come from, you might still have good views of the alps and you get the thrill of skimming the Jura as the plane comes through the col by the Fort de l'Écluse.  
If you're taking off and you've not got a seat booked: if they are taking off to the east sit on the right. But if you are flying to somewhere generally to the east of Geneva still sit on the right which ever way they're taking off.   
All too often Geneva is stuck in low cloud/fog, and climbing through this, the sudden spectacle of bright sunshine on the mountains tops can be magnificient.

post:
We always go to France or Italy, never went anywhere beyond Lausanne in Switzerland (I know, we should, but somehow never happens).   
Anywhere in Provence is usually great but we like to stay in St Rémy de Provence and make daytrips to different lovely villages (Gordes, Roussillon) or Marseilles (for bouillabaisse) or famous towns (Avignon, Arles, Nimes).    
I am also very much in love with Burgundy (Cote-d'or) and, a bit closer to home, Jura is also very attractive, depending on what you like to do. If you like cities, you can also do a day trip to Lyon. Annecy, already mentioned, is a very charming little town for a relaxing day by a lake that is not Lac Leman.

Privatair own and operate a corporate fleet on behalf of a few airlines such as Swiss, Lufthansa and KLM as well as major companies who can afford their services. Alpine Club huts are not really geared for spending a weekend.  Their basic clientele consists of climbers or hikers who hike in, eat, sleep, and resume hiking or climbing the next day.  There is not much to do in the hut during the day.   
Accommodation is dormitory style, and I am not sure that dogs are allowed.   
Here are a few links I have accumulated over time; I did not reread them for relevancy: 
I suspect that a small hotel in a mountain village might be closer to what I believe you want.   
I have written the above on the assumption that you are not familiar with the Swiss hut system; my sincere apologies if my assumption is incorrect.

Hi All,   
I just got back from a great couple of days in Zernez. Went with a couple of friends who went hiking. I couldn't hike because I've got a couple of injuries awaiting operation.    
But I had a great time eating Hirsch, Reh sipping the local booze and enjoying the fresh mountain air. It was also nice to finally get to meet Raetians and hear Romansh. Very warm and welcoming people.   
I stayed at   and really liked it. A small family run hotel/inn with a great restaurant serving seasonal game. The owner was always around and I had a good time chatting to her.   
If you're looking for a short getaway away from noisy tourists, this has to be one of the places.   
I also stopped by St. Moritz on the way back to Zürich and enjoyed walking around the town. Lots of desginer stores and expensive hotels.   
Happy Holidaying.

This is a wonderful two day stroll (moderate hike) across the mountains. I did it last weekend and it comes highly recommended.   
First Day: 
- take the Madrisa cablecar in Klosters 
- hike over the 'Schlappiner Joch' to Gargellen in Austria 
- stay over night at Haus Wulfenia (I paid 51 Euro for half board accomodation including a beer, a glass of wine and packed lunch for the next day), cash only in Euro, no credit cards   
Second Day 
- take the cablecar up to the Schafberg 
- hike up to the St. Antönier Joch 
- cross the border to Switzerland 
- hike down to St. Antönien 
- take the bus to Küblis 
- take the bus back to Klosters   
...nothing tastes like a ham sandwich on a sunny mountain meadow.   
Last day the cablecars operate in Gargellen is October 4.

The suggestions above are perfect. The beauty of Bern is that the centralized old town has most of the tourists sites and everything is within walking distance.    
The Altes Tram Depot is a great lunch stop and they make their own beer but it also really touristy. There are a lot of restaraunts in town with more local flavor if that's your thing. I'd recommend the Schwellenmätteli Restaraunt under the Kirkenfeld Bridge for a nice lunchtime experience.

post: ...Some more general info

Hi there,   
Its a shame you didn't plan on doing this earlier in the year. I started doing the Route 5 in May/June this year as part of my hiking training for Kili.   
We hiked from Dielsdorf to Sainte Croix..... and I am meaning to finish off the rest of the route over September/October at the weekends.   
You are more than welcome to join the remainder of the hike, there is usually a group of us and more info on when the hikes will take place will be posted   you will also find information on the past hikes and some useful links to maps.   
If you need any further info, please feel free to PM me as I have pdf files of all the maps to stage 10 and additional notes such as restaurant locations/good places to stop for lunch etc.   
It really is a beautiful area of the country (then again which part of CH isn't beautiful!) and if it hadn't of been for the fact I couldn't hike the higher trails earlier in the year due to the passes still being covered in snow I would never have discovered it.   
Happy hiking!

The Nurburgring is a bit more than a few hours from Zurich (nearly 5 hours from Basel, and its quite frankly in the middle of nowhere). However, they have recently opened a massive new village with new hotels, and those hotels may include a spa or spa services.    
The ring is an easy place to have a day at the track, because it is a public road. So he does not need to tag on with a specific group to get some track time. You can pay per lap or pay for a bunch of laps. But I would check their website to make sure it is open to the public on a weekend that you want to go.    
On the downside, it is a public toll road. So anyone and anything can go on the track. I mean, you can even see buses. There are no corner workers for safety, and the track is narrow so there is not a lot of margin for error.    
You can find info on the Nordschleife here:    
There are lots of tracks in France that may be closer than the ring. But you would have to check calenders and see what groups are attending, then try and sign up with those groups (for example, there is a track at Dijon that gets rented out all the time by Suisse car clubs). But unfortunately, most tracks are conventiently located in the countryside, so finding a spa facility nearby could proove difficult.   
I'm just getting to know some of the European tracks myself, so unfortunately I can't offer you much more info than that.

As a kid i preferred the Basel Zoo and even started a tradition with my numerous nephews and nieces to go there  with them as a 5th birthday pressie,thus i happened ot be there frequently in my tweens, and this was the time when they started to alter the zoo,it was just one big building site at times and some of te animals they choose to exhibit were no the ons we were interested in and then it lost the appeal for me.   
I now much rather go to the Zurich Zoo wit my lassies,where a visit to the MASOALA hall is a MUST, but its not to be recommended with very small kids (IMHO) since you need to be able to be still and observant to spot the various animals running freely around in there and the hotness and humidity might make a toddler cranky too.   
i also think the voluntary service is ACE,where volunteers manage a kind of small stall in front of  few choosen animals, where the kids can ask questions to their hearts content as well as touch and feel various things ( lions tooth & claw,Fur,bones etc) and thus learn much more about the animal too.   
ZH gets now big thumbs up for me!!!!   
Also inteersting, just as a tip to those interested is the PAPILLIORAMA/NOCTURAMA/JUNGLe trek             in Kerzers ( yes i am biased       
Admittedly,the entrance fee is a bit steep,tho i think you get oyur moneys worth, there is also a big well maintained playground outside as well as a hut close to a biotope where you can try to spot animals ( take looking glasses with you),a tiny petting zoo is also on the premises....see link

post: I knew a couple (and it wasnt us!) who used to take both the pram and the huck-a-pack on some of their wilder walks. They used the pram till the going got too steep or two rough, then either left the pram till they came back down to collect it (Grîndelwald to Faulhorn in winter) or used the pram like a wheelbarrow, if necessary with a rope to pull up the slope or brake coming down and the other person pushing while the baby was safely in the huck-a-pack!. Seems to have worked quite successfully  they are all still alive and well.    In Grindelwald they did Männlichen to the Kleine Scheidegg and First to Faulhorn too. I believe they used a bus to get to the starting for a walk to First. Mind you, they did say something about getting some funny looks from other walkers and some folk wanted to take photos!   .    This came up when I looked for Grindelwald First and Kinderwagen. (pram)     This Link has Kinderwagen walks for many place in Switzerland but I cannot see any in Grindelwald.    Perhaps looking for Rollstuhl (wheelchair) might give more Information     Hope you find suitable walks. It's a great region.

for the US rate the pass typically has to be purchased in the US -- the passes can be purchased here but the rates are higher (convenience factor) than those offered in the US -- you can oder them at   and they are delivered usually in 2 days.

Many people like to complain that Ryanair are trying to trick them into paying charges, but it's just a matter of getting out of the mindset of flying with a conventional airline and reading the smallprint concerning online check in, luggage, onflight snacks, airport location etc. Sounds like you're getting prepared, i'm sure your flight will be fine!

post:
Majestic train ride to the high Alps and glaciers: 
Zurich -> Landquart -> St.Moritz -> Bernina 
(approx 4h 30min each way)

Hire a bike and cycle along the lakeshore. I'd suggest getting up early, taking the bikes on the train Villeneuve (change at Montreux to local train) at the other end of the lake then cycling back past Chateau Chillon to Montreux, Vevey, then take the corniche road through the vineyards to Lutry /Ouchy/Lausanne. You can get the train back from Lausanne or depending on your stamina continue on to Morges and get it from there. This is my view the very best stretch of the Geneva lakeshore and the views are magnificent. 
If you're not into bikes and have a car then spend a day driving round the lake or if no car take the train to Villeneuve and then walk back along the lake to Montreux (stop at Chateau Chillon), fromm Montreux, take the bus to Vevey, then the bus from Vevey to Vevey funicular (up to Mont Pélerin) then train back from Vevey to Geneva stopping off maybe at Lausanne/Ouchy, Morges and/or Nyon. 
All of above easily done in a day. I'd have to say three days would be difficult to fill in Geneva itself.

post:
Just back from a weekend at the Delta camp site. We were two people and survived the storm on Friday night/Satur-day...... all day... mad, we really thought the tent would have flown, but luckily it didn't... others were not so lucky.   
We paid Fr.353 for 2 people for 3 nights.... wow wow wow... 
the invoice was divided into Fr57/prime location tenting (most expensive category) After that they wanted more money for each person staying... turned out to be over Fr100 for the 3 nights... wow, and I thought it cost 57/night for the space... well yes it did, but only if you weren't staying in it!!! 
we paid a flat-rate of Fr.5/night for electricity and here's the mad thing, Fr50 Buchungsgebühr... eh what? Well, for what??    
Anyway, there was no entertainment, nothing to speak of anyway.. a few slots for the kids - for money of course - no band, nothing else either...   
Also, it is considered 5* well, I have to say the toilets didn't smell like toilets and seemingly that's what 5* is considered... constant hot water, working showers, not exactly clean all the time, some people are basically pigs when it comes to public amenities, but I expected a constant cleaning service, especially for that price.     Positives : Great location, great weather, if not a little adventurous, no driving in after 10pm which is good. Huge place, one can eat, there is a restaurant on site... lake was beautiful, we even got close to a mother duck and her 10 ducklings... very cute. great swimming. Friendly service...   
All in all a great weekend, BUT expensive... Katie Melhua was also super, very good live singer... any suggestions for a camp site in Italy? somewhere not quite as expensive?

Go clockwise (far less cross-traffic to worry about at intersections).   
In France, take the road that goes via Yvoire - it is a very nice medieval village that you can spend some time looking at plus the road is far nicer than the main Thonon-Geneva road.   
If you don't mind a bit of extra climbing, then between Cully and Vevey, take the "Corniche" road that climbs up through the vineyards (via Chexbres and Chardonne).    
Likewise, there is a great road between Aubonne and Gland through the vineyards and with great views.    
In Geneva, have an ice cream while admiring the big fountain (Jet d'eau), but you can skip the rest of the city.    
In Lausanne, the Olympic museum is right by the lake and is worth a couple of hours if you are interested in sporting history.   
Montreux is a nice place to stroll around.    
The Chateaux de Chillon (just south of Montreux) always impresses non-Europeans and even some Europeans, it is a particularly nice castle. Even if you don't go inside, you can cruise by on the cobbled road outside for a quick look.   
The section of road in France from St Gingolgh to the turn-off to Yvoire is the worst part of the ride. It is difficult to avoid the main road which is very busy. Doing this on a Sunday is the only way to avoid some of the traffic. If you're taking your time to do the ride and like a good, long climb, then some people have been known to incorporate a ride down to Monthey and over the Pas de Morgins mountain pass (1,000 vertical metres of climbing) and then descend all the way down to Thonon as part of their lake tour.   
You should find some more info in the following threads:

Our Swiss friends go to a chalet somewhere in the valley between Kandersteg and Goppenstein where there's no car access only rail or post bus. I'll have to scrounge up the details if you're interested in knowing more. They are from the mountains so they know these things that outsiders don't I suppose.

Three of the best (views, restaurants etc) are the National, the Schweizerhof and the Palace but they are chf 450 plus. Wherever you go, do call them and see what offers they can make you. I read an article Le Matin or 24 Heures a few weeks ago that said luxury 5 star hotels in Switzerland are suffering because international tourism is down this year and many are offering substantial discounts off listed rates to attract Swiss residents and steal business 3 from 4 star places.

Take the train from Bern to Murten, stroll through this ancient village, have lunch, take the boat across two lakes for 18 chf per person if you check the web site, or with a coop supercard, to Neuchatel or St-Blaise, and visit the vinyards in that region.  
St-Blaise is a wonderful village to walk through (take the path beside the stream, past the old watermill, and turn left after the railway bridge where you find three vinyards). But check the web for their names and tasting times!

post: Sorry, never been there but I'm interested to hear from others, as we will be in Bellinzona next week...
How long does it take to walk from central Lugano to Gandria?

I expect that the marmottes are out of hibernation by now, but whether they'll be active while you're there is another matter. Another thing to do up there is a 5-10 minute walk from the train station there is an alpine garden. It is very well cared for and contains lots of special species of Swiss Alpine plants and flowers. If you're lucky then one of the people who help to care for the garden will be up there and will be very eager to point out a few of the more special flowers to you. But even if not, everything has labels; keep an eye open for the Edelweiss! The snow has probably only recently gone from the garden, but that is when many Alpine flowers come into bloom, so it should be a good time to go.   
The hike up from Caux is via the Col de Jaman. My rough estimate as to length would be 2-3 hours, but this is very rough. From the Col to the top is not an easy hike, but it is certainly doable. The more challenging part is going across the face of a scree slope and then up a pretty steep and narrow cleft in the rock. The path is well marked, and when we were there, we saw a family with children about 10 years old on the trail who weren't having much difficulty. Even so, take it easy and safely, and take lots of breaks, and you should be fine. You could then ride the train back down in comfort.   
As for the time to go, during the middle of summer, haze tends to build up during the day, so the morning can be better than the afternoon for visibility. At the moment, I don't think there is too much heat haze, so I would base the decision on the weather forecast for that day.   is currently predicting better weather for this morning than this afternoon.

post: Definitely 'Brass Monkey' weather

Hi there,   
I just wanted to add/subtract to the Gruyere suggestion started by the OP ( which by the way was a great resource). I am coming from a family perspective.   
We just came back from a great weekend there - 4 adults and 5 kids ( ranging from 1-7 years).   
We did the hike from Moleson to Gruyere with kids ( it is about 5-7 km) and going this way you go down the hill instead of up. For us this was an advantage. The kids made it but were pretty tired at the end. You can then take the bus back to Moleson which leaves every 40 minutes or so - after visiting Gruyere and having an ice-cream!   
The Maison de Gruyere tour was a complete waste of money and time. It is for the mass tourist market , has no heart, no smell ( of the cheese) and no interest. I really would  suggest   to do this. There is however an artisanal cheese making place in Moleson which is more  interesting     
If you stay the night, I would suggest the farm house 'Praz July'. It is simple and great for  kids. The beds are not very comfortable but you manage to sleep.  It has an amazing view and close to everything. With breakfast it costs CHF 45 for adults and CHF 25 for kids over 2 years.     
The chocolate tour was fun but the only thing missing was actually seeing the machines working - stopped now for hygenic purposes.   
The Gruyere Chateux was suprisingly well done. They have a film ( which all our kids sat and watched - amazingly) and there are some beautiful views from the top.   
Lastly, if you want a simple meal ( again with kids) the aerodrome at Broc is fantastic. There is an amazing park for kids ( with goats, flying fox, swings etc), plus they can watch the small planes take off and land. Menu is simple, steak and chips, steak tartare, fondue etc but it was perfect for us!.   
Hope this helps with any families visiting this beautiful region of Switzerland.

I presume you are using touring or road bikes.    
You could do something like Chur-Lenzerheide-Tiefencastle-Bergun-Albulapass-Engadine-Berninapass-St, Moritz-Silvaplana-Julierpass-Tiefencastle. Or some variation of this. The Bernina part is an out and back from Celerina/Pontrasina so could be added in or left out depending on how you feel. You could also head down as far as Livigno if the fancy took you.    
If you are using MTB's there are other possibilities available depending on snow melt rates.    
The one part on the route I suggested that may cause problems is Albula pass. At the moment it's still closed and I don't know when they plan on opening it.    
Be aware that in May its still going to be quite cold up there. Camping should be with equipment that can cope with temperatures below 0deg C.

I was at Titlis yesterday for the first time.  Stunning views.  And the skiing wasn't bad either.  Loads of snow. ( 4m (13 feet) at the top ).   
I suggest that you wait until the day before, and check the forecast.  Go to whichever is sunniest.

First thought. Do you really need to travel by car? Travelling by train will give you the opportunity to all relax and take in the scenery without any traffic jams. Admittedly, it will work out more expensive and can be less convenient on timings.   
I mention travelling by train as there are some really spectacular journeys. For me, the best is the Bernina Express: Chur - St Moritz - Tirano.   
For a good mixture of scenery, mountains and lakes, the Lauterbrunnen area is as good a starting point as any. This gives easy access to Schilthorn, Jungfrau/Eiger, Lakes Thun & Brienz, Trummelbach, Staubbach and Reichenbach Falls, Brienz Rothorn Railway, Schynige Platte, Wengen/Murren, Grindelwald and Interlaken. Plus much more.   
If you go to the Zermatt area you will have to leave the car at Tasch. There is certainly plenty there. My favourites include include Mountain walks to Z'mutt area, Klein Matterhorn, Gornergrat, Sunnegga/Rothorn. You could consisider basing yourself around Brig so that you also had reasonable access to other places nearby such as Saas Fe, Bettmeralp/Aletch Glacier etc.   
Another option in 'The Swiss Riviera'. Lake cruises, Montreux, Vevey, Chillon Castle, Rochers-de-Naye and Gruyere just for starters.

Here is the rough plan.   
1  LH 728  19AUG 3 FRAPVG     1730 0955+1                            
2  LH 729  07SEP 1 PVGFRA     1315 1855   
795 EUR including train ticket in Germany.     
Aug. 20, check in Shanghai Mansion Hotel in Shanghai, around CHF 100 per night per room (pnpr thereafter).   
Aug. 20 afternoon, sightseeing in Yu Garden, Pudong New Area and Nanjing Road.   
Aug. 21, sightseeing in Huaihai Road, afternoon check out, train to Suzhou. Check into Suzhou Renjia Hotel, about CHF 100 pnpr.   
Aug. 22, sightseeing in Suzhou, including Huqiu, Wangshi Yuan, Hanshan Si, Suzhou Mesuem.   
Aug. 23 morning, check out, train to Hangzhou, check into Liuyin Hotel, CHF 100 pnpr. Visit West Lake area.   
Augt. 24, West Lake and Xixi area.     
Aug. 25 morning check out and train to Shanghai, take flight to Beijing. Check into Qintangfu Hotel, CHF 100 pnpr.   
Aug. 26, sightseeing in Forbidden Palace, Beihai, Summer Palace,   
Aug. 27, sightseeing in Greatwall, Ming Dyansty Tomb.   
Aug. 28 morning, check out, flight to Xian.  Check into Xian Meihua Jintang Hotel, about CHF 90 pnpr.  Sightseeing in Xian city.   
Aug. 29, sightseeing in Binma Yong and Huashan.   
Aug. 30 morning, checkout, fight to Chengdu.  Check into Haiyue Hotel, CHF 100 pnpr. Sightseeing in Chengdu city.   
Aug. 31, sightseeing in E Mei Mountain.   
Sept. 1 and 2, sightseeing in Jiuzhai Gou.   
Sept. 3 morning, flight to Lijiang. Check into Guanfang Hotel, CHF 100 pnpr.   
Spet. 4, sightseeing in Lijiang.  Check out and flight to Guilin.   
Sept. 4 night, check into Guihu Hotel, CHF 100 pnpr.   
Sept. 5, sightseeing in Guilin.   
Sept. 6 morning, flight to Shanghai.   
Sept. 6, check into Park Hotel in Shanghai, CHF 100 pnpr. Sightseeing in Shanghai.   
Sept. 7 morning checkout, flight back to Zurich.   
Total cost person including international and domestic flights, food, sightseeing spot tickets, around CHF 3200.

post:
How much do you want to do, as without a car some of the tips given would have you spending most of your time on draughty railway platforms. Driving from Edindurgh to Inverness is dead simple, way quicker, and the A9 scenery is as pretty bloody good.    
I would fly to Edinburgh and hire a car there, as between 4 of you it would work out cheaper than taxi's and trains, and way more convienient if you time restrained, have dinner at the Cavalry Club for a nice Indian, and a stroll down Princess Street for a few beers, and a good nights kip. Then day 1 do the Edinburgh castle, Leith and the ex Royal yacht Britannia, and the Whiskey Society vaults, finishing up with supper and a beer around the Grassmarket or Golden Mile, that's pretty packed day. Then drive up the A9 on day 2 and base yourself in Inverness, if you can get in at the Heathmount or Corriegarth, that would give you a great place to explore from during the day but at night they are both have good restaurants and bars and are only a 5 minute walk to Inverness city centre, they are small and probably not on the typical Holiday inn/Ibis type search engines, visist Culloden Battlefield and Fort George at Ardersier, or take the tour out into the Moray Firth for some dolphin watching so that's, so after your 2.5 hour drive north thats a relaxing day ender as those places are all 15 mins from Inverness. Day 2 drive down Great Glen past Loch Ness (which no one mentioned , but I'd guess most never went that far north or are from the central belt), you must stop and get a photo with Nessie at Drumnadrochit, onto Fort William and take in Neptunes Staircase and Ben Nevis, then back via Glen Coe (not possible to do by train, as it would take to long and would involve sight seeing in the dark), finnishing with dinner at either hotel which both have good restaurants, or head into town to the Mustard Seed which was Mama G's fav', all serve traditional (ish) food. Day 3 Head off to the Glen Morangie distilery (at Tain), then up to Dunrobbin Castle the Drive is up the A9 and follows the coast, then to the falls of shin and Mohomad Al Fyad Harrods of the North, back to Inverness for a good Chinese at Dickens, Indian at the Shapla with great views over the River Ness or a fantastic Thai on Union st (the name escapes me). You's probably find live music at either Johnny Foxes or Hootananny's, and there was a place opening as a live venue called the Ironworks but I never wentDay 4 for then drop the car at Inverness and fly back from their Inv-Gat, Gat-Zurich.   
I should be a travel agent as I quite fancy it myself now, and Mama G's there just now. If you want more detail you can PM me .

The OP is making a connection back to ZRH which means he will start his trip in the US and therefore NO need to go through customs. But 1hr 10 mnts is too short. Now days in JFK you will go through security even if you arrive and depart from the same terminal. In my opinion (as an aviation expert) you will not make your connection.
So who's been up and about since 4 am ?

post:
As I have been going to St Moritz for ski holidays for the last 25 years (though not this year) I'll try and give you a quick resumé:   
St Moritz has a great image. The reality is usually a disappointment - it is on a high plateau, rather than a valley, thus the views, like the local architecture which seems to favour flat-roofed blocks, are not particularly attractive. The town is high at 1800m, but this does not always guarantee plentiful snowfall.    
The Engadin has a special climate that means high amounts of sunshine, but often a lack of snow - and about every 10 years too much snow. This is a too much year.   
There are of course ski schools and I would not attempt to ski without lessons. St Moritz is not ideal for beginners and the run down to the valley, whichever area you are on can be a challenge, but you can always come down by lift. There are beginners' slopes, but the area is generally for more advanced skiers. You cannot ski to your hotel door and a car woudl be useful to access some areas. Tip: best place to stay - Club Med...

Actually, there is a fan-bus from Vaduz to Geneva.  SBB is not interested  
in the smallness and lack of fanship of the FC Vaduz fans.  The fan-bus  
arrives about 15 minutes before the game start... then departs about 10  
minutes after the game is finished.  The people that get off the bus are  
"herded" to the visitor's stands by security... no way around it!

LHR is a lot better now they've moved to Terminal 5.  Now it's over the problems we thought it was actually a very nice terminal, quite spacious and plenty of shops and duty free.   
We have flown with KLM (via Amsterdam), Easyjet (from Geneva) and BA (Via LHR Terminal 5) in the last 6mths to Newcastle.   
KLM are generally slightly more expensive than BA I have found, however there often isn't much in it.  Easyjet are obviously cheaper, and if you have a halbtax card you can get a return Zurich - Geneve Airport for 80CHF, so factor that in too.   
Easyjet might be cheaper - but Geneva airport is horrendous (in my opinion) and the boarding the easyjet flight turned into an undignified scrum last time we were there.

Actually, if you really look at a specific case, the rates are higher (often promotion or empty seats when the flight is announced). In addition, you have to add for the following: 
- Flight to London Stansted (for example not possible from Zurich, so you need to add train or parking in/to Basel) 
- Airport taxes 
- Booking fee from Air Asia 
- Meals to be paid in the flight 
- Luggage allowance to be added 
- etc   
I have professional experience (as private and travel agent) with good fares to Asia, especially Malaysia where my wife comes from.   
If you have any plans to travel to that region, send me a PM with you specific travel plans, and I can give you some recommandations.

What you all have to say about the Weihnachtsmarkts is true - in a way ...... I have a regular stall at our village Christmas Night Market, and have learned to not expect to "make money" .. its all about Atmosphere and community spirit.   Most stall holders are happy to just cover their stall hire costs.      
If there were no stall holders - there would be no atmosphere worth talking about!   
I have noticed that its mostly the oldies who will buy a few items from various stalls ... they know we wish to recoup our costs, that its all mostly about the service we provide to the community anyway.   
Talking about bargaining ..... people should try it......Otherwise we gotta hang onto the stuff for another year!... better to convert it to cash.  Thats just MY opinion anyway.  I guess that those stall-holders who do regular "flea-markets" wont want to bargain as they need their goods for the next weeks market?   But there`s nothing lost in the asking!

post: No need to travel far. Drop your kid off at La Madeleine des Enfants,  , then go to this luxurious urban day spa  . You have to book your treatment in advance, but your child you can leave in the garderie above without prior notice (max 3 hours).
TIP:  Thermalp les Bains dOvronnaz is best enjoyed after a full day of skiing.

For us, 18 months was pretty much the worst age to travel with kids. Since you are only going to Italy, I would choose the quickest option with the plane. Actually, the least stressful way would be taking a car and not planning on driving for more than 4 hours maximum per day.
Treat yourself to a VIP cabin- there is a jacuzzi in the parents bedroom bathroom and a steam sauna in the second bathroom.

I would recommend Morocco too.  I was there last winter and had an awesome time. I visited Marrakesh, Fez, and Casablanca (I traveled everywhere by train.  The train system is good and the price very reasonable).  Food is cheap - you can have a meal for under 5 euros.

post:
Frederik:   
The thing to do in Switzerland is to pick a ski area - I'd go for the Hasliberg 
if I were you - and then contact the local  , the tourist office (they will certainly speak English!), and ask what they have in chalets or other accommodation for your dates (for example in Reuti or Wasserwendi where the gondolas take you up to the ski area).  Many locals rent out their own places during the season, and list them at the  .  Still, you may have some difficulty with the number of people; most winter apartments I've heard of are for 4-6 people.  Maybe you can stay in two houses next to one another?   
Good luck! 
J.

Unless you are changing mega-bucks , it hardly makes any difference, a few francs here or their....use credit cards but beware issuers add on 1-2% for "charges" although exchange rate is far better than cash.

post:
Hi,   
Well, despite the nasty windy cloudy weather we went and had a fine time...   
The weather cleared after lunch so we could see the lakes from the top, and the trip back down and across the lake to Luzern was lovely.   
We now have an 'idea' of how far it is to Zug, and to Luzern from Zurich - I think Luzern will be our next trip out of town...   
It was ok to go up Rigi in the nasty weather - you really don't have to be outside - there are heated waiting areas with food and toilets at each train stop...and the trains etc are all heated.   
They also gave us a 10chf voucher x 5 for all of us - the kids included - which paid for half our lunch at the Rigi Kulm Hotel cafeteria, and that made the whole day feel great...   
The kids are keen to go back when the snow comes...

hope it works out for you.   
can't be as bad as the grandparents not taking a child's medical card (or any other ID) and also discovering after the four hour car trip that they also didn't take his injection needles - for diabetes.   
It was a good experience for them in asking for help - from the 'likely' places (hospital, pharmacy etc)...driving around in the middle of the night... then discovering that if they'd just mentioned it at their hotel, the hotel manager's sister had diabetes and could have given them what they needed !

Hi!   
I hope it's not too late for an answer!   
Well, the Vivarium in Lausanne is great: they have snakes, spiders, crocodiles, etc. If you have a car, the zoo in Servion is very nice as well. Just google 'Lausanne' and 'Vivarium'/'Servion' and you'll get all the directions you need.   
Otherwise, the playgrouds at Ouchy and Pully are very nice (both at the 'débarcadère' where you take the boats). If it rains, there are a few nice museums as well (Musée de la Main, for instance). The gardens of the Olympic museums are also beautiful.   
Still with a car, a day or an afternoon at the Signal de Bougy (above Aubonne) is wonderful: huge playgrounds for every age, walking in trees ways, farm animals...    
Hope this helps!

Hi there. 
In Riazzino-Cugnasco there shouldn't be any "safety" problems whatsoever. 
Locarno has had a recent history of juvenile misbehaviour in the wee times of the night, especially around the train station, but really nothing much during the day.   
Try looking for accomodation in Tenero as well, as it hosts a national sporting center.   
The Locarno - Ascona area is a favourite holiday place for many coming from norther Europe - especially germany and the german part of Switzerland, so don't be surprised if you'll be greeted in German at stores, restos and hotels. 
The strong touristic attraction also means that prices in the region tend to be higher than average :-/   
Best,   
Paul

Do you enjoy skiing? If yes, you could go to Ischgl in Tirol. You need to book early though. There's an excellent restaurant ( ) called Paznauner Stube that has a great Christmas dinner and there's also a very late mess in the local Church in case you're into that. It's a roughly 2.5h drive from Zurich. Most hotels might require that you stay for 5 or 6 nights at least as they are always fully booked around that time. Its definitely nicer than any skiing resort in the East of Switzerland and still quite close.

A few years ago I had the good fortune of finding a second hand copy of Miriam Underhill's book  .  In it she describes, among many other climbs, a climb (with Robert Underhill, who was not yet her husband) of the   by the  , or  .  In either language it translates into "Ridge of the four asses".  I am not sure why she used the German name, since the ridge is in the francophone part of the Valais.   
The name intrigued me, but only mildly.  I had often admired the   from the  , but that ridge is not seen from there.  A couple of weeks ago I was hiking in the  , and had an excellent view of that ridge.  It rekindled my curiosity about its name.

From Interlaken to Montreaux via Gstaad could be interesting.  I'm sure there's a set of routes to do it.  You could also take the train, which is really interesting, to connect parts where the walking isn't so great.

It is a Lindstrand balloon in their colours so it is pretty colourful    
Weather is good for the weekend.

For those of you in the Basel area who want to see something a little different this weekend. There is the  annual Roemerfest held at Augusta Raurica.   
Augusta Raurica for those of you who aren't aware, is the oldest known Roman colony on the Rhine and is situated just outside Basel. It has a theatre, a temple and an Ampitheatre plus The best preserved Roman oven north of the Alps   
Lots to see and do for the whole family especially the children with gladiator school, horse riding, money minting and lots more   
Runs from  
Saturday,  : 10 – 17:00 
 Sunday,  : 10 – 17:00     
Prices:

post: Just came back from a fantastic 2 day trip to rochers de naye. Went with kids (15, 13 &8) and hubby  on the train up the mountain. It really depends on your pattern and distance of travel. Based in Basel doesn't help as you only really have East and South to go. Some of the best bits are a 3 hour journey from Basel by train, 5 to venture on to Ticino or Wallis. Luzern/Pilatus would be an easy day out from Basel, as would going East towards Lake Constanz and a visit to a vinyard or 2 around Schaffhausen plus the Rheinfalls (I recommend Fam Strasser  )   
I wouldn't go the whole hog on a 4 day pass unless you intend to travel 8 hours a day on the train and/or try the paddlesteamers on the lakes.   
Either way enjoy.

post:
I enjoy going to the area near Grasse. You are about 9 miles from the coast if you want the med and Cannes is not far away.,   
Grasse is very interesting as you can visit the Fragonard perfume house and the museum although closed until Sept is well worth a visit. 
There are many local restaurants to sample and some beautiful walks.

I'd recommend the Clock and Watch Museum Beyer on the Bahnhofstrasse as highlighted in the Hidden Gems posting. The curator is interesting, enthusiastic, friendly and a happy soul. They have water and sand clocks from pre-watches/clocks.   
Also in August is the Rundfunk month where you can go to the Landesmuseum courtyard (afternoon till 11 pm) where DJs play live music which is broadcast on the 1 month only radio station. It's a nice a relaxed place to go for a drink or bite to eat.  
Starts 2nd August   
HBF

I went on Saturday afternoon.  It was very nice but crowded.  Our favourite features of the day were:   
1.  Listening to a Jodel group singing "Barbara Ann" from the Beach Boys.  They even moved like a boygroup.  They got a huge applause.   
2.  Watching "Hopp dä Base" being filmed and being pushed back by a Jodler group.  I realized they were speaking English to each other and asked them where they came from.  They replied, "New Glarus, Wisconsin" and it turns out they know people who my husband knows.  It was a very special moment and we had a huge laugh together, just right before they had to go on TV.   
The later the evening, the worse the crowd got and so we left.   
My biggest disappointment was the high prices of drinks.  They made a mint in food and beverage in the tents around the KKL.

post:
Lake Orta is a bit cheaper than Como, though a little more touristy and a bit nicer.   
I was just in Domodossola this weekend for a day trip (from Brig, where we were staying).  It's a pretty funky place, but pretty cool.  If you stay in this region, a trip up the Simplon  would get you near Zermatt, and would be a possible if long day trip.     
Basically stay in Orta/Domodossola.  Drive north to Iselle, where you can get the drive-on rail car ferry North to Brig.  It'll save you about an hour of driving.  Go to Zermatt then drive up to Goppenstein and take the Loetschberg auto ferry train across to Kandsteg.  Drive back to Zurich via Luzern - Zug (depending where you're going in Zurich you might be better off driving back via Bern.   
Another option would be to drive all the way to Brig, which should be possible, but it might be a really long day on the Autostrada.

The downstairs is usually run by PTR, which books punk rock, and sometimes metal, and KAB which books indie rock.  The upstairs is run by ZOO which books cutting-edge electronic music, mainly DJs from places like London, Detroit, San Francisco, Amsterdam, etc.   
Place des Volontaires is the address.

We included a stop at Le Gruyere Dairy, then into Gruyere itself for the Castle. There is also the H R Giger Museum there (see my photo gallery).

well, Geneva is an very nice city, Mikey. it was  a hot day out and i was with two girls...what can you do wrong (apart from being flashed by speed radar... )? we rented out a car, drove 2:30h down, parked very central and walked first along the lake. at one pier we found a boat rental and took a small motorboat for a cruise on the lake. it was 50CHF/hour. 
lovely! i mean...the envy grows by the hour because you'll see so many speedboats n yachts...massive! the countryside is amazing! further we walked the city a bit and had lunch in one of those nice lil restaurants up the hill towards st.pauls cathedral. we have climbed the church stairs and had a nice view over the city...and that was it. for other things to explore it was simply too hot, but check it out...

Also to add to the list of things to do...   
I have had my parents here this week and we have visited      - took a boat over the lake to Vitznau (1 hour) then took the mountain railway right up to the top of Rigi, amazing views going up on the train and amazing views from the top, we then took the cable car back down to the village of Weggis and took the boat back to Luzern - a great day out.      - went there today - Drove to Engleberg and took the cable cars up to the top - it was stunning, it was a perfect clear day so we could see for miles and there was so much snow!! Definitely recommend going here....      - Take boat from top of lake (burkliplatz) - takes an hour and a half - beautiful old town      - I didn't go here but my parents said the monastry there was amazing      - Again didn't go here but my parents recommended it      - A good joint trip, we drove to both in a day but you can take a train from Zurich to both - Stein am Rhein is a must see place!      - Not been but its next on my list of things to do!   
Thats about it   
Nicky

Definitely nothing on the scale of Stonehenge or Avebury. Can second the Clendy Stones at Yverdon. In Suisse Romande more to be seen at Lutry (just outside Lausanne) and Sion (Valais). Haven't come across more in my neck of the woods and haven't heard of any in the north but there must be some. As an addict of the the History Channel, Time Team, Discovery Channel and all similar stuff I thought you only tended to find these things in more fertile areas of Europe. They took manpower to erect and depended on a very stable, settled agrarian society. You don't find many in mountainous regions even though stone is obviously plentiful there, probably because folks there were nomadic hunter gatherers and didn't stick in one place long enough to justify building anything permanent. The people who built Stonehenge lugged stone all the way from Wales to the more fertile south of England. In neolithic period people tended not to settle in mountain regions and preferred lowlands, lakes and coasts. Probably explains why two of three I mention are based on lake shores and why the major Scottish ones are near the coast. To head off any experts out there I only know what I've picked up watching repeat after repeat programmes on the above TV channels.  I'm sure there's exception to every rule and there's sure to be a standing stone somewhere which says otherwise. They could be astronomical calendars or navigational aids for alien spaceships for all I know.

Last year we bought quite a lot of our kit from Oschener and also Carrefour, baechli Sports has a good selection but its very very expensive.

post:
It was a long drive, but well worth it.   
Plenty of trike and recumbent manufacturers, including Greenspeed, Challenge, Trice, etc.  Even Santana with a few of their tandems, in particular a beautiful titanium triplet-tandem.   
Outside the main hall, there were lots of velo-cars with their smoothly polished cocoon-like shells, still shiny despite loads of admirers. The test-track was zooming with trikes and 2-wheel recumbents.  Not many places actually sold stuff - we took all that cash for nothing  .  I waited for ages to ask the guys from Challenge about a Jester recumbent, but they were too busy, and with all the lights and people the hall was a bit of a sauna.   
Hall 3 had even-less-conventional bikes, including rowing-power, and feet + arm drives, in-seatpost electric helper motors, all sorts of weird and wonderful things.   
Outside hall 3 was a bicycle powered chainsaw, it was a stationary (ordinary) mountain bike that took the chain-drive forward, then through a second set of gears and onto the bar of a chain saw.  People were welcome to have a go, but I was too chicken because of the language barrier.  Other guys drove it, taking 15 seconds or so to saw through a 12cm square pine beam.   
Unfortunately I forgot my camera.  Seriously considered turning around 140km up the highway.  Anyway, you'll have to search flicker in the coming days for some photos.         
cheers, 
(Mr)Wibble
Around Greifensee (but not all) also around the airport.  But not so local to you.

I also had a great day out around Schaffhausen. Get hold of a bike at either Schaffhausen or Kreuzlingen and follow bike path 2 between these towns. It is about 50kms of flat bike path and quiet roads. You basically follow the shore of the Untersee until you get to the Rhine, passing Stein-am-Rhein which is worth a stop and look and finishing in Schaffhausen ( or vice versa depending where you start) with the many beautiful buildings to be found there and just to finish in style the Rheinfalls at Neuhausen.Last wekend was perfect. I just have a townbike so speed wasn't important and it is dead flat and really relaxing ride.
Thanks for feedback, everyone!  Will check out hotels you recommended + sites you shared.     Cheers!     Jill

I know exactly what it's like... 
here are some of our tried and tested rainy day ideas: 
- IKEA in Aubonne, if the kids are old enough to stay in the playland on their own (from the age of 3) 
- Signal de Bougy, they have a very nice indoor play area. 
- La vallee de la jeunesse in Lausanne. There are other indoor places provided by the 'espace prevention de la cote', e.g. in Morges or Nyon, but the one in Lausanne is the most exiting. 
- different activities at 'Edukids' in St-Sulpice 
- 'children's palace' in Lausanne, on the expensive side, though 
- 'Yatouland' in Geneva, can get a bit scary and loud for very little ones (and parents)

It's a bit more of a hike, but there's always   (in The Netherlands).  We've been a few times, lots of parklands and open space.  If you can pull if off, go for a weekend and hire a bicycle.  Cycling around the bulb fields is fantastic, Lisse and Leiden(sp?) are nice towns too.  The tulips should be at their best for the next few weeks (or so).  If you want a guarantee, ring the gardens or Lisse VVV (tourist info) to ensure the bulbs are out, because if the winter has been cold, they can be a week or so late.   
Make sure you take a raincoat/umbrella though.

post:
Review of Flumserberg Friday night skiing.    
Free on the first Friday of each month and open every Friday from 7.00pm until 10.00pm.    
Only the one lift is open from the Tannenbodenalp car park, it is the 4 seat chair lift that only goes roughly half way up, the longer one from the that same car park is not operating.    
Crowds were pretty heavy from 7.00pm with about a 10 minute wait for the lift later in the evening there was only a 1 minute or so wait time.    
Because only one lift was open the ski area was not so busy. Many people were of an expert level, although the course was only an easy run, I could see from the form they were mostly very good.    
Getting there, take the bus from Flums or go by car to the Tannenbodenalp car park as none of the other lifts are open there is no other option.    
Lighting was good to excellent. White light, no need for goggles so long as it is not currently snowing.    
Overall good to go once or twice in a season. Problem is the run is limited so you will get bored, almost guaranteed. There was even some entertainment on the slopes in the form of clowns with painted faces skiing and some faschtnacht instrument players walking around. Last good point is there are a number of bars along this particular run and these are all open.

Any chance of narrowing that down a bit?   
Avoid Italy and France in August.   
Try Sicily, Sardinia or the west coasts of the British Isles in June or September.   
Hiking in the mountains of Switzerland is quite popular, I understand...

We've taken advantage of the Hotelplan deals a couple times now. One place we highly recommend is Hotel San Gian in St. Moritz (think the Swiss counterpart of Aspen or Whistler). The service is friendly and the food is EXCELLENT (4-course dinner every night).    
For 5 days of skiing (covering 3 mountains), room and breakfast & dinner, the high-season cost is just about CHF 1,000 p.p. (low season is around CHF 700+) My husband and I are heading there again next week.   
A comment on the halbpension - from my understanding Swiss hotel rooms typically already include breakfast, so the "halbpension" is really cost for the dinner during your stay at the hotel.

My two rappen:   
As you are traveling with a little one it might be easiest to fly to Rome and then take the trains (or even rent a car) from there. Florence is only 170 km from Rome and Venice is only 190 from Florence. With a car rental you could stop along where ever your hearts desired as there is lots to see between the cities. (I did it a couple of months ago and really enjoyed the freedom of a car). The train ride from Zurich to Rome is pretty long (over 8 hours I believe) and a flight is generally not that expensive and much quicker. If you're on a limited time frame it would make more sense to not waste a bunch of time in transit.

NYE in Barcelona (to me) = BORING!!!!   All bars and clubs close. Only thing open is restaurants as the tradition is to go eating at a restaurant late evening. Some people will receive the NY at the restaurant, other will eat and then head to Plaza Cataluña where there is a big clock a top one of the buildings. They will all wait for the clock to strike twelve and then proceed to eat 12 grapes before the last stroke of the bell / clock. Then most people either hang out on the streets and wait until the bars re-open at 2am or go home and then go out around 4am to celebrate. Of course, if you are a tourist and it is your first time spending NY in Barcelona or for that matter Spain, no one bothers to tell you that the bars will re-open just a few hours after midnight. I was with friends there and we all had the impression that that was it... eat your grapes, get drunk, go home. Grrrrrrr

Indeed, you have already been advised that Edf means spoken English, with deutsch and french subtitles. If the movie just states D, then it's spoken German only. It's not just kids movies you have to watch out for, but also some of the bigger blockbusters.    
Finally, if a movie wasn't originally in English, then you're out of luck, as there'll be no English subtitles. In other words, be careful with Mel Gibson movies.   
Diem

I take it that you need your ticket to show a US carrier's flight number? Do you work for the US government, I know that Federal workers have to fly US carriers because of this Fly America act.    
The United flight to Washington Dulles (UA 937) continues on to San Fransico. You clear customs etc in Washington.   
Additionally, probably better for you,  United and Swiss code share on the LAX flight so if you book on UA 8600/ UA 8601 you will be on the direct Swiss flight to LAX with a UA number. US don't seem to codeshare though.   
Hope this helps.

Suppose it depends on what you mean by close, an hour and 10 mins by train and you can be on Vierwaldstattersee where you can easily spend a day visiting various towns around the south end of the lake. Can be a bit touristy but my kids loved the William Tell Museum in Burglen and the trip on the lake to Rutli and Tell's Kepelle.

I've done this one three times with boy scouts and I like it:      - Monte Lema - Monte Magno  - Monte Pola - Monte Gradiccioli - Arosio - Mugena - Breno - Miglieglia.   
Horizontal distance: 21 km 
Total altitude difference (upward): 1300m 
Highest point: 1935m above sea level   
The route starts with the climb to Monte Lema, which also can be done in a cablecar. There's a restaurant and a small hostel on the top. Then you follow the ridge which is over the tree line, the sight is nice and sunscreen a must. The descent isn't marked as well as the other parts of the route but once you're on the road there are some possibilities to take the bus instead of walking back to Miglieglia.

If the weather's good, pack a towel and walk along the Limmat until you reach the Werdinsel. Have lunch, frolic in the river and order your chilled continental lagers from the kiosk. Then take the tram back to the city

I agree with ISE, most of the summer ski areas have stopped operating. Titlis and Laax I know don't do summer anymore (or at least didn't last year). We went to Zermatt to do some summer boarding and it fairly good. The pistes are good and wide, but it is only pull lifts that operate, and just like Saas Fee you have to get the lift back up to the top to get the cable car back down to the town.   
Also you need to get up at the crack of dawn to get the cable car, it takes nearly an hour to get up to the ski area, and you can only board/ski until 1pm.  Its a morning only activity.   
Having said that, it is kinda cool to go snowboarding in a t-shirt, and the conditions were surprisingly good.

The sub-title "Free Time" in this topic and the "Entertainment" name in the Entertainment and Dining topic are often confused. Indeed, what one man does in his free time may well be entertainment for another.    
We will reorganise the topics in the near future to make this more clear. In the mean time, use your best judgement.

Does anyone feel like adventuring out to take a train ride up the Alps tomorrow (Sunday)?  I'd like to brave it with someone else who speaks English.   
If no one is up for tomorrow, feel free to suggest another date!

Lausanne, what a wonderfull city, if you know where to look !   
I'm here since 1998 well I had time to see some  wonderfull places, and sometimes, I find new great places I never saw before.   
Well, first one of my favourite place is the Roman Ruines, near Vidy, it's so beatifull, with trees and grass, and a calm place to be with your Wife/husband or lover. There's a little pond with frogs and cute mice.   
How to find ? With the bus 2, "bois de vaux" stations take the first street which bring you to the lake.     
The Main graveyard: 
Ok basicly graveyard isn't a fun place, but his one is just amazing, not so for from the Ruines. It's a big one, with lovely tombstones, and there is a "happy air" I mean, it dosen't look like a sad/dead place, it looks like a place for people to rest, but still be loved by the familie. There's amazing building all over, with artificial ponds, some places looks like video game "alone in the dark". It's also a good place to watchanimals. There is Foxes, loads of birds and squirells ! very quiet and good for a walk.   
How to find: With the bus 4 or 2, "montoie station" the grave door is in front of you     
Mont-repos: 
My favourite aera ! It's an enormous parc, with old castles and bird cage in the middle. Place to walk, and an Ice Cream kiosk. Really lovely, I love to read here, or think, stay alone for  hours and watch trees and sky. The castle is now an olympic official building.     
Just some feet away there is the "tribunal federal" (in the UK it's the Old Baileys of London)   
The Building looks american, but behind the building there's something amazing. 
A wonderfull medieval Tower, with a micro forest all around. Under the tower there is a cave, with a river inside, and from the tower ther's a waterfall. Not known even from people who live here !     
Well that's it for tonight, next time I'll give you tips for places to eat/drink   
Tell us if you know good places in your aeras, also tell me if you visited this places, what do you think of them !   
Have fun !

6 themed visits of the lovely city of Carouge:

We were there just a couple of weekends ago, Bellinzona and the castles are very nice.   
Instead of taking the bus up to Castello di Montebello, you can take a pleasant 15 minute walk from the train station. Turn left outside the station and walk until you get to a square called Piazza Collegiata, with a large church that has a grand staircase called Collegiata dei SS Pietro e Stefano. Turn left up the small street on the far side of the church (the right-hand side when facing the front of the church), where you should find the yellow diamonds that signal all Swiss walking trails. Follow the yellow diamonds up to Castello Montebello (there are quite a few steps, but not too many - my wife had no problem even with a bad knee). You can walk around the grounds for free, or pay 4 CHF to look at their museum.    
As Lob said, you can also get into the grounds of Castelgrande for free, just take the free lift/elevator up there from Piazza del Sole in the middle of town.   
Apparently, the top castle, Castello di Sasso Corbaro, doesn't really have any grounds, but still has a museum that you can pay to visit. However, we never made it up there so you'll have to let us know how it is if you get there.

Having just spent the weekend in Ascona, I can recommend it very highly indeed - a fantastic FREE(!) Lido with a failry large sandy beach (and a smaller stoney one) and lots of facilities for the kids, cafe etc.
